data.name: Linear Algebra
data.html_details:
Overview

Linear algebra is one of the most important parts of mathematics, perhaps as important or more than the Calculus. Peter Lax (NYU) has remarked: "If you can reduce a mathematical problem to linear algebra, you can most likely solve it". The introductory concepts (that we will study in this course) are easy to understand, but are powerful and apply in many contexts.

The applications to various fields are too numerous to mention. Lets just say that the modern world would not be so modern without the application of linear algebra, nor would our understanding of the universe be where it is now. And neither would mathematics be as developed if all kinds of mathematical objects are not studied using linear algebra.

However, the course is mostly mathematical. Applications will be to understand some mathematical objects. In this regard, this course may be regarded as an introduction to abstract mathematics, as reflected in the title of the main textbook.

Its a busy course requiring a lot of effort and enthusiasm. You have to be young and energetic and want to learn a lot very quickly. But why am I saying this? You are Ashoka students. Of course you are young and energetic and want to learn a lot very quickly!

Learning Outcomes

Syllabus: Real vector spaces, subspaces, spanning sets, basis sets, dimension of a vector space. Solution of a system of linear equations. Row space and column space of a matrix, rank of a matrix, elementary row and column operations of a matrix. Inversion of square matrices, rank factorization of a matrix. Properties of determinants. Linear transformations, range and null space of a linear transformation, rank-nullity theorem. Matrix representation of a linear transformation. Inner product spaces, normed linear spaces, examples of different normed linear spaces, orthonormal basis sets. Eigenvalues, eigenvectors, characteristic polynomials. Spectral theorem for real symmetric matrices. Singular value decompositions.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Text book:

Isaiah Lankham, Bruno Nachtergaele and Anne Schilling, Linear Algebra - As an Introduction to Abstract Mathematics, Free online text available from:

https://www.math.ucdavis.edu/~anne/linear_algebra/

We will cover most of thebook including Appendix A.

References.

You may find the following books helpful as supplementary reading in case something is not clear from the textbook.

1. S. H. Friedberg, A. J. Insel and L. E. Spence, Linear algebra, Pearson, 2015.

2. Gilbert Strang, Linear Algebra and its Applications, (4th or 5th edition). (Lectures are also available for these.)

3. Wikipedia is great for mathematics.

Computer algebra system.

We will make extensive use of the computer algebra system SAGE. In the real world, Linear Algebra is done using many different numerical packages. However, we use a symbolic algebra package. SAGE is available at:

www.sagemath.com

Please install it before coming to class. Write to me in case of difficulties. There is a possibility of using it online too, but that has become very slow and irritating. It has to be used as a last resort.

There will be quizzes/assignments every week (in lecture), 2 midterms and a final (all take home). More details will be provided on the first day of class. The best 10 quizzes/assignments will be used to determine the final grade.

The course will cover a range of topics from individuals to ecosystems with an emphasis on theoretical foundations and recent developments in the field. data.name: Responding to Difference: The Aesthetic Turn in International Relations
data.html_details:
Overview

What is the role of theory in making the world intelligible? How does it shape and condition what we look at and how we look at it? Does location matter in IR? This course aims to open up knowledge practices from sites and positions that are usually not immediately addressed or recognized in mainstream debates in International Relations. International Relations is also enacted and performed through various mediums such as popular culture, films, literature, music, art, paintings, museums, sports, etc. The course will enable the students to look at the two-way relationship between aesthetics and international politics − both shaping and structuring the other. It will also underline that aesthetics and its deployments are deeply political acts and not value-neutral. The course will simultaneously familiarise students with conceptual and methodological tools drawn from different fields to understand the art and craft of international politics by other means. In doing so it explores what counter imaginations may exist to conventional disciplinary understandings regarding statehood, citizenship, borders and boundaries, violence, development, human rights, social change and subjectivity as well as what new political horizons and alternative modes of scholarly engagement might unfold from them.

Grading Rubric

Shall be discussed in detail in the syllabus.

Attendance Policy

Attendance in this class is compulsory and will be monitored. After the first three absences, the student’s final grade will be reduced by one point (from an A- to a B+), and by a further point for every additional absence.

data.name: Critical Thinking Seminar: Literary Journalism
data.html_details:
Overview

Literary journalism sits at a happy intersection of literary and journalistic writing. It brings in all the rigour, depth and understanding of a subject that literary writing demands, and then presents in the form of journalistic writing for a wider, non-academic readership through mass and niche media. The course will explore several different forms that exist at this confluence. We will both read and practise forms that include book criticism, long-form essays, critical interviews, in-depth profiles, informed commentary, argumentative opinion and literary juries. We will work not just with text but also videos, podcasts, and social media posts. The course will involve extensive reading of up to a dozen works of fiction.

This course will work as an alternative to Forms of Literature as a mandatory requirement for a Creative Writing minor.

Grading Rubric

- 2 single book reviews

- 1 podcast (group)
- 1 video (group)

data.name: Politics and Psychoanalysis
data.html_details:
Overview

In what ways might we understand politics and various aspects of the political system by studying psychoanalytic theory? In its inverse sense, how might political theory or activity contribute to psychoanalytic reasoning? This course aims to explore intellectual ideas and conversations between primarily these two perspectives, including the disciplinary anxieties and methodologies through which these perspectives are shielded and made relevant. In this course – of thirteen weeks, and twenty sessions – we shall aim to study in depth six broad but critical political phenomenon that have not just shaped contemporary psycho-social dynamics, but have also remained central to the sense of the political at the level of the personal and the public. These themes are: (i) colonialism and racism, (ii) narcissism and political leadership, (iii) sexuality and psychopathology, (iv) violence: individual and communal, (v) hysteria, trauma and guilt, (vi) visuality and psychoanalysis.

Learning Outcomes

.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Lectures: Students are expected to attend all lectures and to have completed the reading assigned for that day before class. Students are expected to be able to participate in colloquies conducted by the professor.

• Cheating: Cheating includes any form of plagiarism, including from any web resources, or collaborating with and/or copying from other students in your graded work. Copying a fellow student’s lecture notes if you miss a class due to illness is accepted; copying lecture notes because you didn’t feel like coming to class is lame. The grade for plagiarism is a straight F.

Grading Rubric

• Mid term essay: This short essay will be written on a question framed by students themselves, drawn from the assigned readings. I usually prefer this write up to be the roadmap of the final essay. data.name: Computer Programming and Applications
data.html_details:
Overview

This hands-on course intends to equip students with the necessary computational tools to apply grad-level economics & statistics to real world problems. While establishing solid foundations in computer programming & data science, the course will focus on applications that not only bring about a deeper appreciation for concepts being taught in other courses but also inspire the students to apply computational techniques to venture confidently into new areas. The intended audience for this course is First Year MA economics students.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

  1. Write python code at least as comfortably as they are able to write math in their notebooks, if not more.

  2. Set up their own Virtual-Lab (using Jupyter); Extract, Transform, Analyse data quickly. Build visualizations & communicate results lucidly.

  3. Naturally incorporate computation (as a technology) in their learning & research workflows to:

    1. Enhance understanding (deeper appreciation of abstract math/stats concepts and insights into economic models),

    2. Build richer applications, and

    3. Attack problems which cannot be solved on paper or otherwise.

  4. Translate mathematical concepts into actionable code, especially in the areas of Linear Algebra, Optimization & Statistics that are relevant to economics.

  5. Venture on their own into picking up advanced computational technologies after the course ends, owing to the strong foundations established in their course.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

- To truly deliver the learning outcomes of this course, it is recommended that each student has a laptop and brings it to the class. Pen and paper can-be distractions in fact – as the core vision of the course is to empower you to transform what you are thinking into something actionable, by harnessing the computational power of machines.

- For students with zero or limited exposure to basic computer science concepts, here is a fun and accessible intro (free Harvard Course): CS50's Introduction to Computer Science | edX . This will also serve as a refresher in case you have not studied programming after school.

Grading Rubric

The grading process is focused on bringing the best out of each student and therefore encourages continuously practicing and iterating to get better:

  1. Weekly Programming Assignments, where the students are encouraged to Collaborate to make the learning process quicker, richer & fun (40%).

  2. Class Interaction: In-class programming tasks, error-spotting, Q&As to encourage Attentiveness (20%) *

  3. Keystone Project: Towards the end of course, students will be asked to form groups of 3 – each group will build an application of their choice and present it to the class. This is to encourage Innovation and Independent thinking (40%).

* In case the course happens remotely, a good part of Attentiveness weightage would get converted into evaluations over live coding sessions, where students will be asked to solve problems on a shared whiteboard and code their solutions together in a co-programming environment.

Attendance Policy

There is no attendance policy as such – but there is an Attentiveness bit in grading (20% weightage). Attendance though, is a necessary, but not a sufficient condition for Attentiveness 😊.

data.name: Game Theory and Applications
data.html_details:
Overview

This course is intended as an application of game theory. The choice of topics may vary with instructor and year. For Spring 2021, I will focus on applications of game theory towards understanding problems of economic development. Game theory is the study of strategic decision making by individual agents. One of the most important insights of game theory is that self interested behaviour by economic agents can lead to suboptimal social outcomes. Problems of economic development may themselves be viewed as situations where the society is trapped in inferior outcomes despite individuals striving for better outcomes. Economic development is, therefore, a very fruitful field for application of game theory. This is what this course will focus on. Some of the topics we will study are development traps, environmental problems, land tenure arrangements in agriculture, problems of savings and credit in developing societies, social learning, institutions and property rights, conflict and violence and problems of establishing trust in society. In every topic, the focus will on how game theoretic modeling can help us understand these problems better and allow us to look for solutions.

Learning Outcomes

1. Understand how simple games can be a very powerful tool to model problems of economic development.

2. Applying game theory to various problems of economic development like coordination problems, environmental degradation, economic and social institutions, financial contracts, social learning, social trust etc.

3. Understanding how such problems in economic development result for being trapped into inferior social outcomes even as individuals strive for their self-interest.

4. Developing an appreciation of how game theory can help us understand and solve wider social problems.

5. Developing a familiarity with the literature on game theory and economic development.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

1. The main textbook is "Games in Economic Development" by Bruce Wydick.

2. In addition, the students should have with them a standard undergraduate game theory textbook like "Strategy" by Joel Watson to serve as a refresher for important game theoretic concepts.

Grading Rubric

There will be three in-class exams. Each exam will count for one-third of the total grade.

No attendance requirement. But attendance is higly recommended in order to keep up with the class.

data.name: Anthropology's Methods
data.html_details:
Overview

There are few disciplines that seem to be so deeply wedded to a method as anthropology is to something called fieldwork and to something related called ethnography. So much so that one often wonders if and to what extent anthropology is method? This course explores the relationships between anthropology and ethnography and those between question and method in the making of the discipline. Indeed, in some ways, the course could also have been named Anthropology's Questions. Here are some other questions we will ask: What might it mean to have an anthropological imagination or an ethnographic sensibility? How are they related? Where does the field of fieldwork begin and end and how does one find it? What is the relationship between a 'site' and 'sight' in constituting the field? How else does one sense the field? How long does it take to arrive at and exist in the everyday and how does one exit? How does one deal with questions of subjects and objects, subjectivity and objectivity, intimacy and scale, the actual and the virtual, power and privilege, anonymity and representation, originality and authenticity? How does one go about uncovering and establishing relationships in practice? What is the role of comparison in anthropology? What does it mean to move relationally and comparatively in conceptual and empirical terms? What are the different ways in which anthropologists approach 'the field' and 'the archive'? How does one go about conducting fieldwork and composing an ethnography? What are disciplinary codes and conventions, how are they established, when are they broken? In what ways might the limitations of anthropology's methods expand our imagination of its very possibilities? Over the semester, this course will attempt to address these and other questions through close reading, discussion and debates on a range of anthropological texts and texts on anthropology and its methods. Students will also complete a series of methodological exercises and assignments, including crafting a short research proposal and paper.

data.name: Global Justice
data.html_details:
Overview

Are there any standards or norms of justice that apply worldwide? If so, what are they? These are the central questions concerning global justice. In both political philosophy and ordinary discourse, it has often been taken for granted that on the global level a just system is a collection of independent states that respect international borders and do not attack each other without provocation. Yet, there are serious challenges to this view.

One set of challenges arises from common intuitions about justice and human rights. Is it just for some states to uphold equal rights for all while others treat minority groups as second-class citizens? Is it acceptable for some states to suppress rights and freedoms considered by many to be basic entitlements for all human beings? If we are tempted to answer “no” to these questions, then we must hold that political communities should not be wholly independent.

Another set of challenges arises from the difficulty of resolving challenges facing the entire globe. How can climate change be slowed and how can its effects be managed? How should resources used by many different states (e.g. seas and oceans) be regulated? Should there be regulations on how communities trade with one another and on what they can trade (for example, should they be able to trade in endangered animals or nuclear weapons)?

Some philosophers have concluded that we should resolve these challenges through voluntary international agreements, others have argued that independent states should be dissolved completely, and others have argued for a diverse range of positions between these two extremes. In this course, we will examine approaches to global justice and consider how they address some of the specific global challenges facing us.

data.name: Crafting identities in Central India: Arts , Crafts and Performative practices
data.html_details:
Overview

This course will focus on critically examining trajectories in artisanal and performative practices from the region of central India in post-Independence India. The states of Madhya Pradesh and the recently created state of Chhattisgarh will form the ambit of discussions. The course will acquaint students with case histories of practitioners, from the ground, to trace trajectories of transformation. It will engage with questions of caste and community, agency and selfhood to understand the shaping of art forms and their contexts as well as well as the role and modes of interventions in these practices, including the work of anthropologists, scholars, museums and institutions, and the market. Students will critically engage with discourses surrounding the representation of these forms, including the binaries of Art versus Craft, or the categories of folk and tribal.

Learning Outcomes

What are the forces that shape the lives and practices of individuals referred to in public discourse as craftsmen, or ‘folk ‘and ‘tribal’ artists in post -independence India? How much agency do they have over their lives and practice and to what extent are they ‘manipulated’ by ‘outside’ mediators? How do caste and community shape their practice, and to what extent is it transformed when negotiating spaces beyond traditional contexts? And how do tradition and modernity parley with each other in the shaping of their work and careers? This course is designed to make students actively debate and engage with these issues and beyond, through case studies of practitioners of both crafts and performative practices from Central India. Oral epics, metal sculptures, clay reliefs, ‘Gond’ painting, body art (tattooing) are some of the practices that will form the focus of discussion. Students will also examine shifts in representation in museums and exhibitions and debate them.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Course Structure and modules

The course syllabi focuses on the following set of practices and forms from Central India, listed below as module topics (1). It follows developments in the lives of practitioners and their practice, to chart trajectories that are outlined below as moduel themes (2).

1. Module topics

‘Gond’ art

The module focuses on the ‘discovery’ of the celebrated artist Jangarh Singh Shyam, by Bharat Bhavan, and the role of J Swaminathan as a key interlocutor in his emplacement within art circuits. It goes on to question the category of Gond art as ‘invented tradition’, tracing trajectories the work of artists following Jangarh Singh Shyam, including Venkat Singh Shyam, Bhajju Shyam. As points of comparison, students will follow the work of Bhuri Bai and Jivya Som Mashe, and trace their ‘discovery’ to interrogate notions of ‘tradition’.

Rajwar clay sculpture

Student will trace the life and art of Sona Bai Rajwar, her discovery by Bharat Bhavan, and subsequent valorisation as gifted artist. Discussions will focus on categories of art versus craft, folk verses popular in the life of this form post Sona Bai Rajwar.

Gadhwa Metal sculpture, Bastar.

The module will focus on the transformation of metal sculptures from Bastar, from objects of ritual use to highly sought after objects in the art market. The work of Jaidev Baghel, metal sculptor from Bastar, will form the pivot of discussions. Students will examine this practice within a larger context of the framing of the field of the ‘tribal’ within Bastar, beginning with the life and career of Verrier Elwin, the well- known anthropologist, whose work was instrumental in shaping the field.

‘Ethnography’ and intervention in contemporary art practice.

Discussions on the work of urban artists in India whose practice has displayed ‘ethnographic’ or interventionist intentionalities, focusing on the artists Meera Mukherjee, Ruth Reeves, Navjot Altaf.

Performative practices

This module looks at shifts in the performances of the Pandvani, (stories of the Pandavas recited in Chhattisgarh), tracing the emergence of ‘professional artists’ and the shifts from oral to textual sources of storytelling. Students will also looks at ‘Nacha’ a form of theatre that became popular in Chhattisgarh in the early years of the twentieth century, examining interventions by Habeeb Tanveer, the modernist theatre director, and the trope of ‘indigenism’ in modernist art discourse.

Subalternity in Chhattisgarh.

The module will look at the performative practices of the Ramnamis, a community that perform bhakti and resist upper caste practices by tattooing their bodies with the name of the divine.

2. Module themes

Central India: mapping the field

The theatre is a memory machine, dreamscape, courtroom, pageant, arena, living room, and hall of debate rolled into one—remembering, imagining, interrogating, entertaining, reflecting, feeling, and deliberating through shared experience. data.name: Introduction to Children’s Literature
data.html_details:
Overview

What we read as children forms who we become and provides our first world view. This course provides an opportunity to critically assess the stories that shaped our own understanding of morals, culture, and values, as well as those we will impart to future generations. In this discussion-oriented interactive course, we will read and review children’s books, examine the purposes of visual literacy, and write reviews on specific authors and illustrators.

This course aims to examine how the books children read – from Aesop’s Fables to Amar Chitra Katha comics and the Harry Potter series – shape their outlook and emotional development. We will study the historical, creative, nurturing, emotional, and educational aspects of these forms of literature and their impact on us later in life. We will also consider why a study of children’s literature is important, and how it impacts pedagogies for children across borders.

We will also examine the views of multiple theoretical thinkers and texts in conjunction with actual children's literature. We will ask the important but often overlooked questions about this particular genre, mainly focusing on Indian and American children’s literature. The purpose is not so much to compare these two cultural offerings, but to give us a taste of both.

We shall also consider popular books for children up to 12 years old, including Harry Potter & The Philosopher’s Stone, Amar Chitra Katha, Matilda, The Little Prince, and Alladin. At the same time, we will also study theoretical thinkers such as Jack Zipes, Seth Lerer, Paulo Freire, and Bruno Bettelheim to help us navigate the complex field of children’s literature in relation to issues of culture, religion, difference, gender, and sexuality.

We will also explore the didactic intent as well as the pleasure principle that might have prompted the writers. Authorial intent is, however, only one part of our study; the other part is to see how children and parents receive these stories. Children’s literature creates moral as well as national frameworks that help acculturate young people. In examining the genre of children’s literature, we will consider various sub-genres such as picture books, fairy tales, fables, and chapter books.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Below are the primary readings which you must have ordered before hand. Other readings, especially picture books, can be seen in the library or online.

  1. Rushdie, Salman. Haroun and the Sea of Stories London: Penguin (1990).
  2. de Saint Exupery, Antoine. The Little Prince [Translated by Richard Howard] (2000).
  3. Rowling, J.K. - Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (1997).
  4. Dahl, Roald. Matilda (1988). University of Chicago Press (2009).
  5. Chandra, Nandini. The Classic Popular: Amar Chitra Katha (1967-2007), Yoda Press (2008).
  6. Lal, Ranjit. The Battle for No.19, Penguin India (2007).

Grading Rubric

  2. In-class writing : 10%
  3. Class Presentations : 10%
  4. Visual Literacy project : 5%
  5. Disney Blog (in-class) : 5%

  7. Final paper : 35%

Attendance Policy

After three absences, a letter from your final grade will be deducted for each missed class. If you have 3 unexcused absences, I will reserve the right to fail you for the course. Coming more than 5 minutes late to class will count as an absence. Participation in-class discussions are an essential requirement. This means listening as well as responding and reacting to the ongoing discussions about the readings. Your ability to raise issues and questions that occurred to you while you read the texts demonstrates your attention to the readings. data.html_details:
Overview

In this course, you will develop and rehearse the habits that are essential to the development of a critical mind: reading, writing, speaking, listening and - of course - thinking. You will engage with a variety of source materials and understand how to ask questions that extend and enrich your understanding -- of situations, texts, institutions and people. You will explore the distinctness of academic research and writing, and participate in an active knowledge community constituted by your peers. By the close of the course, you will have a clearer understanding of what it means to be a scholar in an academic setting, and a keener sense of your own processes of learning, thinking and writing

Learning Outcomes

Writing

1. Developing the craft of outlining, revising, editing

2. Applying form, voice, style, tone to affect writing

3. Developing logical, coherent, structured writing

4. Using explanatory, narrative and justificatory writing

Reading:

1. Breaking down texts into identifiable parts.

2. Making patterns and connections across texts

3. Building reading stamina and the ability to select texts

4. Understanding textual context, genre and source material

Thinking

1. Practising converting thoughts into words

2. Narrowing down a curiosity or thought into a question

3. Constructing and developing a reasoned argument

4. Engaging meaningfully with multiple perspectives

Speaking-Listening

1. Aiming for confidence, clarity, coherence

2. Practising and harnessing audience engagement

3. Developing active and respectful listening to others

4. Engaging meaningfully with ongoing discussions

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)
You can expect to do regular reading (of academic texts and wider materials) in this course. The reading list will be communicated to you directly by your instructor and will be included in your course outline as well. In addition, you can expect to write consistently, participate in giving and taking feedback, and work on medium-term projects both individually and in collaboration with your coursemates.

The ICT will be graded on a broad rubric, listed below. The weightage of the elements, their exact definition, and the decision to add new elements, will be at the discretion of the ICT instructor, using student input from the particular ICT section.
1. Participation (in classes, meetings and peer work)
2. Research paper (a longform argumentative paper with citations, written in academic style)
3. Small summative assignments (including homework, and shorter assignments such as outlines and drafts)
4. Improvement over the course

For this course, you are allowed three unexcused absences (for which you do not need permission from the instructor) and two excused absences (for which you do need permission from the instructor). The penalty for any absence beyond these five will be decided by the ICT instructor on a case-by-case basis. Please note that a consistent pattern of non-attendance may include penalties such as grade cuts, at the ICT instructor's discretion

Food in Film and Literature

This course will use food as a catalyst to open up questions around identity, politics, intimacies, memory and other themes. We will learn to employ critical frameworks through close reading of prescribed texts, especially through film and fiction. Overview

In a liberal arts university where the emphasis is on original thinking and the pursuit of knowledge (as opposed to grades/ degrees), you will find yourself drawn into many conversations, whether purely academic or about the world we inhabit. You will find that these ongoing conversations will be enriched more and more by your contributions, as you learn to think critically, argue effectively, and write seriously. The aim of this course is to:

  1. Familiarize you with genres – and attendant jargon – that you might encounter in the course of your academic life, in Ashoka and beyond;
  2. Nudge you towards finding your own voice;
  3. Teach the fundamentals of scholarly research in a discipline-agnostic way;
  4. Hand-hold you as you become comfortable with the writing process, irrespective of what you might be required to write;
  5. Inculcate habits that will stand you in good stead for the rest of your life.

THINKING

SPEAKING-LISTENING

Learn to locate scholarly sources

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

I prefer to keep an element of surprise to the readings in class. Do note, however, that you will need to read a reasonable amount every week to keep up with classes.

Grading Rubric

Each assignment will be accompanied by its own grading rubric. However, class participation, cumulative homework, attendance and overall enthusiasm will also contribute to your final grade.

Attendance Policy

Since your contributions in the classroom are noted and add to your final grade, do try to be regular and punctual. Email your PT/TA if there is a problem with technology on any day. Remember, the philosophy of this class is that every week we build on what was accomplished in the previous week. It’s not a syllabus-based course where you merely ‘cover’ something that was missed on your own, but a collaborative studio space where your contribution to each class actually shapes it. So, regularity is of the essence.

data.name: Material Theatre and Camera as Languages of Performance
data.html_details:
Overview

Tuaght by Anurupa Roy

What does material communicate on stage or in a performance space? What is the language of dead material? What happens when the camera interacts with material? Thus together we will explore the space between technique and improvisation, realism and abstraction, visual language and oral narratives.

The students will be introduced to performance forms where materials lead e.g Shadow puppet theatre, Material Theatre, Story boxes (Kavada), Scrolls, Paper theatre and Object Theatre. Each session will include an introduction to a form and a hands on exercise based on the form. The students will finally pick one form and create an individual creative response to the form. Also included will be a series of lectures on traditional puppet theater, contemporary puppet theater around the world and the history of animation.

Grading Rubric

The majority of the course work will take place in class. Hence, attendance and participation in class are the main criteria for grading.

Attendance Policy

Students can take up to 2 unexcused absences.

data.name: The Photo Story: Photography and Story-Telling
data.html_details:
Overview

Taught by Anshika Varma

Story Telling lies at the core of human communication, it has held our histories of being and often helped create fantastical worlds we learn to give birth to. The power of images to cross barriers of language, geography, and culture is greater today than ever before. And in an era of profound change in the way images are made and interpreted, this course on photography looks at the evolution and place of The Photo Story today. Regular assignments will be given to help students move out of their comfort zones, engage with new perspectives and self realizations by reaching for higher levels of creative awareness. Over a period of 13 sessions, The Photo Story looks to delve in to a student centered curriculum with emphasis on learning through observation and practical hands-on experience in Photography and Story Telling. Students of the program explore the history of photography and it’s development as a unique voice in the region, the role of photography in story-telling and the relationship between photography and its evidentiary power, the current emerging contemporary practices of the medium and its growing engagement as a language. The program looks to emphasize on a supportive learning atmosphere with regular photography projects, discussions and critique sessions. All modules mentioned will have a theory as well as a practical engagement to support the development of technical skills for those interested to pursue this field further.

Grading Rubric

The majority of the course work will take place in class. Hence, attendance and participation in class are the main criteria for grading.

Attendance Policy

Students can take up to 2 unexcused absences.

data.name: The Ashoka Conversation
data.html_details:
Overview

Course Description: The Ashoka Conversation is designed as a a 200 level course to give students a hands on learning experience in conceptualizing, designing and editorial framing of a weekly digital news magazine. This is an ambitious course that seeks to put in place the structure and production of a live media resource entirely run by Ashoka Students.

Students who enroll in this course will ‘learn on the job’. Through the rigor of academic discipline and the commitment of journalistic integrity students run Open Axis- a weekly Multi-media blog project on the lines of the internationally acclaimed website “The Conversation” that was set up as a non-profit network that publishes in depth news stories and content. Though the semester, students will be taught editorial decision making, ideating thematically for an issue, creating content themselves as well as commissioning articles through the University based on the specific editorial requirements for each issue.Class interactions are in the nature of editorial meetings, where students edit, write and commission articles, record podcast interviews and upload them in an organised fashion by set deadlines in rotating groups.

Grading and Coursework: Under faculty supervision, class will be conducted on the lines of bi-weekly editorial meetings and will function as a mini-newsroom. Class participation will be at a premium when it comes to grading. Individual grades will be based on individual articles written and commissioned, and extra work in the nature of design, audio visual inputs and ideas that are brought in.

Students who take this course are expected to display excellent writing skills in terms of both flair and content.

In its fourth iteration, in Spring 2022, Open Axis will be general news website, with a focus on electoral politics. Media Studies, English, Creative Writing and Political Science students are particularly encouraged to apply.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The daily news.

Grading Rubric

6 issues of Open Axis will be published through the semester. Each issue will be worth 15 marks, where 7 marks will be a group grade- 5 for overall editorial of the issue, 2 marks for social media promotions,

8 marks will be individual grades- 3 marks for successful commissions and 5 for independent articles.

The class of 15 students will be divided into 3 editorial groups. Individual grades will be assigned to 4 out of the 6 issues, and group grades for 2- for each individual student.

The remaining 10 marks will be for attendance.

Attendance Policy

students will not be allowed more than 2 unexcused absences for the semester. Editorial meetings are crucial for newsrooms, and must not be taken lightly.

Overview

In this course, we will use economic principles to analyze decisions made within a family. Topics include spousal labor supply, human capital, marriage, divorce, fertility and social mobility. We will then consider the macroeconomic implications of these family decisions. First, we will focus on short- and medium-run fluctuations and study how the changing demographic factors influence aggregate labor supply and savings. Next, we will discuss the importance of accounting for families in explaining inequality and as determinants of long-run economic development.

data.name: Agrarian Worlds: Land, Culture and Power
data.html_details:
Overview

How has capitalism impacted the agrarian world? Have these impacts been homogenous across time and space? How have agrarian societies around the world responded to the capitalist and neoliberal forces? These are but some of the questions that this course examines in trying to understand the modern transformations of the rural/agrarian world and the broader socio-political implications thereof. The course is theoretically rigorous, yet empirically grounded, focusing on cases from different parts of the world. It covers a wide range of issues, including the classical agrarian question, contemporary agrarian debates, green revolution and its legacies, the question(s) of food, land and water grabbing, farmer suicides in India, gender and agriculture, transnational peasant movements, and the recent farmers protest in India. As part of the course, students will also get a chance to watch some iconic films on the agrarian worlds. This course will be run as a seminar, which means students will be expected to actively participate in class discussions.

Grading Rubric

- Class Participation

- Critical Response Papers

- Class Presentations

- Final Research Paper

data.name: Psychotherapy: Theoretical Foundations and Research
data.html_details:
Overview

Psychotherapy: Theoretical Foundations and Research.

Course Description
This course is an introduction to the prominent theoretical approaches to psychotherapy (e.g, analytic, psychodynamic, behavioural, cognitive, humanistic) and their clinical application in addressing mental health, relational and existential concerns. In surveying the major psychotherapy systems, this course will place special emphasis on research and address general issues and controversies related evidenced-based practice. We will explore ethical and multicultural considerations related to the study, theory, and practice of psychotherapy. Example case studies and videos will be used to illustrate the principles of therapeutic change.

Learning Outcomes

1.Introduce the history and evolution of psychotherapy
2.Explore the ethical issues associated with psychotherapy practice and research
3.Understand the principles of psychotherapeutic change and the role of thetherapeutic relationship
4.Critically evaluate psychotherapy research, as well as current controversiessurrounding the integration of science and practice.
5.Reflect on the role of cultural diversity, privilege and oppression, andmulticultural issues with respect to the practice and study of psychotherapy
6.Explore contemporary approaches to psychotherapy and the integration of theoriesinto practice

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

All lectures and office hours will be online so a working internet connection with audio and video capability will be necessary.

Required Readings:

Corey, G. (2017) Theory and Practice of Counseling and Psychotherapy, Cengage., 10th edition, Boston, MA: Cengage Learning.

Recommended Readings:

American Psychological Association (2019). Publication manual of the American Psychological Association (7th ed.). Washington, DC: APA.

Yalom, I.D. (2009), The Gift of Therapy: an Open Letter to a New Generation of Therapists and Their Patients. 1st Harper Perennial ed. New York: Harper Perennial.

**Please note that I may change/add readings to those mentioned in the syllabus. I will announce changes in readings (if any) during our class at least one week prior to when I expect you to read the articles**

•Attendance and Participation - 5% of final grade

•Research Paper - 20 %

•Exam 1- 25% of final grade

•Reflection paper - 30 % of final grade

•Final paper - 20% of final grade

Attendance Policy

Ideally, I would like students to actively participate in class and have at least 80% attendance.
Research has shown that students who attend class regularly tend to receive better grades than students with sporadic attendance. This is likely to also be true in this class, as class participation will account for 5% of your final grade. The evaluation of class participation will rest primarily on (a) attendance, and (b) the synthesis of the readings and the presented material, as communicated during classroom discussion. Attendance therefore is strongly encouraged and students who cannot attend a class meeting(s) for any reason are responsible for the material covered those days.

data.name: Principles of Science
data.html_details:
Overview

Science entails systematic pursuit of knowledge, which essentially involves unbiased observations and multiple methods of validation. Science gives us the ability to understand how our world works and how we interact with our physical surroundings. It not only incorporates basic ideas and theories about how our universe behaves but it also provides a framework for learning more and tackling new questions and concerns that come our way. Science also provides an unparalleled view of the order and symmetry of the universe and its workings—subatomic particles to the never-ending space. Science enables you to integrate with your surroundings, both living and non-living. It has also given us the tools to alter living and non-living things. It has the potential to have both positive impacts such as coping with natural disasters, curing diseases, and discovering new sources of energy, as well as negative impacts in the form of climate change and weapons of mass destruction.

The course narrates some of the key theoretical and technical developments in the evolution of the sciences and offers a synoptic view of the development of concepts that drive modern science.

Lecture topics

What is Science

data.html_details:
Overview

This course will focus on a set of texts that offer powerful critiques of the societies the authors lived in. They seek to disturb our conception of the social normal, what we take for granted, and what we see as acceptable. They help us understand how and why we might see things differently from those who lived a century or two earlier, and why what we are likely to consider unacceptable and discriminatory now was normal in earlier times. They make us sensitive to structures of social oppression and domination, and help us understand how discriminatory social complexes – of race, gender, caste, class – operate within society. By juxtaposing texts from different times and regions in the world, the course will explore how seemingly similar issues are conceptualized in historically specific ways in different societal contexts.

Learning Outcomes

A discussion of these texts will help us understand how our lives, our subjectivities, and our identities are shaped by the hegemonic cultural, social, economic structures of the societies we live in, and the way these constitutive structures are questioned and refigured.

In the course of the semester we will also explore how texts can be read. How do we relate the text to the author, or to the historical context of its production? Is the meaning of the text fixed, or does it change over time? What happens when a text circulates, and is interpreted in diverse ways in different times and in different places? Finally, through these explorations, we will also ask: what makes a text great? Is greatness inherent in the text itself, embedded within it, or is it constituted over time, in the way it is received and the significance it acquires historically?

In this course we shall be looking at some books and excerpts from books – philosophical texts, a sonnet sequence, plays, an epic and a treatise - that engage with ways of thinking about empowerment, gender and related issues. Fundamental questions that we are grappling with today have been raised since classical times. If Wollstonecraft was regarded as a radical by her contemporaries in the 1790s, passages in the works of the fifth century BC philosopher Plato are equally radical along the same lines. Aeschylus and Shakespeare weave patterns of magic into their considerations of gender and empowerment. Perhaps the most powerful questioning and dismantling of the tradition of disenfranchisement is in Milton’s Paradise Lost and the most memorable suggestion of the way forward is also there. The experience of reading seminal texts both deepen our understanding of these issues and enrich our lives through our encounter with these great books.

This course guides students through a multiplicity of performance practices existing on the subcontinent. These practices include the locally specific, the socially specific, the traditional, the hereditary, the rural, the nomadic, the urban, the pan-Indian, as well as those practices with discernible connections to performance conventions beyond the specifically Indian context. An important premise of this course is that music, dance and theatre are three strands of an intertwined whole. Their closely related cultural, social and aesthetic histories will constitute the core material to be studied. While acknowledging a cultural corpus often possessing obvious mutual affinities, this course will give pride of place to the wide varieties of performance practices found in India and the divergent histories accompanying them. Have you ever wondered what Arab Spring, Occupy Wall Street, MeToo and the Tea Party have in common? Not much, you might think. On the contrary, quite a lot. Even when they are vastly different from each other in politics, whether left or right-wing, radical or conservative, highly organized or very diffused, they are all examples of social movements. It is quite likely that you are often asked to tweet, friend, like or donate for some social cause. That is because social movements are propelled by the rhetoric and politics of emotions. It is true that intense emotions like those of anger, fear, disgust, love, empathy or grief are habitually invoked for social mobilizations and persuasion by most populist leaders. To study rhetoric and social movement therefore, is to study how dissent from poor and working-class people, women, people of color, LGBTQ activists, the disabled, immigrants, and other incompatible voices, come together in diverse ways to aid in building justice.

data.html_details:
Overview

We are living in a time of amazing technological advances. Effects of these emerging technologies are everywhere. From the Google search that you do to the things, you buy on Amazon or Flipkart to the recommended shows that you watch on Netflix. Even in Grammarly's editorial suggestions as I type this description up!

What will the impact of Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Learning (ML) on our economy and society be? Technology giants like Amazon, today have hundreds of economists working for them. What is it that these economists do? These are some of the questions that this course will try to answer.

We will begin the course by understanding what technology and innovation mean to an economist and why are they important. Then tools learned in earlier courses in macro and microeconomics will be used to develop an understanding of the economics of automation and emerging technologies such as AI. In doing so we will also focus on aspects of the data and digital economy including privacy. This understanding will then be used to study the effect of such technologies on a range of topics such as employment and the future of jobs, economic growth, organisation of businesses, etc.

The students should have completed courses in microeconomics, game theory, and growth theory. Knowledge of differential calculus and the basics of integration will also be required. Some knowledge of regression analysis will be useful.

data.name: Cognitive Neuroscience : A Clinical Perspective
data.html_details:
Overview

Welcome to “Cognitive Neuroscience”! This course will cover the main areas of Cognitive
Neuroscience, that is the science of the biological bases for cognition , i.e. the relationship between
the nervous system‘s structural and physiological mechanisms and the psychological reality of the
mind. Following an overview of the anatomy of the human brain, we will then look into the neural
processes underlying cognitive functions including sensory cognition, memory, attention, language
and music, reward and decision making, consciousness and time. Along the way, we will learn about
the methodologies used to study these functions: neuropsychological work in patient populations (e.g.
stroke, degenerative diseases) to brain imaging at the macro- and microscopic level (e.g. magnetic
resonance imaging, MRI; electro/magnetoencephalography, M/EEG) and brain stimulation
techniques (e.g. transcranial magnetic stimulation, TMS; or deep brain stimulation, DBS) and
computational modelling and brain-computer interfacing.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The course will in part follow the text book “Cognitive Neuroscience”, by world-renowned
researchers Michael Gazzaniga et al. (which remains the gold standard in its field) including exciting
chapters from its newest edition (2020). In addition, the course will heavily draw on scientific
research articles (presented by the instructor as well as by the students), which will range from
seminal “classics” to hot-off-the-press ones, whereby the final list of papers presented will be
determined by the students’ specific choices.

Recommended prerequisite:
Introduction to Neuroscience.

Grading Rubric

About half of the course is taken up by lectures and presentations given by the instructor, whilst the
other half is taken up by student presentations. The course will familiarize you not only with the
topics of the course, including a general and specific knowledge on classical as well as cutting-edge
research findings, but also give you insights with how the world of research works and provide
valuable training and practice in presenting research papers in the safe environment of peers. In both
the lectures and presentations, interactive discussions based on questions, curiosity and critical
thinking are highly encouraged. Your input into these discussions is welcome in any and all forms,
whichever suits you and the occasion best (raising your hand & voice, chat or even email if preferred
although a bit cumbersome and of course not immediate). The final grade will be a composite score
including participation, presentation, exam questions and an essay exam.

data.name: Drawing as Extended Play
data.html_details:
Overview

This course is envisaged to create scope for exploring possibilities of inclusion of soundscapes, text, performance, and performativity with drawings. Thinking of the everyday through the prism of theatrical reality, the course encourages inquiry about how can drawings and the act of drawing itself be a dialogue about provisionality, uncertainty, and change. How do artists and artistic explorations address issues of meaning-making and shared history, politics, and culture?

How does the process of repetition, layering, overlapping, erasure, and incision transform an image, leading to alternative perspectives about how we perceive and engage with the known?

Recognizing the importance of contradictions, ambiguity, and serendipity as integral to processes of meaning-making, students have the flexibility to make interventions that can vary from being poetic, polemic, theatrical, metaphorical, incisive, etc. You are encouraged to borrow from processes of design, craft, and theatre and bring them into the domain of visual art. Typically class assignments would include lots of viewing (of William Kentridge, Kara Walker, Nalini Malani, Jitish Kallat, and others) and making, along with snippets of readings, recording, editing, collating, and assembling.

By taking figures and forms out of their familiar settings and putting them in a ‘fluid’ and fantastical environment where seemingly unrelated sounds, text, and projections respond to one another, the course encourages students to attempt blurring of boundaries between fiction and reality.

Course Structure

  • Session I-Introduction to the course, course readings, materials, and assignments
  • Session II- Getting started with the process book; understanding its functional, aesthetic and conceptual role
  • Session III- Understanding how to translate ideas from the fields of literature, poetry, and theatre into a visual form
  • Session IV- Assignments on drawing processes, including collage, assemblage, and cut-outs
  • Session V- Creating multiples of the drawing using printmaking and stenciling
  • Session VI- Exploring possibilities of movement using analog and digital processes
  • Session VII- Exploring possibilities of association of form with text and sounds
  • Session VIII- Introducing gestural and performative interventions in the form of projections overlaid onto drawings
  • Session IX- Students work on their individual project
  • Session X- Students work on their individual project
  • Session XI- Students work on their individual project
  • Session XII-Discussion and review of the final projects
  • Session XIII-Project Presentation & display
Learning Outcomes
  • An understanding of drawing as a visual language with transmedia and transdisciplinary possibilities and concerns
  • An experience of working across media, materials, and materiality

data.name: Metric and Topological Spaces
data.html_details:
Overview

The study of large or infinite classes of objects interacting with each other, there is a need to impose various structures to understand their properties better. The common notions of objects being nearby or close to each other need to be mathematically formulated in order to get at a more quantitative as well as qualitative understanding of such large classes. The subject of mathematical analysis grew out of the study of considerations such as convergence, continuity, rate of change, etc.

Our course will give an introduction to the basic concepts and tools of mathematical analysis. The notion of distance gets axiomatized by that of a metric space. To get the sense of continuity and plug holes needs the concept of completion, and so on.

We will try to illustrate these concepts by examples and the applications will point out the usefulness of these concepts. Thus the course will be based on examples and applications of the theory that will be developed during the course.

Learning Outcomes

The various concepts and methods of mathematical analysis and their applications: convergence, metric spaces, completion, compactness, topological spaces, and continuity, connectedness, etc.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

W. Rudin, Principles of Mathematical analysis.

James R. Munkres: Topology, a first course

It is an art of composing space (as totality or fragment, continuous or discontinuous) and time (linear or non-linear) through the arrangement, assembly and interaction of images (static or dynamic) and sounds (on-screen or off-screen). This course will enable students to gain an in-depth understanding of key issues, debates, and theoretical perspectives, and to critically analyze the relationship between culture, media, and society.

Through the course, students will closely examine mass media forms such as news, film, television, advertising, and the digital space and will explore how our everyday engagements with media are influenced and structured by broader economical, political, ideological, and social contexts.

Mass media shapes our understanding of the world. This course has been created to recognize the utmost need for media literacy in contemporary times. The course aims to create smart and critical consumers, creators, and participants of mass media. At the end of the course, the students will be able to identify and develop an understanding of Media theories and analyze media practices globally. Overview

ENG-2002-1 Literature in the Age of Empire Sharif Youssef

TR 11:50-1:20

ENG 2002-2 Literature in the Age of Empire Sharif Youssef

TR 3:10-4:40

In 1773, the imperial administrator George McCartney wrote enthusiastically of Britain’s “vast empire on which the sun never sets and whose bounds nature has not yet ascertained.” This notion of a territory that the sun always shines upon and whose boundaries defy nature and the imagination became increasingly popular and contentious during the eighteenth century and nineteenth century. With the colonies of North America, the commerce in India, Ceylon, Turkey, and the Middle East, the slave trade across the Atlantic, and the exploration of the Pacific, the interests of eighteenth-century and nineteenth-century Britain were indeed world-wide. In this class, we will use concepts such as “empire” and the “globe” to organize English literature and culture. In particular, we will examine eighteenth-century and nineteenth century literature’s “global consciousness” by looking at the texts of British writers who act globally and of colonial subjects who “write back” to empire. These texts will include novels, poems, letters, paintings, engravings, and more. While analyzing them, we will consider the extent to which British writing advances and questions the creation of empire, and determine how notions of empire change what it means to be a British subject. We will draw from theories of post-colonialism, global history, nationalism, and world literature to interpret texts that range from Scotland, Ireland, North America, the Caribbean and Africa, India, and the South Pacific.

Grading Rubric

A-F

Attendance Policy

As per syllabus

SAN 2001 is a course that combines a study of Sanskrit grammar with reading exercises. In the grammar lessons, we will review the Sanskrit verbal system and cover some topics in syntax. At the same we time we will cultivate a familiarity with literary Sanskrit by reading from Aśvaghoṣa’s Buddhacarita (ca. 1st century CE). Introduction

The objective of ‘Elementary Sanskrit-I’ is to introduce interested learners to basic Sanskrit grammar.

The word 'Sanskrit' is synonymous with a continuous trail of intellectual traditions in language and literature which includes the Vedas, vedangas, epics, puranic traditions, etc. These intellectual traditions serve as storehouse of knowledge that waits to be decoded and explored which is precisely why they intrigue researchers even today. Institutions working in applied research in Indian psychology study and interpret the Sanskrit texts based on yoga. The central preoccupation of modern social theory—from the 18th century onwards—has been to plumb the nature and possibility of the social bond in a non-religiously sanctioned social order. This is an elective course in advanced macroeconomics that will cover various issues related to the conduct of monetary policy and fiscal policy.

The Global Financial Crisis highlighted how important an understanding of the banking sector is for macroeconomic policy makers. The first part of this course will briefly study the economic justifications for money and how banks play a central role in creating money – and hence having an impact on inflation beyond the control of the central bank. This is a course about migrations into the Indian subcontinent, and how they gave shape to new languages, primarily across the north and down the western coast, and what this tells us about a people’s history of this region.

What we will focus on is how the languages spoken all across the north of the subcontinent emerged. We start millennia ago with Sanskrit and the different Prakrits, searching out the backstories of the modern North Indian languages spoken today. This will give a picture of how early Indians met and mixed with mostly male explorers who came and settled in this land, a fusion that is still visible in the sounds, grammars and words of the languages they made. We will see how, often, the languages of the ‘little people’ shaped the grammars of the modern languages, while the migrating men contributed the superficial layer of vocabulary. We will see why the languages of the northwest, as far east as Hindi and down to Konkani, constitute a single sub-family, while the languages of the east, from the dialects of eastern Uttar Pradesh to Bengal, Odisha, Assam form a different sub-family which is still expanding, and how that goes back to the two regions having different linguistic substrata on account of the differences in the early local people and the early migrants who settled there.

We will examine different models of how languages mix, going on to look at different situations in the subcontinent where, over the ages, local elites and ‘little people’ came to terms in different ways with new power structures which called for adjustments, creating Prakrits as well as more radically mixed varieties. This will mean stretching our minds back to imagine how things might have been before the early empires appeared, spreading Prakrits across the north of this land. We will also see how that gave way to the connected web of languages we have today, with the influence of those early Prakrits continuing to spread into India like slowly cooling lava. We will then go on to think about English, the newest player in Indian language power structure. And we will end our journey by looking at the other end of the life cycle: Indian languages that are threatened as their speaker communities move on.

Overview

This course will focus on the history and evolution, sounds and images of Malayalam poetry. It is designed in a way that a person who is new to Malayalam can appreciate poetry in this language. With this aim, I have decided to focus on one particular characteristic of Malayalam poetry, which is its oral heritage and inheritance. Most of Malayalam poetry of the past was written to be memorised and sung/chanted/recited, like in most Indian languages. However, this tradition continues to dominate in Malayalam to this day. And, it is also a poetic tradition, where genres have emerged with distinct links to performance. This ranges from poetic forms written for the stage such as Kathakali and Ottan Thullal, to be sung by oarsmen (Vanchi Pattu), and in the modern age, for public recitals (Chol Kazhcha).

The course will introduce students to poets, poems, movements, who/that have an organic link to this musical and performance inheritance, over 12 lectures. Poems taken up for discussion are those available in English translation. I will also use audio recordings, documentaries and may even have a couple of poets recite their work for students on Zoom. The intent of the course is to enable a person to appreciate Malayalam poetry, particularly through its rhymes and rhythms, rather than impose a theoretical take on its history and aesthetics.

From one voice to many, from simple homophony to complex polyphony, from unaccompanied a capella singing to the gradual use of instruments, from liturgical texts to vernacular lyrics—varied singing styles flourished in the 15th and 16th centuries. A major song form that evolved in parallel with the sacred motet was the secular madrigal. In this course we will explore the context in which some of these song forms developed and sing them in diverse languages. Familiarity with western music notation would be helpful but is not essential.

In this course, students will discover how sacred and secular ritual forms have and continue to influence contemporary theatre practices. Through improvisation, collaborative devising, and theatre games and exercises that draw on psychophysical praxis, they will grapple with questions like – What is a ritual? How can the power of ritual awaken, challenge and nourish the actor’s inner life? Can the physical enactment of ritual transform perception and presence? What can theatre practice offer us in an uncertain, rapidly evolving world like ours? Students will also develop their own individual and collective rituals based on personal inquiry into their own lived experiences, creative impulses and immediate needs.

Instead of focusing on learning the form as it has been, carried forward and handed over to new learners by Gurus, dancers, teachers and experts over decades, it attempts to find points of entry and points of departure through the body (or collective bodies) located in the present socio-political and cultural context. We try to navigate queries like 'what would be the negotiations of a body to embody Odissi'? By large, mitigating our fears, challenges and curiosity of the "Indian Classical Dance Forms' become a crucial aspect of this negotiation. data.name: Visual Journaling with the Mobile Phone Camera
data.html_details:
Overview

Taught by Dinesh Khanna

The best camera is the one with you. And which is the one that is always, well mostly, with us? The mobile phone camera, of course. So that takes care of the hardware. And what do we do with it? Take pictures, snaps, clicks, captures, selfies, et al. And what do these represent? A haphazard and largely incoherent account of our lives. However, our days and our lives have so many interesting incidents which when strung together would make for really interesting stories to tell, share and preserve.

Now consider this. The number of images shot and shared every day is believed to be over 2 billion. Yes, every day. On the negative side, one can feel that's like a tsunami which we all are drowning in. However, on the positive side, one can say that the most used language today is photography. And we are all fluent in the language but tend to be rather flippant and chaotic in using it. The idea of this course is to understand how to approach image-making and storytelling in a more mindful and purposeful manner in order to create a visual journal of our lives and matters that interest us, using photographs, words, feelings and maybe, even music.

data.name: Conservation Policy in the Developing World
data.html_details:
Overview

Course Title: Conservation Policy in the Developing World (Instructor G. Shahabuddin)

Many of the policies relating to biodiversity conservation in developing economies are made and implemented without adequate knowledge of ecology or the socio-political and historical contexts of ecological degradation. The aim of this course is to help students of environment and development effectively integrate ecological concerns with sustainable development policy as is articulated by donor agencies, scientific organizations, governments and civil society. The course will begin with giving an understanding of the processes underlying the loss of biodiversity and ecosystem degradation as well as its consequences for ecosystem function. The historical and political dimensions of species loss and conservation policy will also be discussed. After this introduction, the course will turn to critically exploring prevalent and emerging paradigms in biodiversity conservation such as strict nature protection, Integrated Conservation and Development Projects (ICDP), community-based conservation and conservation incentivization with the aid of landmark case studies. Themes such as science-policy linkages, sustainability, and equitability will be the over-arching framework for this course. Biodiversity and forestry laws and policies, as well as their implementaiton, in the Indian context will form an important part of the course.

The overall aim of this course is to use perspectives from a variety of disciplines: ecology, history, political science, economics and sociology, to help the students develop a holistic view of the causes and amelioratory strategies for today’s biodiversity crisis. The essential ingredients of scientific rigour, social equity and economic sustainability will be used to discuss solutions. The course will be largely held in seminar mode with students expected to read papers critically and discuss them in class. Each student will be expected to present and discuss at least 5 papers during the course of the semester. There will be upto 50 pages of reading each week as this is a seminar course.

One EVS course in ecology/conservation biology is a preferred prerequisite for this course (such as Ecology, Wildlife Conservation or Human-Wildlife Conflict). Students are encouraged to contact the instructor if they have questions regarding course prerequisites.

Learning Outcomes

The students will learn to critically integrate knowledge from different disciplinary areas to understand real-life biodiversity conservation in terms of design, implementation and outcomes. They will also learn to critique papers and debate various topics in class and be part of candid and informed discussions.

In the last three centuries, nationalism has proved a powerful ideology that has reshaped the political map of the world. As the nation-state became the norm, nationalism inspired both state-led nation-building and bottom-up mobilizations. Yet nationalism has also sparked xenophobic sentiments that lead to discriminatory attitudes and sometimes ethnic or inter-state conflict. This course seeks to make sense of nationalism as a positive source of political creativity and as a dangerous source of tension. data.name: Nation and State-Making in India's Borders
data.html_details:
Overview

Nation and State-Making in India’s Borders examines four key concepts - nation, state, violence, and development - in the context of India’s contested border regions. It is motivated by a set of perplexing observations about armed conflict in India. First, India’s response to civil wars (or insurgencies) involves both massive levels of violence to coerce communities into obedience, and extensive distribution of development funds to induce loyalty. Do these strategies complement or contradict each other? What is the long-term effect of these strategies?

Second, India has an impressive track record in defeating armed groups, but it struggles to resolve conflicts. Regions like Kashmir, Nagaland, and Manipur continue to remain affected by low levels of violence. Why?

Third, India’s governing institutions do not fritter away. Generally, we do not notice a complete breakdown of law and order that often leads to large-scale migration in other countries. Instead, civil administration remains robust and even expands during civil wars. How does India succeed in avoiding the World Bank’s conflict-trap hypothesis, wherein armed conflict depletes state’s capacity and creates conditions for future conflict?

Fourth, even as India limits fundamental rights (such as right to assembly, right to speech and opinion) through the Armed Forces Special Powers Act time and again, it is eager to resume electoral democracy. Why? Why not just continue with the President’s Rule? From Kashmir to Nagaland, elections in conflict zones register exceptionally high participation. Yet, contrary to the convention that voting is an indicator of legitimacy, surveys and ethnographies show that communities affected by conflict do not positively associate with Indian identity, or at the very least, their identification with Indian nationalism is tenuous. How do democratic institutions operate in conflict zones where political rights are limited by the threat of violence by both sides?

To understand these seemingly contradictory observations, one must look beyond the literature on civil war. The course, therefore, is a compliment to Militants or Freedom Fighters? Armed Conflicts in India (taught at Monsoon 2021) that examined civil wars in India through the lens of major works of civil wars. Nation and State-Making in India’s Borders will use canonical works of nationalism, state formation, organised violence, and the politics of development as pillars to guide our search for answers to these vexing questions. Equipped with the knowledge of theory, we will study detailed case studies and collectively discuss the most convincing explanations for patterns of nation and state-making in India’s contested borderlands.

data.name: Democratization and Foreign Aid
data.html_details:
Overview

The core concern of the course is to analyse the ways foreign aid might or might not work when it comes to democracy promotion. Since this concern links two concept groups, this course doubles as a stylized and brief introduction to the literature on foreign aid and democratization. In democratization (Part I), we will consider the type of foreign interventions, the drivers of democratization, the special role of elections and the varieties of authoritarianism. In Foreign aid (Part II), we will cover the types of foreign aid, the efficacy debate, the modalities of democracy aid, the incentive of aid donors and recipients and donor switching.

After the theoretical overview, we consider a practical approach to existing political constraints (Part III), as articulated in my book, Liberalization at the Margins. We skim the empirics and put more emphasis on the case studies of the aid-democratization dynamic for Egypt, Fiji, and Myanmar. We conclude by considering the policy implications of such strategies with an emphasis on the authoritarian backlash (and authoritarian strategies for international law.)

Learning Outcomes

Through the course, students should be able to 1) identify the major issues and debates in foreign aid, 2) analyse the costs and benefits of various modalities of democracy aid, and 3) consider the policy implications of democracy promotion. Students also have the opportunity, through the term essay, to specialize on the aid dynamics of a given country and understand why democracy promotion frequently fails. As a bonus, students get a sense of the background work that goes into the writing of a book, They may appreciate (or not!) that what you see the finished product – the book - is merely the tip iceberg. It is the part that is underwater and not immediately obvious where the real labor lies.

This is not a course on current events.

As Uttar Pradesh gears towards its 18th state election, this course will at the same time a deep dive into the political history of India’s political heartland, a study of a campaign in real time and an introduction to the art of electoral analysis. We will cover the history of party formation and of their electoral performance, the transformation of Uttar Pradesh’s party system, the successive phases of electoral politics that have shaped not only the politics of UP but of the country at large. We will also cover the sociology of parties, elected representatives and candidates and the transformations of electoral politics.

The course will contain a variety of assignments, including (among other things) maintaining a campaign journal, profiling marginal players and writing a book review.

data.name: The Listening Body: Fundamentals of Contemporary Theatre Practices
data.html_details:
Overview

Taught by Neel Chaudhuri, Anirudh Nair

This course explores a contemporary approach to actor training and the embodying and staging of text. The first part of the course focuses on body, mind, breath and voice as a single integrated whole and suggests a practice that prepares the actor’s instrument for the state of performance. Students will work towards removing blocks that we develop as a result of socialisation, in order to find freedom in the flow of impulse and actions in response to stimulus. In the second part, we apply and realise this practice in devising and staging scenes from selected contemporary texts. The teaching methodology includes theatre games and exercises, partner and ensemble work, including simple acrobatics, improvisations, movement structures and basic textual analysis to unpack scripts for performance.


The Listening Body draws on principles and approaches that are grounded in the work and lineage of artists and teachers, beginning with Konstantin Stanislavski and navigating through various global practices through the 20th century. It proposes a living and breathing practice that develops, challenges and reimagines these traditions in response to the culture and experience of practitioners in India today. The course encourages students to consider their own context and desire as performers and build from there.

Grading Rubric

The majority of the course work will take place in class. Hence, attendance and participation in class are the main criteria for grading.

Attendance Policy

Students can take up to 4 unexcused absences.

data.name: The Sensory Body: Desire, Permission, Transgression
data.html_details:
Overview

Taught by Navtej Singh Johar

This course will be equally devoted to theory and somatic practice. Revolving around the phenomenon of ambivalence, both the readings and practice will aim to look between-and-betwixt the possibilities and impossibilities of being and/or becoming insider/outsider, native/stranger, self/other. An examination of ideas pertaining to boundaries, permissions, desires, negotiations and transgressions, will be countered with an analysis and exploration of bodily appetites of touch, taste, gaze, voice, sound, shape, gesture and so on. In particular, the liminal condition of ambivalence will be studied in relation to the arbitrariness of categories and divisions that modernity imposes, and the absurd certitude of nationalism that it can foster. The underlying thrust of this course will be to explore the sensory body being as being the source and the means of clarity.

Grading Rubric
