data.name: Intermediate Sanskrit 2
data.html_details:
Overview

SAN 2002 is mainly a course to develop proficiency in reading and translating Sanskrit. We will cover any grammar topics left over from SAN 2001 and practice grammar worksheets to review topics learnt in previous semesters.

In this edition of SAN 2002 we will read selections from literature produced around the turn of the 13th century in the Sena kingdom in eastern India. We will read samples from different genres – standalone verses (muktaka) seen in anthologies, inscriptions, verse kāvya-s of Dhoyi and Govardhana and the singular Gītagovinda of Jayadeva.

Learning Outcomes

The Gītagovinda is a remarkable phono-aesthetic synthesis of poetry and song bending preexisting genre boundaries. The combination of song and verse in the Gītagovinda exemplify a highly polished poetic register. Deceptively simple, it is highly allusive and has inimitable diction. Reading this selection of texts from different genres will train us in analyzing verbal forms and compounds. We will read the texts closely, translating every single word.

data.name: Anthropology of Women and Work
data.html_details:
Overview

Note: While our effort will be hold face to face classes, the course may have to be partially online. Depending on the evolving situation we shall take a call closer to the start of the semester.
This is an undergraduate course to introduce students to three significant strands of scholarship in the Anthropology of Women and Work. Starting with the late 70s, an evolving gender studies focus offered pathbreaking approaches to women’s roles in production. The first strand will explore how women’s productive activities complement those of men in the simplest societies. We shall examine some issues raised in gender-based enquiries within the vast anthropological literature that emerged to understand women’s labor and production in simple or pre-class societies.
,
A second strand concerns the Indian agricultural context. Here we analyze notions about the peasant household, as well as women’s contribution to agrarian production. The course will examine the implications of imagining the cultivator as predominantly male, which led to the invisibility of women’s contributions to agriculture. The effects of this bias will be explored along with reflections on the research that emerged to address it.

A specific focus of the section on India will be to explore the links between agrarian production and cultural production.

The course concludes with issues raised in recent documentaries about women’s labor in the global fashion industry.

Reading selections are made with a view to generating active class discussion and introduce students to ongoing debates in the field. For example, through selected pages from Chakrabarty’s‘Provincializing Europe’, the class will be first introduced to significant issues and themes in the exploration of the Anthropology of Women and Work. The book’s broad historical sweep offers a stimulating entry point to ask questions about labor, peasantry, distinctions between public and private; social institutions from which women were excluded; women’s repetitive tasks such as grinding and associated narratives, and the concerns of social reformers – themes to emerge as the weeks unfold. If in the Introductory week our effort is to think of women’s work not as an abstraction but deeply rooted in concrete realities, the second week asks how the recent pandemic has forced us to think of other compelling issues about labor - migration and women’s visibility or invisibility in these processes. Questions raised by Chakrabarty’s and Agnihotri’s texts anticipate themes we shall explore over the remaining weeks.

data.name: The Anthropology of Humour
data.html_details:
Overview

In this course, we will both study the fool and play the fool.

These pandemic years have been difficult indeed. As we continue to grapple with the pandemic, in this class we will shift our focus to humour, through a deep exploration of what it is, why we have it, and how we do it.

What is funny and why? What work does humour do in human societies? Do other-than-human species make jokes? What is the relationship between comedy and power? These are some of the questions we will explore, through focusing in particular on the burgeoning and shifting scene of humour in the societies we live in. We will analyze and think with WhatsApp forwards and memes, stand-up comics and reels, and the jokes that we make, hear, and critique around us everyday. Our readings will include Beatrice Otto's Fools are Everywhere: The Court Jester Around the World; Sigmund Freud's Jokes and their Relation to the Unconscious; and Humour and the Performance of Power in South Asia, edited by Sasanka Perera and Dev Nath Pathak, among others.

data.name: Caste and Gender
data.html_details:
Overview

Note: While our effort will be hold face to face classes, the course may have to be partially online. Depending on the evolving situation we shall take a call closer to the start of the semester.

This course will introduce students to influential thinkers who have grappled with the inter-relationship between caste and gender. Each unit will offer a new way to understand this intertwining. Beginning with texts influential in bringing together understandings about caste and gender, the course is divided into 6 units: Approaches to Gender and Caste; Upper Caste Patriarchies and Cultural Models; Marriage Transactions; Dalit Identity; Gender Violence; Agrarian Production and Cultural Production.

B.R. Ambedkar’s essay on caste endogamy sets the tone, followed by a 1990 foundational text on gender by Partha Chatterjee, and Anupama Rao’s Introduction to an edited volume on Caste and Gender. From an analysis of upper caste models and patriarchies that inaugurated studies on the intertwining of gender and caste, the course takes up the concerns of recent scholarship on Dalits. A unique feature of the course is its attempt to integrate people’s voices, songs and biographies, as forms of cultural production. Five of the six units in the course offer at least one such example for deeper engagement with people’s own texts/narratives. While these come to us as reflective pieces analyzed by commentators, students may collectively explore other possible meanings. The aim is for the classroom to emerge as a space to elicit meanings from material with which anthropologists construct texts. Over the semester, students learn about caste and gender as empirically grounded phenomena, as well as analytical tools that illuminate our reality.

data.name: Torture and Anthropology
data.html_details:
Overview

Torture and Anthropology

If we are to make the study of torture meaningful, we must at the outset recognize that the complexity and diversity of this term is best grasped in its historical and ethnographic specificity. While the reading of torture is classified in multiple discursive regimes – judicial and punitive accounts, interrogational manuals, biographical and autobiographical details, online videos of lynching, to name a few – this course aims to situate torture in its relation to the social. In the process, we will read about how torture establishes bonds of solidarity as much as it breaks forms of sociality. Beginning with how torture, pain, and suffering (or what Max Weber calls the problem of theodicy) are linked, we will move to a discussion of torture as a ritual of initiation, where the mark of violence on the body is a pedagogy of affirmation and non-dialogue. Subsequently, the course will examine case studies of torturers and the problem of witnessing and remembrance. We will then locate the practice of torture within institutional contexts, such as the prison and rendition and concentration camps, showing the difficult relationship that torture establishes with state sovereignty. The course will close with reflections on the relation of torture to life and death.

Students will be evaluated by a mid-term (40%) and end-term (40%) paper. In addition, there will be weekly prompts (20%) of no more than a page to be written in class time.

Learning Outcomes

An understanding of how torture makes and unmakes the world

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

data.name: Theorising the Contemporary: Words and Worldings
data.html_details:
Overview

It matters what stories we tell to tell other stories with; it matters what knots knot knots, what thoughts think thoughts, what descriptions describe descriptions, what ties tie ties.(Haraway, 2016)

If ‘worlding’ refers to the summoning of new ways of being of in the present, words pluralize any singular worlding from a comparative perspective. Reformulations of the anthropocene such as the chuthulucene, plantationocene, capitalocene, Shivacene, and many more speak from particular time and space. Adjacent concepts modify the universe with the pluriverse and the multiverse, politics with cosmopolitics or juxtapose the globe and the planet. To give another example, the human is amended by the non-human, the post-human, the inhuman, the unhuman as well as with other-than-human persons through practices that seek to express the divergent. And beyond such worldings, the present ecological crisis casts the decimation of the indigenes in the Americas as the first extinction where the ‘end of the world’ has already happened - an invitation to think the future through non-western-centric constructions and revised genealogies.

The focus of the course will be to analyse the significance of contemporary concepts so as to learn how to evaluate and sculpt concepts that reflect difference.

We will draw on a selection of worldings from Donna Haraway, Isabelle Stengers, Dipesh Chakrabarty, Bruno Latour, Viveiros de Castro , Marilyn Strathern, Philippe Descola, Eduardo Kohn and Michel Foucault and will attempt to orient the readings to students’ research interests.

data.name: Economy, Ecology and Infrastructure: An Ethnographic Approach
data.html_details:
Overview

In the age of the Anthropocene, it is unsurprising that Anthropology has begun to focus on the more-than-human. This exploration of the links between different humans, other species, material artifacts, and the biophysical world has unsettled our understanding of subjectivity and agency, scales of analysis and disciplinary boundaries. It has also made us question what constitutes anthropological knowledge and how it is produced.

This course aims to examine these issues at the intersection of political ecology, science and technology studies, and environmental anthropology by studying recent notable works that offer conceptually rigorous and empirically grounded analyses. We will carefully read the work of Anna Tsing, Anand Pandian, Tania M. Li, Nikhil Anand, Rashmi Sadana, Annu Jalais, Shaila S. Galvin to study the craft of Anthropology, attending not only to discursive contexts and arguments but how they are situated through fieldwork and expressed through writing practices.

The course will be conducted as a weekly three-hour seminar.

Learning Outcomes

This reading intensive seminar aims to develop a critical appreciation of scholarship in the overlapping fields described above. Its objective is to equip PhD students in Sociology-Anthropology and related fields with concepts and methods for thinking through their research projects.

data.name: Quantum Field Theory 1: Introduction and Foundations
data.html_details:
Overview

This course will introduce a number of important concepts and foundational topics in the relativistic quantum theory of fields. The focus will be on the hamiltonian formulation of QFT, spin 0 (scalar) and spin 1/2 (spinor) fields, and on simple tree-level processes for the most part.

Brief Course Outline

Quantum Mechanics + Special relativity, the need for many particles, antiparticles and quantum fields.

Fock Space, many particle QM, the quantum field as coupled harmonic oscillators.

Relativistic causality, cluster decomposition and locality, mode expansions.

Classical Field Theory: Lagrangians, Hamiltonians and equation of motion, Noether’s theorem, Symmetries (spacetime and internal), conserved currents, energy-momentum tensor, Canonical Quantisation.

Perturbation theory and Scattering: Schrodinger, Heisenberg and Dirac pictures, Dyson formula and Lorentz invariant S - matrix, Wick contractions and normal ordering, simple tree level processes in the canonical operator formulation.

Green’s functions, Propagators, LSZ and KL representation, Feynman rules.

QFT in curved spacetime - a primer.

Spinorial representations of the Lorentz Group. Weyl Spinors and Weyl equation. Dirac equation and plane wave solutions, quantisation of the Dirac field, anti-commutation relations, Majorana fermions. Propagator and Feynman diagrams and Feynman rules.

Basic Quantum Electrodynamics (Feynman rules and amplitudes for simple tree level processes).

* Spin-statistics and CPT theorem.

* UIRs of the Poincare group.

* Path Integrals in QM and QFT.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

For a good part of the course we will (try to) follow the excellent recently published book:

“Quantum Field Theory Lectures of Sidney Coleman” (World Scientific)

This will be the primary reference. Lecture notes from the course are available also on arXiv:

https://arxiv.org/abs/1110.5013

The 1975 Harvard lectures of Sidney Coleman are available to watch here:

https://www.physics.harvard.edu/events/videos/Phys253

One more important reference will be:

“Introduction to Quantum Field Theory” by M. Peskin and D. Schroder [Chapters 1-4]

Another classic is

“The Quantum Theory of Fields” by Steven Weinberg [C.U.P , 3 volumes, Chapters 1-7 of Vol. 1 are especially recommended as they explain and develop systematically important conceptual aspects of QFT and motivate its structure]

A very incomplete list of good introductory textbooks - with varying perspectives, different choice and order of topics, and distinct pedagogical styles - which may also be useful for particular topics, is the following:

"Quantum Field Theory and the Standard Model” (M. Schwartz)

“Quantum Field Theory” (M. Srednicki)

"Quantum Field Theory in a Nutshell” (A. Zee)

Credit: Exams (60%) + Viva (20%)+ Project (20%)

Audit: Exams (75%) + Viva (25%) (a 65% overall mark is required for a successful audit)

data.name: Computational Modelling of Behaviour
data.html_details:
Overview

This course will provide an overview of how computational models are employed in the study of
human behavior. Computational modeling is a key methodology in psychology, cognitive
science and cognitive neuroscience, and often provides mechanistic insight into psychological
phenomena. In this course, students will be introduced to a variety of models of perception,
memory, learning and decision-making and will explore examples of how these models were
employed to gain insights into psychological and neural processes. In addition, they will delve
into a few models in detail to gain hands-on experience with computational modeling.

Each week will follow the same structure. There will be two classes. The first class will be a
lecture + discussion class where we will go over content. The second class will either be a
seminar-style class, where a student/group will present the assigned reading (a research paper
that all attendees are expected to read, or a tutorial/practical, where we will be implementing
models in MATLAB.

data.html_details:
Overview

Is Shakespeare queer? Debate has raged for centuries about whether or not Shakespeare was gay, but that is pointedly not the question this class will ask. Instead, we will grapple with a double-headed monster that asks both: how does Shakespeare allow us to theorise queerness, and how does queer theory engage Shakespeare? We will read, among other texts, the Sonnets, as well as plays like Romeo and Juliet, Richard II, and Othello, queer theory texts by Lee Edelman, Valerie Traub, Jonathan Goldberg, Eve Kosofsky Sedgwick, and Judith Butler, and adaptations like Omkara and Ram-Leela. With every text we will think through the assumptions on which queer theory builds its arguments, and inquire into the extent to which Shakespeare might perhaps more fascinatingly be encountered as Shakesqueer.

Overview

Title of the course: Comics For Social Media

(Offered in Spring Semester, 2021-22)

Level: 1000, 2000

Instructor: Orijit Sen

Prerequisites:

Research and writing skills, basic drawing, photography and social media skills.

Course Description:

The rapid and almost universal spread of internet in the past two decades has generated a large number of interactive online platforms and social media spaces. These offer novel and complex media and means for comics artists/producers to connect with their readerships. In terms of both capabilities and reach, online comics offer powerful new ways of not just communicating but also of forming communities. It is no longer a one way or even two street. What we have now are intricately interconnected networks.

In this context, political and social ideologies and identities have become powerful currencies of dialogue and exchange. In our modern media environment characterised by participatory media culture, comics, graphics and memes are tools for citizens seeking to participate actively and discursively in a digital public sphere. There has been much debate on the polarising nature of social media exchanges, the propagation of fake news and trolling and toxicity in general. What are the ways to negotiate these aspects and tap into and channelise the positive currents of sharing and learning that are also intrinsic to the social media space? What role can/ does art and creativity play in this process?

As predicted by comics theorist Scott McCloud and others, the medium of comics has gained a new, different and expanded life in the digital age, while continuing its innovative development in the traditional domain of print. This course will look at the challenges posed by the burgeoning new form of digital comics and consider the co-dependencies of print and digital media in the comics world. The hitherto unprecedented role offered to creators and audiences alike - through the ability to shape the course of the creative exchange via likes, comments, shares and mimetic variations will also be explored.

Course Modules:

The initial module of the course will focus on research, discussion and analysis of the work of academics such as McCloud as well as popular social media accounts sampled from varied geographical locations, interest groups and communities.

The main module will be a live project on social media. The class group will launch a social media page and attempt to create a profile that invites dialogue and engagement from the public through the medium of online comics. The profile will be updated on a daily basis with contributions and posts that emerge - collaboratively as well as individually - from classroom discussions and explorations.

Course Deliverables:

Each student will be expected to develop and deliver 10 graphic/audio/video short comics

Learning Objectives:

Students will learn to engage with and analyse the renewed relationship between graphics, text, animations and sound, and interpret how meaning is produced in the process. They will develop a greater fluency in creating digital comics series, memes, cartoon strips and other forms of visual media communication and be able to convey more relevant and impactful messages.

data.name: Fuzzy Cartographies
data.html_details:
Overview

While our position in space is an objective fact determined by geographic coordinates, our understanding of a place is fundamentally subjective. The same space can have radically different meanings depending on the observer. This course explores this tension through the theory and practice of Qualitative GIS: an area of cartography that tries to map our experience of place. Using visualizations, maps, and other digital media, we will experiment with different ways of capturing the "placeness" of space in fiction, history, and narrative texts more generally. Along the way you will become conversant with Geographic Information Systems, such as QGIS, and will also learn some of the basics of web mapping with MapBox. No prior knowledge of computer programming is required, but you are asked to keep an open mind about learning some basic HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, and maybe some Python. Due to the collaborative nature of the Digital Humanities, most projects will involve group work.

Learning Outcomes

Coverage:

Students will learn how to interpret narrative data and map it spatially. As the definitions for doing this type of work are still being created, there are no options for cookie cutter methods, instead students will need to think critically about how best to represent the data.

Basic Computer Logic:

Although DH relies on technologists who do the more sophisticated coding, it is necessary for practitioners to have a basic understanding of computer logic and programming. We will cover entry-level computer programming for GIS using Python and JavaScript for MapBox.

Professionalization:

You will be asked to produce a public-facing web map.

Collaboration:

The digital humanities are an inherently collaborative enterprise. Barring a few assignments pretty much everything will require collaboration. This means that you should respect other team members’ opinions and their time. Everyone should work together fairly. Though I will not directly manage groups, you will be given opportunities to provide feedback on the collaborative process. If the group dynamic does not appear to be working, I will intervene.

No Objective Whatsoever:

In a famous essay, Stephen Ramsay describes what he calls, “The Hermeneutics of Screwing Around.” Much of the work done by Digital Humanists means taking the data and displaying it multiple ways until it reveals something interesting. This is possible because, unlike the social and physical sciences, literary scholars are not trying to test a hypothesis, but rather are trying to (re)describe a literary text in a new way. You are encouraged to “screw around” with the data you gather even if it does not lead to a concrete conclusion.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

There are no formal requirements for this course, though students who have taken Introduction to Digital Humanities will have a distinct advantage. For students who have not done so, they can consult supplemental materials on GitHub, QGIS, and Relational Databases. Revised Dec. 25th, 2021

This course will be cross-listed with the CS department. At the moment, some students are experiencing a registration block. If you are not able to register, please contact johannes.burgers@ashoka.edu.in to indicate your interest. Also, CC the TA Sonal Rana (sonal.rana_ma23@ashoka.edu.in) on the email. Generally, English majors, upper-level CS majors, and students who have taken Introduction to DH will be able to register. All other students will need to be interviewed.

Note: CS Majors will need to do a separate assignment to have this meet the requirements for the CS department.

Grading Rubric

Project 3: Web Mapping Partition 35%

Attendance Policy

Overview

Writing about watching a film as a film critic MS 2451 Course Cap: 20 Tuesday & Thursday 10:10 – 11.40 am Media Studies Stream: Film/ Content Production

Course Professor Tisha Srivastav Course TA devanshi.daga_asp22@ashoka.edu.in

COURSE OVERVIEW: This course will teach you how to write film reviews in the media. It will do so by delving into media writing on film.
One, the popular culture focus of the film reviews of American film critic Pauline Kael. Secondly, the critical writings in the earliest and more recent issues of the British Film Institute magazine, Sight & Sound. The course will also provide fundamental clues into ways of watching potent moving images and understanding cinema as a medium of entertainment, communication and representation of ‘reality’.

Kael has written on films from a newspaper and magazine film reviewer’s perspective over a century of American cinema, from the birth of popular film genre, right up until near the end of the 20th century. The act of movie going, how ordinary film goers are in the movie hall and talk to each other after watching a film? How an appreciation of the wider world of literature, painting, theatre, music and observed behavior, informs her reviews and through them, her readers. We will discuss how her work interacts thoughtfully with popular culture.

Sight & Sound, on the other hand emerges from brochure/government report beginnings in Great Britain in the 1930s, to offering a critical eye on cinema, as a magazine in 2022. Focusing on how thought evolves on reviewing film, the readings from the magazine articles will be on writing in the media with a critic’s lens. What is cinema? This classic question posed by early film theory will guide our survey of theoretical approaches to the study of film from its beginnings in the 1910s to the present. We will study major film theories such as the realist film theory, formalist film theory, auteur theory, feminist film theory, apparatus theory, semiotics and psychoanalytic film theory but also turn to film-philosophical approaches to cinema. We will discuss the major film theories in relation to different film genres, film movements and national cinemas. Film theorists studied will include Hugo Munsterberg, Béla Balázs, Walter Benjamin, Rudolph Arnheim, Sergei Eisenstein, Siegfried Kracauer, Andre Bazin, Jean-Louis Baudry, Christian Metz, Laura Mulvey and Gilles Deleuze. data.name: Medieval Travellers
data.html_details:
Overview

We often think of the Middle Ages as a time when people (and ideas) were stagnant. And yet people did travel, more slowly perhaps than we do now but with curiosity and enthusiasm. In fact, the Middle Ages is full of travelers: pilgrims en route to Jerusalem, knights returning from battle, and merchants journeying to urban markets. People, languages, texts and ideas migrated. Some travelers returned to share their impressions with others in geographical treatises, crusade narratives, and pilgrim handbooks. Other writers stayed home but imagined voyages in romance tales or dream visions. In all these cases, travel, real or imagined, facilitated exchanges between cultures that had profound impacts on notions of self and community.

In this seminar, we will investigate how travel, as an act and an idea, courses through medieval literature from around the globe. The seminar is organized around different types of travel—wandering, crusade, pilgrimage, exploration, and dream vision. Reading authors such as Xuanzang, Geoffrey Chaucer, Ibn Battuta, and John Mandeville through the lens of mobility studies—the critical study of the movement of people, goods and ideas—we will ask historically-situated questions with transhistorical relevance. What defines travel writing and what generic boundaries do these writings transgress? How do narratives of travel construct self and community in the medieval past and today? How does writing about travel establish and/or complicate authorial subjectivity? How might travel at once destabilize and/or reinforce notions of the center? Is there something ‘medieval’ about medieval travel?

Learning Outcomes

In this course you will

  • develop an understanding of the purposes and uses of medieval English travel writing;
  • become familiar with key genres in medieval literature such as hagiography, chanson de geste, and dream vision;
  • develop literary analysis skills through close-reading;
  • gain an understanding of how medieval English literature is historically situated while also not over-determined by its historical moment;
  • engage in independent learning through a research-based digital assignment that requires the use of primary and secondary sources;
  • hone academic writing skills through bi-weekly blog posts and two literary analysis papers
Grading Rubric

A full list of assignments will be given on the first day of class. These will include an in-class presentation and a final research paper of 15-18 pages.

Attendance Policy

Students may miss up 3 classes without any penalty to their course participation grade.

data.html_details:
Overview

Literary study in the 21st century has been riven by debates about the practice of reading. Is distant reading likely to dethrone the dominant method of close reading? Will deep reading lose its primacy to new methods of surface reading? Has critique become synonymous with the hermeneutics of suspicion? Is it possible to enact affirmation in an act of critique? We plan to bring these questions to the amorphous archive of world literature in English as shaped by British colonialism and Anglo-American globalization. Beginning with James Joyce’s Ulysses and concluding with Arvind Krishna Mehrotra’s 2020 Book of Indian Essays, we’ll study the elusive symbol of world literature through some of the most urgent questions about reading, history, context, reason, and modernity.

data.name: Is There A Modern Indian Literature?
data.html_details:
Overview

For ‘Is There a Modern Indian Literature?’, I will use the Picador Book of Modern Indian
Literature and a few other texts, and some cinema and music. I also plan to bring in some material
from outside India – the stories of Junichiro Tanizaki, for instance. The question in the course
title is one I asked myself as I began putting together the anthology I mention above in the late
1990s. How was one to conceive of a tradition called 'Indian literature'? Was it the total of thevarious literatures of India? Or was there another way of exploring this category? It was a time
when the Indian novel in English and the idea of 'postcolonial literature' had begun to dominate.
How did the modernist and avant garde trajectories of literatures in the Indian languages fit into
these relatively recent categorisations? One of my own reasons for rethinking and enlarging the
frame had to do with my affinities with modernism as a reader and writer, affinities that seemed
out of place post-Midnight's Children, but not so out of place within the experimental histories of
modern Indian literatures themselves. The use of the word 'modern' was, and is, deliberate, to
point to developments that the term 'postcolonial' doesn't address. The texts we'll read here
would follow, without too much narrow systematising, ‘Indian literature’ and the way its
emergence from the late nineteenth century in various languages embodied the trajectory of
modernity, modernism, the avant garde, and formal preoccupations in India. The course means
to question the largely theme-driven, Anglophone parameters of the ‘postcolonial’ that have
been with us for some decades now.

Learning Outcomes

Students from Oxford and other universities will be sitting in on the class, and will participate in discussions. However, only Ashoka students will be writing essays, for which they'll be graded.

Grading Rubric

data.name: Transnational Transgender
data.html_details:
Overview

Translating the transitions that trans* theory asks us to make, this class will think about trans* theory transnationally. For too long considered the outcome of Western liberalism, trans* theory and narratives in fact exist in several shapes around the world. Whether it is the Sufi mehfil of erotic transcendence, the Indic landscape of hijras, or the Thai ecosystem of lady-boys, trans* theory has a rich life scattered across cultural and sexual geographies. We will transition across some of this terrain over the course of the semester as we are transported by texts from Iran (Afsaneh Najmabadi), India (Serena Nanda, Gayatri Reddy, Bullhe Shah), Taiwan (Qiu Miaojin), and France (Paul Preciado), among others. All along these travels, we will be guided by the etymological sense of "trans" as something that moves beyond what we think we know and how we like to think.

Grading Rubric

A-F

data.name: Performance/Politics
data.html_details:
Overview

Collective life articulates power. On the one hand, forms of assembly and presence always enact power through ritual, action, prescribed norms of self-presentation, and established codes of social interaction. These same forms of collectivity, on the other hand, also hold potential to perform a rhetoric of resistance or, at the very least, hold out a promise of transformation. If performance is understood in its broadest sense as embodied presence going beyond aesthetic forms to include all kinds of social behaviour, then we will see that performance and power are inextricably intertwined and mutually constitutive. This course investigates the relationship between performance and politics that lies at the heart of modernity. We will focus on the politics of performance, and equally, on the performance of politics.

Our investigation will lead us to view some recurring concerns of modern social theory from a performance perspective: concepts such as community, the public sphere and counterpublics, discipline, action, assembly, and affect as well as identities such as gender, race, and caste. We will organize our analysis of performance/ politics around four themes: structures, processes, selves, and identities. First, we will explore the ways in which thinking with performance in its broadest sense—as shared live experience—can help us understand social relationships and political structures. Second, we will examine how performance—and often, performance alone—makes possible certain political processes. Third, we will trace the fraught political relationships between individual and collective selves. Finally, we will analyze the politically charged articulation of social identities. Course material may include films on music and sport, along with writing by BR Ambedkar, Hannah Arendt, Begoña Aretxaga, Judith Butler, Uma Chakravarti, Emile Durkheim, Diana Taylor, Victor Turner, Byung-Chul Han, Jurgen Habermas, Nancy Fraser, Arlie Hochschild, Stuart Hall, Teresa Caldeira, Ann Cvetkovich, Erving Goffman, Ngugi wa Thiong’o, and Jisha Menon.

Overview

The course will concentrate on Indian Philosophy during its 'middle period': from the 5th century to the 12th century. There are two reasons why this is known as the 'Golden Age' of Indian Philosophy. (1) By this time the ideas and arguments had attained a sophistication that was not there in the earlier period; and (2) Buddhism, a crucial ingredient in the philosophical mix, providing an impetus for the non-Buddhist systems to evolve in order to address its powerful critiques, still flourished, prior to its disappearance from India in the 12th century.

We will focus on the following topics: logic, theism versus atheism, momentariness versus persistence, idealism versus realism, and the mind-body problem. We include some recent developments in the study of these topics.

data.name: History of Early Analytic Philosophy
data.html_details:
Overview

This course will introduce students to the analytic tradition in philosophy. It will provide an overview of the origins, motivations and ambitions of early analytic philosophy. We will cover three aspects of the history of analytic philosophy: (1) its initial founding phase, as inaugurated in the early seminal writings of Gottlob Frege and Bertrand Russell, as well as Ludwig Wittgenstein's Tractatus; (2) the inheritance and reshaping of some of the central ideas of the founders of analytic philosophy by logical positivists like A.J. Ayer and Rudolf Carnap (3) Criticisms and developments of (1) and (2) by thinkers like the later Wittgenstein, Quine and Kripke.

In this course we will study questions like the following.

  • How is mathematical knowledge possible?
  • What is the relationship between math and logic? (Are mathematical truths really all just logical truths?)
  • Are most traditional philosophical claims and questions nonsense? Can we come up with a criterion that demarcates meaningful terms from nonsense?
  • Can using contemporary logic to analyze language help us more clearly state and/or solve metaphysical questions?
  • Is all knowledge either analytic (roughly, something trivial we know by logic and definitions alone) or empirical?
  • What does understanding a language (or the meaning of a word) consist in?

Media Studies Stream: Content Production/ Craft of storytelling

OVERVIEW: A broad sampler into storytelling skills through data, climate fiction writing and science. This course is on ways of storytelling and unrelated to journalism. Although useful for students who want to understand how to tell the story hiding inside the data or in their imagination.

In month 1 of the course, professional data visualizer Nithya Subramanian takes students through an introduction to climate change data, analyzing datasets, experimenting with different forms of data representation using design thinking methods. Storytelling with data: What are we trying to say, whom are we saying it to, and how all can we say it? There will also be an introduction to semiotics in data storytelling and overview of careers in data and visual storytelling. At the end of month one, each student would have created a portfolio-worthy visual storytelling project on communicating climate change.

Nithya Subramanian is an information designer and illustrator, and runs the data graphics studio PoppadomCo. Between 2019-2020 she was the visual editor of Scroll.in. She has also worked in policy and education, and is visiting faculty at NID Kurukshetra and SPA Bhopal. She has degrees in Engineering Physics and New Media Design.

Week 6-11 of the course, students take a deep dive into Climate Fiction with Professor Tisha Srivastav, in the realm of popular culture in the English language. This includes reading Indian story books for early, middle level readers and Young Adult fiction in text. This may include a web series on the subject. Elements of storytelling will be taught and students will produce a 2000 word fiction story around the theme of environmental consciousness and/ or climate change.

For likely two weeks at the end of this course, Professor Iain Stewart, who teaches at Ashoka’s Natural Sciences Department as Visiting Faculty, will take workshops on Science Communication. Connecting science to everyday life and popular mainstream storytelling.

data.name: Environment and Social Exclusion
data.html_details:
Overview

This elective course focusses on questions of social exclusion and social justice in environment, with a particular emphasis on race, caste and class. The concept of social exclusion as an analytical framework has become increasingly relevant for an understanding of the notions of environmental inequality, conflicts, rights and justice. The course will capture the social exclusion structures and processes which restrict the access of certain social groups to environmental resources and entitlements. It will explain the different forms of social disadvantage – in village and community, in land and water, in space and commons, in wilderness and conservation – that persist, in multiple variants and with different intensity, across societies and nations. It will locate the agency to groups that either guard their domain of privilege or challenge the system of social inequalities and segmentation. Thus, understanding social exclusion as a condition/outcome as well as a dynamic process, the course will also examine some environmental justice movements. The course will also be contextually and temporally embedded. In the north, for example, along with African-Americans, Latino and indigenous people, the focus has been the changing nature of social exclusion in environment. Accordingly, the relevant focus groups are the new social groups, including the immigrants and ethnic groups. By contrast, in the Indian context, the problem is one of the persistent, multiple exclusion of certain social groups like Dalit affecting their basic environmental access and rights.

Learning Outcomes

The course is organized around weekly lectures and discussions based on the readings. Students will be asked to write an essay on one of the topics of the course, with footnotes and bibliography, and further readings will be given to them on their chosen topic, so that they can go in much more depth on a particular topic.

data.name: Women on the Move: Gendered Travel in the Indian Ocean
data.html_details:
Overview

Did women travel in the premodern world? If yes, why there is hardly any accounts written by or on women? We have read and heard a lot about all the great travellers of the ancient and medieval times: Faxian, Marco Polo, Ibn Battuta, Ma Huan, Benjamin of Tudela, Niccolao Manucci… the list goes on but all men!

This does not mean that women did not travel at all. They did undertake long journeys across long distances, between Asia, Europe, Africa and the Americas. Along the way, many of them disguised as men to protect themselves. Many travelled as pirates, some became queens, mystics, prophetesses and saints. Others were traders, sailors, admirals or pilgrims. Even many more were captured and taken across continents (for e.g., from India and Mozambique to Mexico and the Caribbean), and were forced to slavery and concubinage.

In this course, we explore such untold peregrinations of women between ca. 800 and 1800 CE with a focus on India and the Indian Ocean world. We shall read primary sources together in various languages to unearth the arduous journeys of those premodern women outside their comfort zones.

This is a reading seminar: we will read excerpts from primary sources in each class (2-3 pages per week). In addition, you need to read 10-15 pages for each class and write a short note of 500 words each week.

Learning Outcomes

On the successful completion of this course, you will be able to

• Comprehend some of the major issues and debates on women travelers, the premodern world, and the Indian Ocean world.
• Approach social and cultural processes in any community in a global, oceanic and long-term perspective, and to take gender as a crucial analytical category in exploring history.
• Develop the advanced skills of reading primary sources critically, especially for research and writing.
• Familiarise yourself with conceiving, writing, and presenting a research paper.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This course is a reading seminar: reading and discussions are the central characteristics of this course, there will not be any lecturing. We will read excerpts from primary sources in each class (2-3 pages per week). In addition, you need to read about 10-15 pages for each class and write a short note of 500 words each week (from the 3rd week onward).

It is designed for final year undergraduates, ASP students, and Ph.D. students. Ideally, you should have successfully completed at least your first year of undergraduate studies.

No prior knowledge of History is required.

data.name: Stone, Paper, Bamboo, Silk: Sinophone Textual Cultures
data.html_details:
Overview

Today, when so much of our daily communication occurs via text or email, it can be difficult to imagine a world in which writing was the preserve of a tiny minority. Chinese characters are frequently cited as the oldest continuous written tradition, beginning over three thousand years ago, but in that time the physical form of the characters and the materials they were written on have transformed over and over again. We will consider what questions these problems raise for historians' use of textual sources by looking at writing as a social, material, and political act. What were the symbolic meanings attributed to writings that most people could not understand? What practical uses could writing serve? How did access to writing intersect with other social hierarchies, like gender and class? Beginning with the invention of writing in the Yellow River region, we will discuss problems such as: the relationship between speech and writing; changes in writing materials; writing for display and writing for use; censorship; Chinese characters in non-Chinese societies; and debates over script reform.

data.name: Chinese Pasts: “Ancient China” Through Contemporary Eyes
data.html_details:
Overview

In November 2021, the 6th plenum of the 19th Chinese Communist Party Congress adopted only the third ‘Historical Resolution’ since the CCP’s founding, and the first since 1981. While the focus of these resolutions is on defining the party’s role in Chinese history since 1921, they also locate the CCP within a longue durée history of the Chinese state. These resolutions point to the significance of China’s pre-modern history as a source of ideas and narratives about China’s present and future.

Over the last four decades, Chinese journalists, academics, and other public intellectuals have energetically debated what direction China should take after the end of Cultural Revolution. In this class, we will explore the contours of these debates through a focus on history. In addition to key concepts and figures in intellectual history, we will discuss the role of the state in shaping and restricting the scope of debate at particular times. Finally, we will extend our analysis into the ways that ideas about China’s history play out ‘in practice’ – practices of memorialisation and display, fictionalisation and entertainment.

data.name: History of Modern China: Empire and its Aftermath
Borderlands: Towards a Spatial History of Empire
A Cultural Reading of India and China: Connections and Networks
data.html_details:
Overview

In this course we will conduct a comparative cultural and literary study by focusing on the resemblances and contactual relationships and typological affinities within two ancient civilizations, India and China. The complex method of cultural confluence between India and China was initially a spontaneous contact that happened primarily as a result of an intellectual quest by the Buddhist monks. This literary-historical comparative study reveals the spontaneous interliterary contacts between these two civilizations. The Indian literary and philosophical values contributed to the formation and the development of the new trends of the strange tales in the recipient literature. This exchange between India and China is important because Chinese literature is enriched by Indian literature not only as a consequence of direct contacts but also because of the inner potentialities of the emitting Indian phenomenon and this happened in spite of the existence of China’s own strong and powerful cultural heritage. The interliterary reciprocity of these two countries formed a concrete literary and cultural relation and the impact of the source culture was almost undistinguishable and had a creative manifestation in the recipient narrative tradition. The creative manifestation of the narrative tradition due to this direct impact from the source culture was only possible for the recipient culture of China because it already had its own strong and written literary tradition. This course will conduct the thematic comparative study of the strange tales of China and India and its migration to Afroeurasian region. This study will execute a systematic analysis with reference to the cultural, aesthetic and intellectual situation while looking into the lapses and the surviving and the residual elements.

The Unit –I touches upon the advent of Buddhism and the transmission of the Buddhist elements via the translation of the miraculous indigenous strange tale tradition to which Buddhism contributed immensely. A short introduction to the bianwen genre which is considered to be a direct descendent of the Indian gatha tradition will be introduced. Following the Confucian ideology which emphasise greatly on the documentation of history, the narratives that included supernatural elements were documented as a history of the other world. Buddhism, Confucianism and Daoism together had contributed to the growth of the strange tale tradition in China.

Unit 2 will examine the emergence of China as a Buddhist realm and the phase of termination and also discuss the Tang-India diplomatic relations during premodern time. With this advent of Buddhism the translation of Buddhist literatures escalated. The course will discuss the problems and prospects of the early Chinese translations which helped in the linguistic development and evolution. Unit 3 will discuss the spread of Buddhism across and beyond Asia. Buddhism in China has immensely contributed to the evolution of narrative traditions in China. This unit will illustrate the Indic philosophical concepts and estimate its influence on different narrative genres through the readings of folktales and strange stories. The connection between the historicity and fictionality of the narratives can be understood through the readings of different genres of literatures. Unit 4 will examine four motifs/themes that are essentially Buddhist and the course can study their reception and acclimatization within the Chinese strange tale tradition. Parallely the course will examine the evolution of similar motifs in the Indian Sanskrit tradition. The purpose of the course also is to draw a pattern expressed through thematic resemblances of the strange and the fantastic stories of the medieval Indian and Chinese literary traditions. With this parallel study it can also be established that after traveling to China, Buddhist philosophy influenced indigenous Chinese folk and popular story tradition and the idea of Buddhism eventually got merged with Daoism and indigenous story tradition.

Learning Outcomes

1. The students will learn about the early and premodern India China historical and literary connections

2. They will know about different genres of literature and historical writings and will understand the methodology of looking into the different knowledge systems each culture provides.

3. They will learn to understand historical connections and networks through the readings of chinese and Sanskrit stories in translation

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This is a multidisciplinary course. The students should be interested to read and learn various kinds of reading materials including historical connections, philosophical and literary concepts, fiction and poetry.

data.name: Apparitions of Macbeth
data.html_details:
Overview

ENG-4203-1 Apparitions of Macbeth Jonathan Gil Harris (GIS, PS)

MW 10:10-11:40

Macbeth stands unsurpassed among Shakespeare’s works for its capacity to frighten. It is not just that it features scary Witches who predict the future in riddles, or a murderous tyrant who strikes terror into every corner of his kingdom. Much of the power of the play derives from its staging of eerie, unsettling apparitions – a floating dagger, a bloody ghost, a series of visions that emerge from a cauldron. Even the name of the play has acquired a legendary apparitional power: merely to mention it in a playhouse is supposed to conjure unspeakably bad luck. What is behind the play’s ability to scare the heck out of us? This seminar will scrutinize Macbeth and its terrifying apparitions. As we will see, these apparitions are not just plot points or theatrical special effects. They are also emblematic of the spectral power of matter to conjure untimely possibilities and impossibilities – to make us feel, as Lady Macbeth says, “the future in the instant.” We will consider how Macbeth’s apparitions have eerily predicted subsequent apparitions of the play, in theory (Sigmund Freud’s account of psychological attachment, Terry Eagleton’s analysis of capitalist reification, Michel Serres’s imagining of human-non-human assemblages) and in cinema (Polanski’s Macbeth, Kurosawa’s Throne of Blood, Bhardwaj’s Maqbool, Jayaraj’s Veeram). In the process, we will treat the “apparitional” as a theoretical lens that helps us think about the temporalities of political conflicts involving tradition and modernity, indigeneity and cosmopolitanism, globalisation and planetary turmoil, violent tyranny and resistance.

Grading Rubric

A-F

data.name: Chorality
data.html_details:
Overview

The chorus was an integral part of ancient Greek drama. Singing and dancing in the orchestra, the choruses of tragedy moralized, hymned the gods, and lamented, incorporating lyric meters and rhythms into drama. In comedy, playwrights created ever more fantastical choruses of animals and even clouds, poking fun at language, philosophy, religion, and political life. This course is an introduction to Greek and Roman drama through the chorus, considering ancient Greek choral lyric, the tragic choruses of Aeschylus, Sophocles, and Euripides, the comic choruses of Aristophanes, and the transformation of the chorus into monologue in the Roman dramas of Seneca. We will also consider the endurance of the choral voice in modern performance, including musicals on stage and screen.

data.name: Gender Lens Reporting
data.html_details:
Overview

Spring 2022

MS-2115-1 Gender Lens Reporting

Course Overview

Patriarchal agendas still form the bedrock of public discourse. Media outlets refuse to treat marginalised genders as equal participants in the nation and its politics.

Many news organisations believe that they are pulling their weight because they publish a few pieces that cater to gender – the odd inspirational business story, something about reproductive health, the occasional report of domestic or sexual assault, harassment, violence, government schemes or aid for the trans community.

So, how can we begin to fix this problem?

The answer is that we can apply something known as a gender lens. A gender lens is not a tangible object; it is a way of looking at things, a means to critically assess a wide range of social and political situations, to see how gender-inclusive or gender-sensitive they are.

In a patriarchal world, most critical decision-making powers lie with cis men. This approach shifts the focus and allows us to identify opportunities for those powers to be distributed more evenly.

It highlights the difference in interests for various genders– be that within the same household, state, country, or globally – and also shows how they interact.

Put simply, it is like a pair of spectacles that correct the prevailing view of marginalised genders and their place in the world.

In this course, you will learn how across the global media, gender stereotypes are used to trivialise, objectify and sexualise. With the application of the gender lens, you will be provided with a viewfinder that filters all of that out and exposes the roots of inequality. It will help the students place the spotlight on the realities, needs and perceptions of all genders and not just cis-men.

One of the gender gaps in society is between those who have immersed themselves in scholarship on gender and the privileged who may not have, or not as much. Same with gaps between, LGBTQI people and cisgender people.

Far from ignoring cis men, gender lens reporting will allow them to consider the world more holistically and reveals how their interests intersect with those of other genders.

With a few exceptions 'gender issues' are always seen as exclusive of the wider world of economics, politics, sport and current affairs.

In the conventional reporting hierarchy, gender issues are often perceived as a “soft” subject. There is nothing soft about war reporting or investigative journalism. Yet both fields abound with stories that directly relate to all gender and not just cis-men – and, therefore, everyone else’s – lives. Comprehensive and genuinely reflective coverage must consider all.

Through, news reports, films, exercises, field trips, seminars, discussions, the students will learn how to cover important stories – be they of war, poverty, or crime – objectively and responsibly, by looking for the intersections of gender and these “bigger” issues.

This class will study reportage on women, men, and LGBTQI issues from an intersectional perspective, as tempered by race, ethnicity, nationality, caste and class – as well as other factors such as religion, culture and ideology.

Inclusive reporting would also look at the gender diversity involved both in the decision-making and influencing public opinion processes leading up to the creating and passing of legislation, policies, and their execution.

There are many other topics to investigate as well: such as the terms of professional survival, success and leadership, in journalism and other fields. We will study body issues: health, sexuality, gender identity, and reproductivity. We will also look at migration, displacement, conflict, and development. The goal is to understand plural voices to provide a solid foundation for change.

The students will be taught how to use these intersections to write ground reports, narrative pieces and profiles.


Instructor’s bio:  
Neha Dixit is an independent investigative journalist based in New Delhi, India. She covers politics, gender and social Justice in South Asia. She has worked with multiple mediums and reports for Al Jazeera, Washington Post, Caravan, Wire and others. She has won over a dozen international and national journalism awards, including One Young World Journalist of the Year Award 2020, International Press Freedom Award 2019, Chameli Devi Jain Award for Outstanding Woman Journalist 2016, Kurt Schork Award in International Journalism 2014, Lorenzo Natali Prize for Journalism from the European Commission, 2011 among others. She is a contributor to the UNESCO Casebook of Investigative Journalism 2011, Zubaan anthology on Sexual violence in South Asia and First Hand: Graphic Non-Fiction in India and others.

data.name: In Situ: architecture, sculpture and painting in the Western Himalayas
data.html_details:
Overview

Course Description:

This course is an introduction to the architecture, sculpture and paintings of Buddhist temples and monasteries in the Western Himalayas, with a focus on extant sites in Ladakh and Himachal Pradesh. Students will study major sites of art historical and cultural importance, while tracing their roots and interconnections to developments in art, religion, iconography and aesthetics in Kashmir, Bihar and Tibet and Nepal.

The course focuses on studying monasteries and temples through their geographical location, their usage, and changes in structure and style in response to religious and socio-political developments. The artistic strategies employed, the material used in making paintings and sculptures will be explored in relation to their architectonic contexts as well as the ritual requirements of different schools of Buddhism in the region. Students will also be familiarized with artistic styles from the late 9th century onwards and the major iconographic programmes and deities of the 'Tibetan Buddhist' pantheon.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, students:

  • Will be conversant with the history and development of major Tibetan Buddhist temples and monasteries in Ladakh and Himachal Pradesh.
  • Will have the ability to ‘read’ sites as architectonic spaces, and study the architecture, sculptures and paintings in relation to their usage.
  • Will be able to identify major deities of the Tibetan Buddhist pantheon and recognise stylistic features of early Tibetan Buddhist art.
  • Will be familiar with developments in the art of the region in conjunction with changes in religious and socio-political contexts of patronage.
  • Will be able to write concise art historical notes about specific sites/ sculptural programme/ paintings etc.

data.name: Collectivism in Art: Nodes from the 20th and early 21st Century
data.html_details:
Overview

Course Title: Collectivism in Art: Nodes from the 20th and early 21st Century

Course Instructor: Srinivas Aditya Mopidevi

Level of the Course: Undergraduate

Prerequisites: None

Course Description:

This course introduces students to the multifaceted idea of the collective in artistic practices of the 20th and early 21st centuries. It unpacks how the idea of collective and collectivity evolved amid a diverse set of historical, cultural, and political contingencies in different parts of the world. From the Vernacular practices of art in India to The Situationist International in Europe, the idea of what constitutes a collective has seen radical shifts and transformations. Collectivism after Modernism, for instance, embraced the heterogeneous character of cultural formations and contested the established notions of individual artistic genius. The collectives that formed in the wake of the internet such as Sarai (New Delhi) began thinking beyond the framework of the nation-state with newly networked cultural communities across the world. At the same time, there are contemporary art collectives like the Gulf Labor Coalition, a temporary group of artists from New York who came together to fight for the betterment of labor conditions in the United Arab Emirates.

With an overview of collectivism in the 20th and early 21st Century, this course will unpack the radical potential and limitations of collective formations of the world. The geographical scope of the discussions will include South Asia, Aboriginal Australia, Indonesia, Russia, Japan to mention a few. The course aims to provide the students with a comprehensive idea of what it means to be a collective in the turbulent times we live in.

Course Modules:

  1. Collective: Introduction to how the idea of collective manifested across the world.
  2. Community: Collective and its manifestations in Indigenous and Aboriginal cultures of South Asia, and Australia.
  3. Avant-garde: Discussion on Futurism, Dadaism, Surrealism, Constructivism, and The Situationist International.
  4. Post-Independent India: Progressive Artists Group, Bombay, Delhi Silpi Chakra, 1890 Group, Indian Radical Sculptors and Painters Association.
  5. Network: Collectives that emerged in the wake of the Internet Jodi Brothers, Raqs Media Collective, and Nettime.
  6. Labor Rights: Introduction to the practices of Gulf Labor Coalition (New York / Abu Dhabi), Art Labor (Ho Chi Minh City), Art Workers' Coalition (New York).
  7. Anti-Administration: Discussion on activist groups, Chim↑Pom (Tokyo), Forensic Architecture (London), Decolonizing Architecture Art Research (DAAR), The Yes Men (New York).
  8. Archive: An overview of the work by CAMP (Mumbai), The Atlas Group (New York), Arab Image Foundation (Lebanon), Lost Society Document (Taipei), The Propeller Group (Ho Chi Minh City).
  9. Gender: Conversation on the practices of Guerrilla Girls ( New York), Mai-Thu Perret, The Crystal Frontier (New Mexico), General Idea (Toronto / New York), Pinjra Tod (New Delhi).
  10. Ecology: Discussion on Toxic Links (New Delhi), Carbon Defense League (USA), SUPERFLEX (Copenhagen).
  11. Dissent: Discussions on the political movements of Rhodes Must Fall, Black Lives Matter, and Shaheen Bagh emerged in the wake of the new citizenship bill in India.
  12. Life: A case study of collectivism in Indonesia discussing the activities of ruangrupa.
Learning Outcomes

Learning Objectives:

By the end of this course, students:

  • Will be well versed in the idea of collective and collectivism in the 20th and early 21st Century.
  • Will develop an understanding of art movements such as Futurism, Dadaism, as well as the idea of collective in Vernacular practices of India and Aboriginal Australia.
  • Will understand from a historical perspective the significance and limitations of a collective, especially in the turbulent times we live in.
  • Will be informed enough to embrace the idea of micro and macro creative collectives within the student community at Ashoka.

data.html_details:
Overview

What was the Little Ice Age? In what ways did early modern Europeans experience the night? How did the Ottoman Empire handle epidemics? How did the whale shape the history of Tokugawa Japan? These are some of the questions we will address in the present course in environmental history. It studies how human societies and the natural environment made each other across different parts of the early modern (1500-1800) world. In course of the semester, we will learn about Europe, the Americas, Russia, China, Japan, South Africa, Egypt, and South Asia. We will cover themes as diverse as time, literature, colonialism, disease, animals, knowledge, frontier, resource, and climate. By the end of the course, students will have a considerable understanding of how the modern world came about through how early modern humans negotiated their environment.

data.name: Economics of Waste
data.html_details:
Overview

Waste generation and disposal is an important, yet a neglected part of our daily lives. This course delves on different aspects of waste management. Course is divided into four parts. The first situates the course in the broad realm of Environmental Economics. It introduces the concepts of property rights and public goods. The second part looks at solid waste creation, collection and disposal. Third part talks about recycling, and design for environment. The final part introduces the concept of Circular Economy.

Since the course derives its relevance from current waste management practices, class participation, presentations and discussions are of utmost importance.

Learning Outcomes

Overview

Making of Indian Republic

This course examines the history of India from the Raj's twilight to the early decades of the republic. The students will get a chance to re-examine the familiar story starting from the second world war, the coming of the independence, partitioning of the British Empire, the making of the Indian constitution and the beginning of planned industrialization from a new perspective. This course lies at the intersection of history, politics, literature and sociology where the focus is not just the big political leaders, the state policies, and realpolitik but on the civil society drivers and the lesser-known figures, regional movements, grassroot workers, histories of labour, food and everyday technology. We will begin each segment through a primary source workshop involving an examination of the ephemera of the past such as the newspaper reportage, cartoon, paintings, advertisements, film posters along with regional literature, oral histories, memoirs, theatre and cinema of the period along with etc. This will be followed by a discussion on the prescribed readings that introduce new ways of understanding their past.

Overview

ASHOKA UNIVERSITY

Spring 2022

Name of the Course: Early Childhood Development

Lecture Timings: Mon/Wed; 11:50am - 1:20pm

Course Overview and Learning Outcomes

Instructor

Dr. Arti Maria

Email: artimaria@gmail.com, arti.maria@ashoka.edu.in

Course Overview

Science tells us that early years hold great promise and carry considerable risk. During these years responsive relationships and healthy stimulating environments help young children build sturdy brain architecture and it lays the foundation for their learning and development. This makes early childhood a critical entry point for ensuring inclusive growth and breaking the inter-generational cycles of poverty and deprivation.

The basic architecture of the brain is constructed through an ongoing process that begins before birth and is influenced by a pregnant woman’s health, her stress, her nutrition and the intrauterine environment. Of these early years, the period from conception to three years of age is the most critical period when the brain develops most rapidly, which makes it the singular window of opportunity to shape the child’s brain and her development. To nurture the cognitive capital of our country it is imperative that this opportunity is optimally tapped.

This new course has been designed to understand the neuroscience and developmental aspects of prenatal, neonatal, postnatal, and the early infancy period with implications on early childhood development. It covers the importance of the critical period of brain development with concepts of neuroplasticity in this period. The course aims to familiarize the students with the concepts of nurturing care framework, the special target population:the high-risk neonates including preterm babies, early identification of red flag signs that would provide an opportunity for early intervention that may mitigate the adverse neurodevelopmental sequelae in these babies. The role of family-centered care to provide a nurturing care framework is discussed to optimize the neurodevelopmental outcomes of high-risk neonates. Students will be involved in active participatory learning and each one will get a chance to present research papers and review articles on relevant topics every week. Wherever possible, the use of videos and illustrative case discussions will be incorporated to make the learning enjoyable and practically oriented.

Specific Learning Outcomes

  1. Understanding connecting brain to the body
  2. Fetal and Infant Neurobehavioral Development: Basic Processes and Environmental Influences.
  3. Brain development and the nature versus nurture debate.
  4. Prenatal Antecedents of Newborn Neurological Maturation; Fetal state concordance predicts infant state regulation.
  5. To understand the Overview of The Nurturing Care Framework
  6. What is early childhood development? Why is it important ? Concept of first 1000 days of life.
  7. To understand clinical and prenatal mechanisms and influences that shape fetal and neonatal and early childhood development.
  8. To learn the concept of neuroplasticity and development of the brain through early critical period of brain development.
  9. The time of the infant, parent-infant desynchronization and attachment disorganization
  10. To understand the concept of a high-risk newborn, how to identify high-risk newborns and infants with red flag signs, the need for continued follow-up, that will provide an opportunity for early intervention; in order to optimize neurodevelopmental outcomes of these high-risk neonates.
  11. To study the principles of early intervention that may mitigate the adverse neurodevelopmental sequelae in these high risk babies.
  12. Family Centered Care: A gateway to Nurturing Care Framework: The role of mother and other primary care providers to enable them to participate in family-centered care and to create an environment of nurturing care in early vulnerable periods of the newborns.
  13. To understand the concepts in epigenetics and infant health. Students will be involved in active participatory learning and each one will get a chance to present research papers and review articles on the relevant topics.
  14. Maternal mental health and impact on Early Childhood Development
  15. Improving Early Child Development: WHO Guidelines

data.name: Science, Everyday Life and Climate Change
data.html_details:
Overview

Instructor: Anshu Ogra

Course description:

The epistemological roots of climate change analysis are deeply embedded in the natural sciences. This course introduces students to an innovative shift in climate change pedagogy: from global climatological narratives to lived everyday experience. It uses everyday life as a conceptual tool for engaging with the often-frustrating question: ‘What can I do to address climate change?’. The action paralysis induced by this dilemma is indicative of spatial and temporal disconnect between the ‘objective’ narrative of the (climate) sciences, and the lived narratives of unprecedented weather variation experienced in everyday life. This course will use a feminist science studies framework of situated knowledge to help students move beyond the global vs local divide in climate change discussions and engage with the lived experience of unprecedented weather variations on the ground in order to better address this pressing challenge of our times.

Instructor: Vijay Ramprasad

Course description

Worldwide and in India, tree planting is all the rage. Tree planting is used as a solution to mitigate climate impacts, decrease poverty, support rural livelihoods, improve air quality, restore landscapes, and conserve biodiversity. But, what is the evidence that tree planting works? Can tree planting do no harm? What are the politics and economics of tree-based solutions? This course will introduce students to the hot topic of trees and tree planting in various land uses such as forests, farmlands, watersheds, and plantations. By the end of the course, students will understand how trees are positioned in climate, sustainability, and development policy. Through interdisciplinary readings, this course will involve students closely in examining the evidence that support and caution against tree planting. The course is designed to be use-inspired, solutions-driven, and highly participatory with a suite of group and individual activities.

data.name: Reading History
data.html_details:
Overview

The course will explore how history as a modern discipline comes into being in the nineteenth century, and how it changes over time. It will focus on some of the dominant traditions of historical writing, and the internal dialogues within the traditions. It will move from positivism to critical theory, from Marxism to the Annales, from the French historical tradition to English social history, from Foucault’s discursive turn to Michel de Certeau’s focus on everyday practice. Through this journey, we will reflect on some of the binaries that often shape historical thinking –– the questions of history and myth, certainty and ambiguity, objectivity and prejudice, truth and falsehood –– and see how these notions are questioned and rethought over time.

If historians in the nineteenth century established some of the founding premises of the historian’s craft, the ‘critical turn’ from the 1970s has powerfully questioned many of these assumptions. underlining the complex nature of historical practice. It has persuaded historians to ask: what does it mean to enter the archive and mine the traces of the past, to read the record, to see and represent, to narrate, and to write a story based on evidence? This course will explore what this critical turn has meant to the writing of history, how it has forced historians to question earlier frames, and opened up new worlds of research.

Structure:

For most themes – except two – there will be one lecture, and after three lectures there will be a discussion around student presentations. Two of the 15 listed themes will be explored primarily through student presentations.

On some days, there will be a film screening followed by a discussion on the film. We will explore how the film resonates with the themes of our concern.

Learning Outcomes

The course will help students understand how the discipline of history itself has a history, and how it has developed over time, through discussions and debates, arguments and refutations, shifts in frameworks and assumptions. It will help students engage with historical texts critically, understand the assumptions on which specific arguments are elaborated, and the frames within which historical knowledge is presented.

data.name: Critical Thinking Seminar: Critical Bhakti
data.html_details:
Overview

ENG-2412-1 Critical Thinking Seminar: Critical Bhakti Nitya Pawar

MW 10:10-11:40

Bhakti is a term that has become synonymous with blind faith and a lack of criticality. This seminar works towards a deeper understanding of its meanings. While we primarily study literature from the Bhakti Movement in the Indian subcontinent, the ideas and questions range from the contemporary political sphere to the ancient usage of the term bhakti. Throughout the semester we engage with some of the following questions: Who is a bhakt and what is bhakti? Is it one idea or there are multiple bhaktis? Is there particular literature that can be called the bhakti literature? What kind of movement(s) does the Bhakti Movement include in it? Is bhakti complete and blind surrender? Or can it be an expression of dissent? What is the object of bhakti? To what extent is a bhakt’s devotion erotic? Is bhakti a gendered phenomenon? How is Mira’s bhakti different or the same as that of Andal’s or Sur’s or Kabir’s? What makes them stand out as bhakts or saints? Would it be possible to call a Sufi saint a bhakt? We will read popular saint-poets such as Kabir, Mira, and Andal along with some not-so-popular figures such as Janabai, Lalon Fakir, and Dayaram. This course aims towards thinking of bhakti itself as a mode of critical engagement. For this purpose, the course also builds a conversation with critical thinkers such as Bruno Latour, Helen Cixous, Roland Barthes, and others. In turn, one of the key takeaways of the course will be to think about surrender and assertion while reading, thinking, and writing.

data.name: Gender Matters in Global Politics
data.html_details:
Overview

This course is concerned with gender ‘in’ International Relations. It is comprehensive introduction to a way of analyzing and researching global politics and international relations that takes gender seriously as a category of analysis. More specifically, it is concerned with how ideas of war, peace, sovereignty, violence, foreign policy, governance and political economy are sustained by specific masculinities and femininities, and how these particular gender constructions impact on the lives of particular groups of men and women. Set against this, the aim of the course is mainly threefold: firstly, to (re)introduce how the discipline has traditionally thought about war and peace; secondly, to reveal the gendered constructions and inequalities that mark the traditional scholarship; and thirdly, to evaluate the specific contribution that feminist critiques have made as part of the so-called ‘Critical Turn’ in IR. Gender is understood here not as a synonym for ‘woman’ but as a hierarchical coding of masculinity and femininity that pervades social relations and institutional practices, with systemic (though not deterministic) effects on inequalities. Gender meanings and practices permeate our lives, and a closer look at these processes is more illuminating than many anticipate, with relevance and implications for who we are, how we think, and how we act – as individuals, groups, communities and nation-states.

Learning Outcomes

Course Objectives:

  • Understand the landscape of feminist international relations thought and challenge gender-blind and gendered approaches to global politics
  • Complicate understandings of global politics by identifying relationship between global crises and global gender(ed) divisions
  • Appreciate that the international is personal and the personal is international and recognize the necessity and complexity of taking gender seriously in global politics.
