Overview

What exactly does regime type (democracy/autocracy) has to do with interstate warfare? It turns out there is a body of literature, known as the Democratic Peace (hereafter DP), that focus on such issues. The DP or the absence of wars between democracies, is one of the more significant findings to have emerged within International Relations scholarship in recent decades. It has consequently attracted significant and critical attention of a large body of scholars and policy-makers alike. In this course we will examine the history of the idea, its main empirical claims, the explanations for it, the auxiliary claims and the criticisms of the research. While the methodological slant will be on quantitative research, we will also examine issues of research design as well as historical case studies as appropriate.

Learning Outcomes

1) Since the course is focused on one topic, the DP, students will acquire substantive knowledge about the major issues in DP research. They should be able to highlight the major works and the arguments made therein. 2) Students should be able to provide a reasoned critique of the major works. This is part of the process of learning to reason in a social scientific manner. 3) Students should gain an exposure to some of the quantitative literature on international conflict. 4) Finally, students should be able to judge the validity of the democratic peace and crucially, justify their judgment.

In this course, students will experiment with the genre of the short story as a means of developing different imaginative approaches to experience. Overview

We live in an era in which the processes of content production and the patterns of media consumption are changing rapidly. Even the most seasoned media professionals are struggling to determine what the media landscape of the future will look like and what business models can be used to support it. In addition, because of the ubiquity of media in our lives, there is unprecedented questioning of how society is being harmed by certain kinds of media messages like superficial or fake news, negative stereotypes, manipulative advertising, gratuitous violence, sex, and the list goes on. Fortunately, scholars have theorized media effects, both positive and negative, in many different ways and produced a very large research literature on if, how much, and how the media influence us. The broadly explanatory concepts of theory help us understand some of the underlying ways in which humans respond to and share different types of information, and can help us make some informed predictions about what the future may hold. This course will introduce students to mass communication theory, focus on theories of media effects and how belief or behaviour change has been conceptualized through constructs such as cognition, affect, attitudes, physiology, social norms, policy etc.

data.name: The Right to Water
data.html_details:
Overview

Water is life-giving and non-substitutable. Exactly a decade ago, in July 2010, the UN General Assembly adopted a resolution that recognized the right to safe and clean drinking water and sanitation as a human right. Yet, nearly a billion people in the world still lack access to safe drinking water, and water-related diseases and deaths remain pervasive, particularly in the Global South. Meanwhile, water grabbing, privatization of water, and mega hydraulic projects have been on the rise, thereby threatening the survival of millions and creating new grounds for water-related conflicts. Hence, right to water remains a rallying cry among scholars, activists, community leaders, and policymakers alike. At the same time, it is important to look at the rights framework critically and, as this course urges, think about water justice more broadly.

This course aims at providing students an in-depth understanding of some of the important theoretical perspectives on water and water governance, while exposing them to water-related conflicts and struggles around the world. We will deal with some of the key scholarship on the subjects of right to water and water justice.

The course is organized around five interrelated themes, which are as follows:

- Ontologies of Water

- Water Governance

- Water & Infrastructures

- Water Struggles and Movements, and

- Water Justice and the Right to Water

data.name: Literature and the World
data.html_details:
Overview

Homer’s Odyssey is one of the central texts of the western canon, and has been a continuous touchstone for literary creation since its earliest telling. With each retelling, authors have used the adventures of Odysseus to reflect on Homer’s time as well as their own. In this course, you will study the Odyssey and the long history of its influence on other works. Like the travels of Odysseus, you will sail to the horizons of the known world, and encounter many different cultures along the way. Your ship will launch from the Baghdad caliphate as you explore the medieval world of Sinbad the Sailor, from there you will travel into the depths of Dante’s Inferno, and sit next to the seat of empire in Alfred Lord Tennyson’s Victorian England, go on to grab a pint in a pub in James Joyce’s modernist Dublin, walk with Primo Levi through the unimaginable darkness of the Auschwitz death camp, journey across Derek Walcott’s Caribbean isle of St. Lucian, relive the Odyssey through Margaret Atwood’s feminist retelling of Penelope’s life, and, finally, return to the Mediterranean via Nigeria with Chigozie Obioma’s Igbo-inspired odyssey in An Orchestra of Minorities.

data.name: Literature and the World
data.html_details:
Overview

This course considers literature written in the former colonial languages of English and French and includes materials drawn from film, advertisements, the press, and historical documents. French texts will be read in English translation (originals may be used by those fluent in French). How does the view of the world change when those who were dominated take up the very languages that once represented colonial power? How does culture, taken broadly, from regions with varying relationships with their respective colonial powers—in Africa, the Indian subcontinent, the Caribbean, the Indian Ocean, New Zealand, Ireland, and Australia—reshape Europe’s modernity? And how do immigration and the presence of formerly colonized peoples within Europe interact with this contested notion of modernity? In considering these questions, this course will focus on the theoretical ideas of postcolonialism and decoloniality as they are expressed at the level of nation or group as well as at the micro-level, in the lives of individuals.

data.name: Literature and the World
data.html_details:
Overview

All stories are migrants. Looking at how stories have migrated across cultures over history, we will think about how any reading of a story is always a reading from a specific point in space and time that creatively reimagines that story in a new language and cultural context. Focusing on how stories from Ovid’s Metamorphoses and the Silk Road masterpiece A Thousand and One Nights were reimagined by Shakespeare, and then how Shakespeare’s retellings have been reimagined all over the world from the UK and the US to Sudan, Sierra Leone and India as poems, films, plays, novels, and graphic novels, this course will ask students to reimagine themselves too, as creative readers. The final project will be a group reimagining of one of the stories in the course in a medium and language of your choice – Urdu dastangoi, Hinglish play, English film, multilingual multimedia installation, or anything else.

data.name: Great Books
data.html_details:
Overview

Not all narratives become books and not all books are termed great. Many fabulous tales are transmitted orally and several terrific ideas are communicated through non-verbal means like art. Of the millions of stories and ideas and arguments that are written down in book form, only a fraction have significantly impacted the world as we know it today. In this course, we will read several books and fragments of books, all of which have shaped the ways in which we think about sexuality. The books we will read this semester come from different cultures, time periods, languages, and cover different subjects. Nonetheless, they all have something significant to offer us as we think about one of the most universal yet thorny issues in the world today.

data.html_details:
Overview

The goal of this class is to present students with access to advanced lectures on emotion, memory and cognition. Broadly divided into three modules, the lectures will be delivered by Dr. Bhismadev Chakrabarti, Dr. Narayanan Srinivasan, and Dr. Shona Chatterjee.

The 3 lecture series by Dr. Bhismadev Chakrabarti will be on the key concepts in emotion and empathy, going into their definitional histories, and introducing theoretical debates around these terms. An important distinction between first person vs second person aspects of emotional neuroscience will be explored. The second person approach, which will be explored by Dr. Chakrabarti, involves the observer understanding another person's emotions; while emotional understanding and cognition from the first person perspective will be delved into by Dr. Srinivasan. Moving further, the course will investigate empathy and emotional processing in non-human animals, particularly through rodent models, and then in non-human primates— does the chimpanzee have a theory of mind? Again, students will learn about several theoretical debates around the theory of mind in primates. The course will then shift its focus on humans; the developmental perspectives of emotion and empathy, and subsequently in adults with and without psychopathological conditions.

Dr. Shona Chattarji will then steer the course towards a neuroscientific approach, on the ways in which emotion and memory are connected, and the neural basis of emotionally charged memory, memory consolidation under stress, and PTSD. Dr. Srinivasan’s module will focus largely on the themes of cognition and emotion, exposing students to a range of topics within cognition. He will deal with emotion-cognition interactions, emotions and attention, emotions and memory, emotions and decision making. He will then move on to talking about emotion regulation: the process model of emotion regulation, different strategies used in emotion regulation, the neuroscience of emotion regulation, mindfulness/meditation and emotion regulation.

data.html_details:

Overview

Course title: Introduction to Mathematical Thinking

Course description:

Some of humankind’s most powerful and beautiful ideas live in Mathematics. This ancient and most human of disciplines also happens to be the ideal arena in which to gain experience in both analytical thinking as well as creative problem solving -- these twin aspects of mathematics are what will drive this course. The topics we will choose to work with will not require any technical background – you will be given all the tools you need. During this course, you will develop a set of broadly useful problem solving strategies and gain experience in making rigorous arguments while encountering landmark ideas. Among other things, we will look at the existence of non-rational lengths, the foundation of calculus, and Cantor’s set theory -- ideas that we take for granted today but which represent some of the "great works" of our collective intellectual history.

A sampling of topics we will cover:
The notion of infinity
Graph theory
A new look at induction
Symmetries and an introduction to algebra
Some ideas from probability

Learning Outcomes

In this course the goals are to:


Develop a set of broadly useful problem solving skills and strategies

These include strategies such as first addressing a simplified version of the question, examining extreme cases, making conjectures in the absence of solutions and the like. More broadly, you will gain experience with struggling with an unyielding problem, treating mistakes and false starts as essential, and being flexible, creative and persistent.


Gain experience in critical and analytical thinking

Mathematics trains us to always ask and answer the question, “How do we know that?” You will be expected to make clear arguments of your own, and to analyse the arguments of others.


Encounter some of history’s landmark ideas

Over the course of these sessions, we will look at, among other things, the existence of non-rational lengths, the foundation of calculus, and Cantor’s set theory. We take all of these for granted today, but they were all radical ideas in their time. This course aims to give you at least a glimpse of some of these “great works”.

data.html_details:

Thursday, Friday : 1.00PM-3.00PM

Also meetings can be scheduled by appointment. Please drop an email @barnali.chanda@ashoka.edu.in

Overview

In this course we will conduct a comparative literary study by focusing on the literary resemblances and contactual relationships and typological affinities within two ancient civilizations, India and China. The complex method of cultural confluence between India and China was initially a spontaneous contact that happened primarily as a result of an intellectual quest by the Buddhist monks. This literary-historical comparative study reveals the spontaneous interliterary contacts between these two civilizations. The Indian literary and philosophical values contributed to the formation and the development of the new trends of the strange tales in the recipient literature. This exchange between India and China is important because Chinese literature is enriched by Indian literature not only as a consequence of direct contacts but also because of the inner potentialities of the emitting Indian phenomenon and this happened in spite of the existence of China’s own strong and powerful cultural heritage. The interliterary reciprocity of these two countries formed a concrete literary and cultural relation and the impact of the source culture was almost undistinguishable and had a creative manifestation in the recipient narrative tradition. The creative manifestation of the narrative tradition due to this direct impact from the source culture was only possible for the recipient culture of China because it already had its own strong and written literary tradition. This course will conduct the thematic comparative study of the strange tales of China and India and its migration to Afroeurasian region. This study will execute a systematic analysis with reference to the cultural, aesthetic and intellectual situation while looking into the lapses and the surviving and the residual elements.

The Unit –I touches upon the advent of Buddhism and the transmission of the Buddhist elements via the translation of the miraculous indigenous strange tale tradition to which Buddhism contributed immensely. A short introduction to the bianwen genre which is considered to be a direct descendent of the Indian gatha tradition will be introduced. Following the Confucian ideology which emphasise greatly on the documentation of history, the narratives that included supernatural elements were documented as a history of the other world. Buddhism, Confucianism and Daoism together had contributed to the growth of the strange tale tradition in China.

Unit 2 will examine the emergence of China as a Buddhist realm and the phase of termination and also discuss the Tang-India diplomatic relations during premodern time. With this advent of Buddhism the translation of Buddhist literatures escalated. The course will discuss the problems and prospects of the early Chinese translations which helped in the linguistic development and evolution. Unit 3 will discuss the spread of Buddhism across and beyond Asia. Buddhism in China has immensely contributed to the evolution of narrative traditions in China. This unit will illustrate the Indic philosophical concepts and estimate its influence on different narrative genres through the readings of folktales and strange stories. The connection between the historicity and fictionality of the narratives can be understood through the readings of different genres of literatures.

Unit 4 will examine four motifs/themes that are essentially Buddhist and the course can study their reception and acclimatization within the Chinese strange tale tradition. Parallely the course will examine the evolution of similar motifs in the Indian Sanskrit tradition. The purpose of the course also is to draw a pattern expressed through thematic resemblances of the strange and the fantastic stories of the medieval Indian and Chinese literary traditions. With this parallel study it can also be established that after traveling to China, Buddhist philosophy influenced indigenous Chinese folk and popular story tradition and the idea of Buddhism eventually got merged with Daoism and indigenous story tradition.

Learning Outcomes

1. The students will learn about the early and premodern India China historical and literary connections

2. They will know about different genres of literature and historical writings

3. They will learn to understand historical connections and networks through the readings of chinese and Sanskrit stories in translation

data.html_details:
Overview

This course – required of interdisciplinary majors in English and Performing Arts – explores the social phenomenon of performance and its theoretical value to the humanities. It investigates the historical context within which performance studies emerged in the late-twentieth century and traces its disciplinary development through early twenty-first century. The course will focus on three recurring themes in performance studies: the relationship between representation and performance, the paradigm of performativity, and the debate between whether performance is an ephemeral or enduring phenomenon. Moreover, in reading these theories alongside Indian theoretical and performance texts, this course decenters the U.S.-focussed history of performance studies and investigates how this discipline can engage with non-Western cultures.

data.name: Multiple Histories of Bharatanatyam
data.html_details:
Overview

Taught by Justin McCarthy

The dance now known as bharatanatyam can be seen through the light of a number of parallel histories. Fragments of these histories can be found in documents, letters, treatises, books, and dramatic and poetic texts. But they also exist in less substantive archives like music, aural narratives, informal reminiscences and, most importantly, in the body. Changing movement patterns, the shifting intentions behind the dance’s gestural language, and evolving sequences of mores and ideas of the self can all be felt or seen in the body of the dancer. This course will look at bharatanatyam through a combination of all of these approaches. Depending on the composition of the class, there may also be a practical component involved in some of the project-oriented work.

Using diverse methodologies, students will participate in the creation of a performance based on a sub-continental dramatic or poetic work. The focus will be on crafting a cohesive whole using the various facets of performance art. Practical texts on performance will also provide a grid for ongoing analyses of the performative process. The semester will be punctuated by semi-public and public delineations of the work in progress. data.name: Understanding Structure and Function
data.html_details:
Office timing

Tuesday 11.50am-1:20pm

Friday 11.50am-1:20pm

Overview

Have you ever visited a keymaker? You must have seen lots of premade keys with unique shapes and sizes. However, only certain keys might work for a particular lock. But what makes a particular key functional, not the others? It entirely depends on the structural features of the key. Similarly, in biology, we have thousands of such keys for specific locks that mediate numerous biological functions. This course will discuss how these biological keys or biomolecules are structured for their specific functions. Through this journey, we will ask some of these questions:

  • What is the molecular basis of biomolecular structures: size-shape-stability?
  • Atomic and molecular understanding of biomolecular complexity
  • Why so many players? Thousands of structure-based molecular keys in cell function
  • Structured, unstructured/disordered biomolecules, and polymorphism
  • Ordered vs disordered biomolecules, a sweet balance between life and death
  • How does structure define a biomolecular function? Understanding the molecular basis of sensory organs
  • What can go wrong if the structure becomes defective? A story of cell dysfunction to disease state.
  • Effects of genetic disorders in biomolecular structural defects. How do we restore them?
Learning Outcomes

Students will acquire a fundamental understanding of the molecular basis and dependency of biomolecular structures and functions. We will walk you through a multidisciplinary approach to understand the atomic and molecular level understanding of biomolecular architecture and its role in stability, diversity, and function. We will discuss how to utilize the molecular understanding of biologics in solving various genetic and epigenetic diseases. Students will also be introduced to the possibility of the structure-based functional aspect in synthetic biology and synthetic life.

data.html_details:
Overview

Distributed computing systems, by definition, involve a multitude of computing agents – often distributed over different geographic locations – connected by means of a communication network. Distributed computing is concerned with leveraging the presence of multiple computing entities – and thus more computing power – to solve various computing problems. However, as Spiderman’s uncle famously said once, “With great power, comes great responsibilities.” That’s especially true for distributed systems. With the separation and independence that follows the presence of more than one computing system, arise the issues of communication and coordination. Unlike sequential computing, where we are primarily worried about time complexity and space complexity, in distributed computing, we also have to take these issues into account. This makes it a tricky – but highly interesting – subject of study.

In this course, we will primarily focus on distributed network algorithms. In distributed network algorithms, the different computing agents are modeled as nodes of a graph and they are connected via edges of that graph. Rather than studying any domain-specific problems, we will study fundamental problems that arise as basic building boxes in most areas of distributed computing.

The course will be divided into three parts. In the first part, we will talk about different models of distributed computing. We will discuss information dissemination algorithms such as broadcast, convergecast. We will look at how to construct a BFS tree in a distributed manner, and so on. We will conclude this section with a study of the shortest path problem in the distributed setting.

The second part of the course will focus on the distributed minimum spanning tree problem and the distributed leader election problem. Note that the leader election problem can also be thought of as a global "symmetry breaking" problem.

The third part of the course will focus on various local “symmetry breaking” problems such as independent set and coloring.


NOTE:

  1. This course is intended to supplement, not supplant, a course on distributed systems.
  2. This course will be useful mostly to those students who wish to pursue doctoral study and research in the following research area: "the theory of distributed computing systems."
Learning Outcomes

After successfully completing this course, students will have a preliminary understanding of

  1. how distributed computing systems are modeled,
  2. how distributed algorithms are designed and analyzed,
  3. what the fundamental algorithmic problems in distributed computing are,
  4. how the structure of the network graph affects the performance of distributed algorithms,


and so on.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Primary reading material: The textbook "Distributed Network Algorithms" by Gopal Pandurangan. The textbook is available for free on his website: https://sites.google.com/site/gopalpandurangan/dna.

Secondary reading materials:

  1. Distributed Algorithms (by Nancy Lynch): https://www.elsevier.com/books/distributed-algorithms/lynch/978-1-55860-348-6.
  2. Distributed Computing: A Locality-Sensitive Approach (by David Peleg): https://epubs.siam.org/doi/book/10.1137/1.9780898719772.


Students will not be expected to have access to the secondary reading materials, considering that they are prohibitively expensive. But if somehow a student manages to get access to any of these two books, then it is highly recommended that they try to take advantage of it. Each of these books is a classic and provides a rigorous treatment of the subject matter.

Grading Rubric

Each part of the course will have its own exam. There will be intermittent problem sets meant to serve as assignments. The different evaluation components will contribute the following proportions to your total score:

  • Three sectional exams – 20% each
  • The assignments (combined) – 40%


The assignments will be, for the most part, algorithmic problems. It is important that you are already familiar with describing algorithms – precisely and concisely – in English or in pseudocode. You should also be comfortable with mathematically analyzing the performance of algorithms. We will not run computer programs (although interested students are welcome to do so at home) to verify the correctness of an algorithm or to measure its performance. We will prove an algorithm’s correctness and mathematically derive bounds on its performance. Thus there will be plenty of mathematical writing to do, but no coding, in this course.

Attendance Policy

None.

data.name: Advanced Philosophy of Mind
data.html_details:
Overview

An important feature of mental states, such as beliefs, desires, and experiences, is that they can be about, or represent, things in the world. For example, Mary’s belief that the cat is on the mat is about a cat, intuitively, and represents the world as being such that this cat has a certain property, namely being on the mat. The power of minds or mental states to represent things in the world is known as intentionality. Despite its central place within the philosophy of mind, intentionality raises a number of puzzles closely connected to other areas of philosophy, including the philosophy of language, metaphysics, epistemology, and the philosophy of mathematics. For example, there are numerous puzzles related to what is known as singular thought, or thoughts about a particular thing. Consider the thought that Pegasus does not exist, for instance. This thought is about Pegasus, apparently, and so presupposes the existence of Pegasus. Yet the thought is true only if Pegasus does not exist. Or consider that John can seemingly believe that Mark Twain is a famous author without also believing that Samuel Clemens is a famous author, even though ‘Mark Twain’ and ‘Samuel Clemens’ name the same person. Or consider that we can seemingly have singular thoughts about abstract objects: our knowledge that 3 = 2 + 1 is about the number 3, intuitively. How is this possible, if numbers exist outside of space and time? The purpose of this course is to survey intentionality, its place within the philosophy of mind, and the various puzzles it raises. The course should be of interest to anyone interested in the philosophy of mind, philosophy of language, metaphysics, epistemology, philosophy of mathematics, and perhaps logic (though to a lesser extent).

Office timing

Overview

What are we? This is the question of personal identity. This course will examine this question and ethical questions related to this question, like whether certain theories of personal identity lend support to certain theories of ethics, and what moral significance the fact of personal identity has.

The course will begin with a discussion of some main theories of personal identity, including pyschological views, physical views, animalism, narrative views, and no-self views, along with some related ethical topics. Further topics will be chosen by class votes.

Learning Outcomes
  • Learn about the strengths and weaknesses of the key theories of personal identity and about intersections between personal identity and ethics
  • Improve your writing skills with a focus on concise summary and argumentation
  • If desired, develop and hone your capacity to explain complex philosophical ideas in a variety of ways
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

All readings will be provided on Canvas.

  • Aug 30: Selections from The Questions of King Milinda and Hume's A Treatise of Human Nature
  • Sep 1: Perry, "A Dialogue on Personal Identity and Immortality"

  • Oct 6: Rovane, "Reductionism, Self-Constitution, and the Moral Significance of Personal Identity"

Further readings will depend on what the class votes for. Possible topics include:

Personal Identity: Buddhism, Conventionalism, Dead Bodies, Death, Fetuses, Narrativism, No-Self, Parfit, Phenomenology

The lowest 6 reading quiz scores will be dropped. You will earn maximum credit (10% of your grade) if your average reading quiz score (after the lowest 6 have been dropped) is 80% or higher. You will earn maximum credit (10% of your grade) if your average reading Perusall score (after the lowest 6 have been dropped) is 80% or higher. Otherwise you will earn whatever your average Perusall score is.

500 Word Papers and/or Idea Illustrations (40% of your grade) are two different things. 500 word papers short writing assignments designed to give you practice writing concisely about philosophy and to give you more detailed feedback about how well you are understanding the material. Idea illustrations are things that make some idea clear to someone who is unfamiliar with it. There are 12 due and the lowest 6 will be dropped.

data.name: Classical Indian Epistemology
data.html_details:
Overview

Have you ever jumped in terror upon mistaking a rope for a snake? Have you ever been puzzled by a discovery that what you thought you knew for sure turned out to be a disastrous misconception? On every step we are bound to make mistakes, question our beliefs, and experience doubts, and yet it seems that sometimes we do know something and somehow manage in this world. In classical India, the attempts to understand the sources and validity of our knowledge grew into impressive epistemological traditions, such as Nyaya and the epistemological school of Buddhism. In fact, all philosophical schools in India developed their own theories of knowledge, in line with the fundamental presuppositions of these schools. In this course we will discuss some of the central topics in epistemology in classical India, such as perception, inference, and reliable testimony, as well as skeptical challenges, theories of truth and mistaken cognitions. As we will see, some of these debates have parallels in Western philosophy, and Indian theories have much to offer to contemporary epistemological thought.

This course does not expect any linguistic access in Sanskrit. Using translations, we will survey the treatment of the human figure in Sanskrit literature – from the Epics, poetry and plays, even religious stotras. In Intermediate Sanskrit I, we will read from one of the best-travelled specimens of narrative literature in Sanskrit – the Pañcatantra. data.name: History, Novels and Cinema: History Writing Seminar
data.html_details:
Office timing

Will be annoucning them through the course of the semester (or by appointment).

Every student must see me for office hours at least twice in a semester.

Overview

Can History be literary genre? Can a historian combine literary prose while retaining a commitment to her sources? Does this combination diminish the rigor of the craft? The dominant mode of historical writing still shies away from seeing history as a literary genre. This stems fundamentally from a disavowal of language as anything other than a vehicle of communication; a belief than use of anything other than dry prose diminishes the scientific rigor of the discipline; and a refusal to think of historian as ‘writer’ – a label reserved for novelists. This course however makes a case for History as creative non-fiction, a literary art form. Critics may still raise the question why should history be written so? The answer to this question lies in the politics of our times. History is now being communicated in wide variety of ways which includes narrative nonfiction, magazine articles, op-eds, museum exhibitions, policy documents, blogs, podcasts, fiction and nonfiction film, twitter feeds, and memes. The accessibility of these modes of narration gives them popular currency but also opens them up to political exploitation. The historians in order to contend with fake and distorted versions of the past therefore need to widen their ‘writing repertoire’ to include other modes of narration. This course introduces the students to narrative history through creative non-fiction, novels and cinema – all narrative genres – that are similar and yet different from history. The course will be taught workshop-style where there will lots of conversations, brainstorming sessions and creative dissensions along with in-class writing exercises. The course is focused on the ‘process’ of writing, the outcome of which will be a narrative historical essay written over a semester.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Essential Readings:

Joan Didon, ‘Why I Write’, New York Times Book Review, 5 Dec 1976

Susan Sontag, ‘Looking at War’

Atul Gawande, New Yorker, 2 August 2010

Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Chronicle of a Death Foretold

Ta-Nehisi Coates, ‘Fear of Black President’

Films:

Truman Show

Gone Girl

Paheli

Judgement at Nuremberg

Eternal Sunshine of a Spotless Mind

Grading Rubric

Everyone who takes this course will begin from a ‘contracted grade’ and work their way up or down from it. If you do all the labour asked of you, you are guaranteed a B+. That is if you have shown responsible effort and consistency in the class. And when you have done what was asked of you in the spirit it was asked. If you miss required activities, do not participate fully in the discussions, turn in assignments late, or forget to do assignments, you may earn a lower grade.

More than 5 absences is an automatic fail.

What will earn you a B+ Grade?

Attendance: 22 classes out of 26 (7 out of 9 Reflective writing exercises + 9 out of 11 classes of Narrative Assignment)

Office hour meeting: One

Grace days: 2 (taken together or separately)

Reflective Writing Exercises: Submission of 7 of them

Narrative Assignment: Completion

How to lose your Contracted Grade? Each item of labour not done will lead to grade reduction

How to improve your grade to A-?

Attendance: 24 out of 26 (8 out of 9 Reflective writing exercises + 10 out of 11 classes of Narrative Assignment)

Office hour meetings: 2

Grace days: None Taken

Reflective Writing Exercises: Submission of 8 of them

Narrative Essay: Completion

Extra written work: Writing a reflective essay on your experiences in the class and the manner in which it challenged or shifted your perspective of history and/or historical writing(1500-2000 words).

How to earn A grade?

Attendance: no absences

Office hours: 2

Grace days: none taken

Reflective writing exercises: submission of 9 of them

Narrative essay: completion

Extra written work:

Any one of the following activities:

A writing workshop planning: A handout on a topic and material that you research for the class’s benefit and will need at least 2 weeks lead time, working with me on the materials. While we’ll determine together the scope your lesson, the main elements of your labor will be to produce: (1) a 1-2 page writing activity handout (2) an outline for our in-class activity that introduces your handout; and (3) a short reflective essay to me of about 1-2 pages (300-600 words) on what you learned in the process of doing this labor and what you feel the class stands to gain from the lesson you offered us.

Doing peer-review for two of your classmates and writing up a reflective essay about it (300-600 words).

Or any other labour that benefits the class: Do you want to write about and report to us on a historical writing/novel/movie related to the class? Or maybe you would like to read an article for us and summarize some of its findings or ideas that you think will help us do our work in class? If you have an idea, come to me early. data.html_details:
Overview

Taught by Ainee Farooqui & Nusrat Ansari

The word Dastangoi refers to the art of storytelling. Dastans were epics, often oral in nature, which were recited or read aloud and in essence were like medieval romances everywhere. Dastangoi died out with its last traditional proponent Mir Baqar Ali in 1928. Over the last 15 years it has seen a major revival thanks to the scholarship of the late S. R. Faruqi and the efforts of his nephew Mahmood Farooqui, who has trained dozens in this modern art form. We will analyse and compare traditional and modern Dastangoi performances using practical examples and lecture demonstrations. We will also simultaneously work on performative aspects of dastangoi- voice modulation, poetry recitation, pronunciation, expression. Towards the end, the students will be required to stage one of the traditional dastans.

data.name: Pulse and Impulse: Rhythm and Time in Music
data.html_details:
Overview

Taught by Punita G. Singh

This course focuses on temporal aspects of music from an interdisciplinary perspective. Intuitive human tendencies like entrainment and beat induction have led to most music adhering to a cyclical meter with a regular pulse, but creativity and cultural propensities produce artistic variants that enrich the musical universe. Some genres of music create hierarchical metrical structures. Some displace or layer sound sequences to create syncopation and polyrhythms. Some build up compound rhythms from simpler patterns, while some dispense with a temporal scaffold altogether. The use of instruments to create rhythm patterns or mark time also varies across cultures. Drawing on concepts in music as well as anthropology, cognitive neuropsychology, literature and physics, the impulse to perceive and produce rhythm is explored and experienced through attentive listening and performance activities.

The emergent technologies of mass communication have a significant bearing on the newfound visibility of Bhojpuri. Thanks to the cassette revolution of the late 80s, single-screen theatres, and, of late, a YouTube-steered resurgence of the vernacular, Bhojpuri appears stronger than ever. Overview

This course will introduce you to some common statistical techniques used by scientists to answer questions of ecological or conservation relevance. data.name: Ecology: Ecosystems and Biodiversity
data.html_details:
Office timing

Class timings: Monday and Wednesday, 2:50-4.20 pm

Office hours: Friday 12- 2 PM

Overview

This is an introductory course in ecological theory and application, designed for students from a wide range of disciplinary backgrounds (both sciences and humanities). The course will cover basic ecological concepts such as population ecology, community ecology, diversity, nutrient cycling, energy flow and evolution, among others and relate the theory to real-life environmental issues. The principal aims of this course are (1) to build a sound working knowledge of basic ecological concepts, and (2) to explore the applications of ecology to environmental concerns in the Anthropocene such as species extinction, climate change and soil depletion. The course will depend on lectures, movies, popular writings, discussions and group projects in class. This course will be a useful stepping stone for students who wish to take higher level ecological courses in EVS or BIO. In addition, it will be useful for students from a social sciences background who wish to engage with ecological issues.

One module will be covered each week, consisting of two lecture slots. Each module will consist of a lecture/slide-talk on the given topic followed by a class discussion on a related ecological issue. Textbook chapters will be prescribed as background reading for each class lecture. Movies, popular articles and news articles will form the basis for class discussions, that will principally aim to link the theory to the discussion topic. Group projects on current debates will form a significant component of learning (and assessment) in this course; the students will work on their group project beginning in Week 6.

List of Study Modules

Module 1: Discovering Ecology (Discussion Topic: What Ecologists do)

Module 2:Conceptualising Ecosystems (Discussion Topic -How we are Changing the Abiotic Environment)

Module 3: Life and the Physical Environment: Soil, Water and Nutrients (Discussion Topic- Sustainable farming)

Module 4: Ecosystems across the World (Discussion Topic- The Ecology of Deserts)

Module 5: Population Growth and regulation (Discussion Topic – Big Cats in Lived Landscapes)

Module 6: The Forces of Evolution

Module 7: Applications of Evolutionary Theory (Discussion Topic1: Evolution and Wildlife Conservation; Discussion Topic2- Quirky Reflections)

Module 8: Community Ecology I (Discussion Topic- Himalayan Birds in Multiple-Use Landscapes)

Module 9: Basics of Community Ecology II (Topic for Discussion: Trophic Cascades)

Module 10: Plant-Animal Interactions: How to be a Fig (Discussion topic- Plant Pollination in the Anthropocene)

Module 11: Ecological Succession (Discussion Topic: Restoring Forests)

Module 12: Balance of Nature? Understanding Equilibrium and Stochasticity (Discussion Topic 1: Equilibrial vs. Non-equilibrial Perspectives; Discussion Topic 2: Can Humans Fit in?)

Module 13: Role of Ecology in the Anthropocene (Student Projects)

Learning Outcomes

1) The course will build a working knowledge of basic ecological concepts;
2) Students will learn to apply basic ecological principles to current environmental challenges;
3) Students will learn to think analytically and write critically on current ecological debates and issues.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

List of Topics (Modules) and Reading List (1 Module will be covered in 3 lecture hours)

Module 1: Discovering Ecology

The students will be introduced to the subject of ecology, using a historical perspective on ecological enquiry. Discussion will be invited on the relevance and application of ecology as a science in the Anthropocene by exploring current ecological concerns. Students will read travelogues from early and modern ecologists (Salim Ali, Alfred Wallace, Alexander von Humboldt and others) in order to understand the practice of ecology as a science.

Background Reading:

None

Reading for Discussion Topic- What Ecologists Do

Module 2: Conceptualising Ecosystems

We will explore ecosystems and their different components. Concepts of energy flow, primary productivity, foodchains and foodwebs will be covered in addition to basic tenets of ecology. Discussion of abiotic factors such as climate will begin. The ecological concepts will be applied to understand climate change and its real-world implications for human ecology.

Background Reading:

Module 3: Life and the Physical Environment: Soil, Water and Nutrients

This module focusses on soils, and nutrient cycling, with the aim to introduce the students to ecosystem-level thinking. We study the underlying principles of flow of matter through ecosystems and the earth’s biogeochemical cycles, taking nitrogen, carbon and phosphorus as examples. The application of nutrient cycles for ecological health will be discussed, using the example of organic farming. Three short movies on organic farming will be used in this module, along with popular reading.

Module 4: Ecosystems across the World

This session will provide an introduction to the distribution of terrestrial and aquatic biomes across the world. Students will be introduced to the features that characterize and distinguish the earth’s biomes, particularly climatic factors and topography. Students will also be introduced to the classification of vegetation types in India as laid out in Champion & Seth (1968). Desert/grassland ecosystems will be taken up for discussion based on four popular articles that point to the complexity of the nature-economy-culture mosaic in which endangered species of the desert coexist with humans.

Module 5: Population Growth and regulation

Concepts of populations, population structure, different parameters associated with populations, growth curves and population age structure will be covered. Mechanisms of population regulation will also be covered. Applications of key concepts in population ecology to the real-life challenge of Bengal tiger conservation will be discussed, based on articles and news on tigers.

Module 6: The Forces of Evolution

Basic concepts of evolution and the historical aspects of evolutionary thought will be discussed. Sources of variation, mechanisms of natural selection, speciation, adaptive radiation and genetic drift will be introduced to the students. Classic writings on evolution by E.O. Wilson will be read in class.

Module 8: Community Ecology I

This module will introduce students to the study of the ecological community with a focus on the concept of biodiversity. They will learn how to characterise communities through commonly used metrics such as species richness, abundance, evenness, diversity indices and similarity will be discussed. The ideas of ecological niche and resource partitioning will be introduced. Patterns and drivers of community diversity and species turnover in space will be discussed, along with real-life applications.

Module 9: Basics of Community Ecology II

In the first part of this module, various interspecific interactions such as predator-prey relations and competition will be covered in detail. Historic lab and field experiments in community ecology will be discussed. The second part of this module deals with food web theory, as a way to describe and understand the complexity in the ecological world. The attributes of food webs that explain community persistence will be examined. The notion of ‘keystone species’ will be discussed. Debates on bottom-up and top-down forces and complexity-stability linkages will be introduced.

Module 10: Plant-Animal Interactions: How to be a Fig

Interactions between plant and animal species have been the subject of much enquiry in the field of ecology. Processes such as seed dispersal, herbivory and pollination that involve co-evolution between specific plant and animal taxa are important to study from the point of view of ecosystem management and restoration, but tend to be neglected in policies. This module introduces the students to the pioneering research on plant-animal interactions, mainly based in tropical ecosystems which show numerous specialized mutualisms. The applications to real-life conservation will also be discussed.

Module 11: Ecological Succession

Many of the spatial patterns in communities that we observe today reflect historical and ongoing ecological processes. The plant and animal communities observed today are likely to be very different from those that existed a few decades ago and bear the imprint of both ongoing ecological processes and human activities. We will explore the successional patterns in plant communities and how these patterns manifest in variations in communities of animals and plants that depend on them. Two short movies on plant succession in the context of forest restoration activities will be shown and discussed.

Module 12: Balance of Nature? Understanding Equilibrium and Stochasticity

This is a module primarily based on two student-led class discussions on the question. Students will present the papers and engender discussion in class with help from the tutor. The first discussion will explore the competing notions of equilibrium and disequilibrium in relation to ecosystems, communities and populations. In this context, the role of disturbances such as fragmentation, climate change and fire in maintaining biodiversity and ecological functioning will be studied. The question to be discussed is: Is it possible to reconcile the opposing viewpoints on equilibrium and disequilibrium in the ecological literature? The second part of this module connects equilibrium theory to the role of humans within ecosystems and the varying viewpoints from which this has been explored, thus connecting it to the literature of political ecology. The question to be explored: to what extent and under what circumstances can humans and nature co-exist?

data.name: Disciplinary Pasts
data.html_details:
Overview

This course examines the ways in which the history of social theory and disciplinary pasts of anthropology and sociology have been conceived at different moments and global locations. Rather than taking the idea of a canon as given, this course invites students to consider what constitutes enduring texts and questions in social theory, how intellectual influences and imperatives move across generations and geographical locations, and the vantage points from which disciplinary histories are constructed or reconstructed. Instead of an overview, this course seeks to closely re-inhabit particular moments, texts, and trajectories, and to ask how those histories, tensions and forms of illumination remain alive in the present.

Learning Outcomes

This course aims to teach graduate students in anthropology and sociology how to engage productively with their disciplinary past, understood not as a fixed canon, but as geneoalogies of thought, and a lively resource for current research.

data.name: Understanding Urban Poverty
data.html_details:
Overview

Understanding URBAN POVERTY- 200 LEVEL


More than 25 percent of the urban population is below the poverty line. By 2030, urbanisation in India is projected to reach 50 percent. This intensified complex, urban issues including land, water and sanitation. The course will focus on looking at socio-economic disparities in Urban India. Key teachings will be navigating geographical landscapes, government bureaucracies and hierarchies of resources and trauma in urban spaces.

Through lectures, reporting and assessment of a wide range of issues like affordable housing, unequal distribution of resources-electricity, public spaces, unorganised workforce, gender gap and more importantly, a lack of representation and voice in framing of urban policies, students will be taught how to report on urban poverty in an ethical, comprehensive and impactful manner.


Week 1: Introduction

Week 2: Urban Landscape: Access to public transport, public spaces-parks, roads, shopping areas. Eviction in the name of development, thrown to the outskirts. Urban designs exclusively for the rich.
Week 3: Inequality in resource distribution: Electricity, drinking water, sanitation, drainage
Week 4: Right to Housing: Lack of affordable places, rent economy, high density area, land rights for the marginalised
Week 5: Migration and reverse migration
Week 6: Right to Education: Access to quality schools, colleges, affordable vocational studies centres, higher education

Week 7: Living on the edge: Gender gap, caste gap, religious majoritarianism, regionalism
Week 8: Right to Health: Access to public healthcare and lack of infrastructure
Week 9: Political representation or the Lack of it: RWA, Wards, Assemblies
Week 10: Public Policies for the urban poor: Social security, kind of schemes and programs

Week 11: Workspaces: Unorganised labour: domestic work, unauthorised factories, sweatshops, contract workers, self employed
Week 12: Violence: From the state players, elite and the privileged.

Week 13: Revision



Attendance Policy

Only two absences permitted in the 13 week long course.

data.name: Financial Markets and Institutions
data.html_details:
Office timing

By appointment

Overview

The main emphasis of this course is to develop the perspectives of a practicing finance professional. This course will enable students to understand the role of financial markets and institutions in shaping the economic and business environment of the nation. With the help of some simplifying frameworks and models, the students will be equipped to develop a series of applications of principles from finance and economics that explore the connection between financial markets, financial institutions and the broader economy. The financial markets studied will include money markets, bond markets, insurance markets, stock markets and currency markets. Students will learn how the term structure of interest rates, stock and derivative market developments and currency fluctuations drive the financial flows.

Students will study the role of financial institutions (intermediation and innovation) played by central banks, commercial banks, investment banks, insurance companies and mutual funds in facilitating the flow of funds in the economy. Keynesian IS-LM theory and the loanable funds theory provide the theoretical background for the course and help students develop simple analytical frameworks to study the interaction of individuals, firms, governments, markets and the aggregate economy. The students will also understand the role of regulation in the overall functioning of financial markets and institutions in the economy.

In the course, the students will be helped to develop both a domestic and an international perspective.

Pedagogy:

Lecture cum discussion.

Case study discussion and analysis

In class discussion of articles from FT, WSJ …

Main Text book:

Frederic S. Mishkin, Stanley G. Eakins, Tulsi Jayakumar and R. K. Pattnaik, Financial Markets and Institutions. Pearson India Education Services Pvt. Ltd. Eighth Edition 2017

Learning Outcomes

Upon finishing the course, students are expected to

1. show the drivers behind the term structure of interest rates.

2. explain how investment banks and mutual funds operate.

3. discuss the stock valuation based on fundamental analysis.

4. read a bank’s balance sheet and discuss how risks are managed in banks.

5. know some histories of the insurance industries and how they operate.

6. grasp the basic features of options and futures and understand how they play out in the financial markets and by various institutions.

7. know the role and impact of the Central bank as the main regulator in the domestic and international currency markets.

8. grasp the fundamentals of regulatory practices in the stock markets and the insurance markets.

Class Participation 20%
Mid-term and End-term assessments 30% each
Group Assignments and presentations 20%
Negative Marks will be awarded for plagiarism

data.name: Monetary Theory
data.html_details:
Overview

Why do we need this object called "money"? Is it simply because it is necessary to carry out trades? If so, then in our simplistic view of the world, money would be a constraint. What about alternative trading arrangements like barter or credit? This course starts with a micro-founded approach to money using an overlapping generations model and discusses why money is not a constraint but an instrument that arises endogenously leading to welfare gains for the economy. This course further discusses why money is welfare improving vis-a-vis barter or credit, why fiat money and not commodity money, and then we go on to study the relationship between money and other institutions that issue/ use money - financial intermediation & banks, a model of bank risk and bank panic (Diamond-Dybvig model), governments & national debt, fiscal theories of price level & inflation, pension systems, etc.

The simple baseline model that you will learn in this course is the overlapping generations model of money by economist Paul Samuelson (1958). As the year suggests, this is a pretty old model, however, it is a model that is quite insightful and at the same time accessible to undergraduates. There are other sophisticated frictional models of money that are beyond the reach of a typical undergraduate and are usually offered as a Master’s/PhD elective.

This course is not about bitcoin/ cryptocurrencies. The OLG model is not the best model to study these issues. For those really interested in economic models of cryptos and possess mathematical prowess, the suggested papers are Budish (NBER Working Paper, 2018), Huberman et al. (mimeo, 2019), and the research papers on the webpage of Bank of Canada’s fintech working group. These are beyond the scope of this course.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

  • You should have successfully completed (i.e. not failed/ withdrawn) your 2nd-year Micro-I, Macro-I & II core courses or equivalent.

References:

data.name: Critical Thinking Seminar: Caste Creativity
data.html_details:
Overview

In this course we will look at texts across genres – novels, short stories, essays, poetry, films – and ask the following questions: What do these texts tell us about caste? How do they erase caste while telling us something else? If caste isn’t explicitly mentioned, what are the tools we may use to understand the caste action at play? Is caste a religious issue? If it is, is it particular only to Hinduism? Can we read for caste only through the lens of identity? We will encounter texts that are immediately identifiable as dealing with issues concerning caste, and those that – with some prodding – show us the many insidious ways in which caste configures our lives. We will think about our own experiences with caste to inform our opinions of the texts we read, and learn to articulate them as cogent arguments across various writing exercises.

data.name: Critical Thinking Seminar: The Bhakt and Bhakti Literature
data.html_details:
Overview

“Bhakt” is a popular term in the current political landscape.This seminar works towards a deeper historical understanding of its meanings.Who is a bhakt and what is bhakti?Is it one idea or there are many bhaktis?Is there a particular literature that can be called the bhakti literature?What is the bhakti movement?Is bhakti complete and blind surrender? Or can it be an expression of dissent? To what extent is a bhakt’s devotion erotic?Is bhakti a gendered phenomena?We will mostly read poetry from the Indian medieval period, including writing by Janabai and Mirabai.

data.name: Introduction to Film
data.html_details:
Overview

This course introduces students to the fundamentals of film history, film analysis and film theory. The students will learn about different periods and movements in film history such as Early Cinema, German Expressionism, Soviet montage cinema, French Impressionism, Classical Hollywood, Italian neorealist cinema and the Iranian New Wave. The students will also learn about major theoretical approaches to the study of film with an emphasis on classical film theory debates. We will examine basic concepts of film form and study the methods of film analysis. Texts will include theoretical writings by Walter Benjamin, Siegfried Kracauer, Sergei Eisenstein, Andre Bazin, David Bordwell, Laura Mulvey, Gilles Deleuze and Tom Gunning. We will also be analyzing films by directors such as D.W.Griffith, Alice Guy-Blaché, Germaine Dulac, Robert Weine, Sergei Eisenstein, John Ford, Vittorio De Sica, Ritwik Ghatak, Yasujiro Ozu, Agnés Varda, Jean-Luc Godard and Abbas Kiarostami.

data.name: Studies in Law and Literature: Wrongful Convictions
data.html_details:
Overview

One of our most haunting legal dilemmas is an ethical question: what can we do about wrongful beliefs about others? In North America, it is well known that African Americans and indigenous peoples are over-represented in the figures of those who are wrongfully convicted. In a course that is transdisciplinary, we turn this sociological observation on its head by beginning with The Apology by Plato. Wrongful beliefs about others give rise to genres that are central to western civilization, such as apologias, justifications, confessions, and complaints. We will read “The Gospel of Matthew” and the work of René Girard to think about the problem of the scapegoat vs. the figure of sacrifice. Augustin and Rousseau will trouble how we understand uncoerced confession as the truth of our beings. Examining fictions by Nathaniel Hawthorne and Maryse Condé and real life witch hunt trials, we will see that since the soul is at issue in confession, the wrongfully convicted have become the flipside of victims. Caleb Williams will help us to understand that exonerees are the only ones who can understand victims. Aside from intellectual history, we will look at cases of wrongful conviction and level critiques of our own at present-day Innocence Projects. We will look to the work of Gayl Jones to explore the problem of representational excess, what it means to come to bear the burden of representation.

data.name: Studies in World Literatures
data.html_details:
Overview

Literature is an art of storytelling. But can storytelling bring about political revolutions? Is it possible for stories to stand up against colonial abuse, fight prejudices, bring social change, impact public policy? In this course, we will talk about stories that did exactly that and did it so spectacularly that generations have remained in awe of them. We will read novels, short stories, memoirs and essays to discover that each of these works of art were responsible for protesting against the political injustices of their times. And in doing so, they highlighted and gave voice to the wrongs and discriminations of today.At the heart of each of these stories, we will encounter a fierce rejection of dogma and a stubborn insistence to speak out.

data.name: The Ancient Novel
data.html_details:
Overview

This class covers the development of long-form prose fiction in Greece and Rome, what has been called the “ancient novel.”These novels, which are characterized by a fascination with love stories, travel, and questions of cultural, ethnic, class, and gender identity, are packed with exciting tales of shipwrecks, pirates, mistaken identities, and miraculous transformations. Taken together, they represent the expansiveness and diversity of the ancient Mediterranean world, with settings in Ethiopia, Egypt, Syria, Asia Minor, Greece, Italy, and journeys to the Arctic and the moon. We will read all the surviving ancient Greek and Roman novels, focusing on one per week: Chariton, Chaereas and Callirhoe, Xenophon, An Ephesian Tale, Achilles Tatius, Leucippe and Clitophon, Longus, Daphnis and Chloe, Heliodorus, Ethiopian Story, Pseudo-Lucian, Lucius, or, The Ass, Lucian, A True History, Apuleius, Metamorphoses, or, The Golden Ass, Petronius, Satyricon, and the epitomes of Antonius Diogenes, The Wonders Beyond Thule and Iamblichus, A Babylonian Story. Selections from literature which influenced the development of the Greco-Roman novel, such as Homer’s Odyssey, Euripides’ escape tragedies (Helen, Iphigeneia among the Taurians, and Andromeda), and paradoxography, examples of later reception, particularly in Byzantine adaptations of the 12th c., and relevant scholarship, will accompany these readings. In the final weeks of the class, we will compare the Greek and Roman novels to those of East Asia, reading selections from Murasaki Shikibu, The Tale of Genji (11th c.), Luo Guanzhong, Romance of the Three Kingdoms (14th c.) and Shi Naian, Water Margin (14th c.).

data.name: Staging the Orient in Early Modern England
data.html_details:
Overview

This course will consider the veritable obsession of Shakespeare and his contemporaries with the Orient – a capacious yet imprecise term that demarcates not just a geographical place (North Africa and Asia) and a religious location (the “Islamic” world) but also a set of over-the-top acting techniques (the histrionic “oriental” excess of the medieval cycle-drama Herod and the early modern Tamburlaine), a temporal relation (the Orient as an earlier “stage” that precedes the English present), and a political nightmare (the spectre of the idolatrous Oriental Despot). We will consider how “staging the Orient” is less about representing a real-world referent than it is a theatrical mode of geo-poesis – which is to say, it is literally globe-making (as the name of Shakespeare’s playhouse suggests). The early modern theatre functioned as a laboratory for England’s future projects of globalization, plotting modes of cultural and temporal relationality informed by various logics – outsourcing, extraction of surplus value, supersession, transnational accumulation – that are now part and parcel of the modern global economy. We will read a number of early modern plays (the Coventry Shearmen and Taylor’s pageant of Herod the Great, Thomas Preston’s Cambyses, Christopher Marlowe’s Tamburlaine, Robert Greene’s Selimus, Shakespeare’s Second Henriad, Day Wilkins and Rowley’s Travels of the Three English Brothers, Robert Daborne’s A Christian Turn’d Turk, Philip Massinger’s The Renegado, Shakespeare’s Antony and Cleopatra, Shakespeare’s The Tempest, John Fletcher’s Island Princess) as well as various other early modern writings engaged with or informed by theatre such as the antitheatricalist tracts of Stephen Gosson, William Prynne et al., and travel narratives about Persia and India by Thomas Roe and Thomas Coryate. We will also consider theoretical texts such as Edward Said’s Orientalism, Dipesh Chakrabarty’s Provincializing Europe, Alain Grosrichard’s In the Sultan’s Court, and Hegel’s Philosophy of History.

data.name: “Interesting” Narratives: Microhistories, It-Narratives, Anecdotes and Trifles
data.html_details:
Overview

Between 1975 and 1990, microhistories starting with Emmanuel Le Roy Ladurie’s Montaillou, followed by Carlo Ginzburg’s The Cheese and the Worms and Ecstasies, Natalie Zemon Davis’s The Return of Martin Guerre, Jonathan Spence’s The Question of Hu, and Robert Darnton’s The Great Cat Massacre and Other Episodes in French Cultural History, flourished, pre-dating the New Historicism within literary criticism. Yet these biographical case studies have a set of eighteenth-century literary and anthropological antecedents. Olaudah Equiano describes his “Interesting Narrative” as a “trifle,” also known as a false or idle tale. As John Bugg observes this kind of contingent tale expands in geopolitical register in the works of Daniel Defoe, “for whom trifles can center imperial exchange: one may “purchase … for Trifles … not only Gold Dust … Elephants Teeth, &c. but Negroes.” In a world in which slavery is legal, one person’s trifle is another person’s human being.” This course will explore a selection of secret histories, it-narratives, anecdotes, trifles, and animal tales that set the stage for understanding the role of conscious and animate personified things. We will think about the case form, scale, personhood, action, and identity.

data.name: The Global 1920s
data.html_details:
Overview

The 1920s are often portrayed as a watershed decade for cultural history generally, and modernism specifically.The story goes that the political realignments, social upheavals, and economic booms that followed the Great War all engendered an international blossoming of the arts.This course aims to question, trouble, and complicate this fundamentally Eurocentric outlook by rendering an expansive panorama of one decade of cultural history at a global scale.Providing only the nodes, students are asked to make their own connections over the course of the semester and map new intellectual reticulations.This course will feature a number of guest lectures.

data.name: Children’s Literature
data.html_details:
Office timing

Office Hours : T/Th 10.30 AM to 11:30 AM (and by appointment)

Overview

What we read as children forms who we become and provides our first world view. This course provides an opportunity to critically assess the stories that shaped our understanding of morals, culture, and values, as well as those we will impart to future generations. In this discussion-oriented interactive course, we will read and review children’s books, examine the purposes of visual literacy, and write reviews on specific authors and illustrators. We will write our own children’s book to gauge all that we have learnt.

This course aims to examine how the books children read shape their outlook and emotional development. We will study the historical, creative, nurturing, emotional, and educational aspects of these forms of literature and their impact on us later in life. We will also consider why a study of children’s literature is important, and how it impacts pedagogies for children across borders.

We will examine the views of multiple theoretical thinkers and texts in conjunction with actual children's literature. We will ask the important but often overlooked questions about this particular genre, mainly focusing on Indian and Western children’s literature. The purpose is not so much to compare these two cultural offerings, but to give us a taste of both.

We shall consider popular stories for children up to 12 years old, including Harry Potter & The Philosopher’s Stone, Amar Chitra Katha, Matilda, The Little Prince, Feluda and Mulan. At the same time, we will also study theoretical thinkers such as Jack Zipes, Seth Lerer, Paulo Freire, and Bruno Bettelheim to help us navigate the complex field of children’s literature in relation to issues of culture, religion, difference, gender, and sexuality.

We will unpack the didactic intent as well as the pleasure principle that might have prompted the writers. Authorial intent is, however, only one part of our study; the other part is to see how children and parents receive these stories. Children’s literature creates moral as well as national frameworks that help acculturate young people. In examining the genre of children’s literature, we will consider various sub-genres such as picture books, fairy tales, fables, and chapter books.

Learning Outcomes

1. The importance of Children's Literature in the growth and development of children.

2. Some knowledge of theorists of children's literature.

3. Close readings of chilldrens literature.

4. To see how the theories work with the literature.

5. The thought processes that go into writing and illustrating a story for children.

6. The value of illustrations.

7. The role of Disney in expanding children's literature.

data.name: Violence and South Asian Literature
data.html_details:
Overview

How should we be thinking about a concept as elusive as violence? What is the relation between thinking and violence? What do South Asian literary texts teach us about violence? What is nonviolence? These are some of the questions that will guide our thinking about the question of violence in South Asian literatures. The course will introduce the students to modern South Asian literary texts that think about violence. We will focus not only on texts dealing with war, riots, torture and other forms of physical violence but also on those processes of slow—and intangible—violence that have come to define collective and individual life in South Asia. We will situate key texts, authors and genres from different regional languages in a wider historical context of political violence in South Asia. We will be reading literary texts by Intizar Hussain, Mohan Rakesh, Mahasweta Devi, Nirmal Verma, Ajay Navaria, Waryam Singh Sandhu, Indira Goswami, Akhtar Mohiuddin, Temsula Ao and Michael Ondaatjee. We will also be reading key theoretical texts on the question of violence by Carl Schmitt, Hannah Arendt, Walter Benjamin, Franz Fanon, M. K. Gandhi, Judith Butler and Jacques Derrida. We will also be screening and discussing films by Ritwik Ghatak, Govind Nihalani, Gulzar and Sudhir Mishra among others.

Learning Outcomes

This course aims to equip students with the tools, understanding, and practice needed to read, analyze, and compare theoretical and empirical market models; and while doing so, helping them appreciate and criticize important and recent findings in the field of Industrial Organization.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

data.name: Decision Theory
data.html_details:
Overview

The objective of the course is a thorough engagement with the project of rationality as understood in economics using the methodological perspective of decision theory. Setting up the exercise in decision-theoretic terms has the advantage of disciplining us to make our claims in terms of (in principle) observable behavior. The course will begin by laying out what the substantive content of rationality in neo-classical economics entails, along with an appreciation of the “genealogy” of this concept. This discussion will also focus on the Bayesian paradigm and the foundations of subjective probabilities, which are key organizing principles when we talk about rationality in environments featuring uncertainty. After that, we will look at the criticisms of rational choice theory. We will then focus on a set of topics and themes proposed as responses to some of the limitations of rational choice theory. Amongst them, prominent themes and questions include:

1. Rational choice theory is too narrowly focused on the outcome of choices and doesn’t pay enough attention to the decision-making procedure by which those choices are arrived at. By ignoring these procedural aspects of decision making, the theory ignores important details like cognitive limitations that decision-makers are faced with when making choices. We will, therefore, want to think about approaches that take these procedural aspects of decision-making more seriously.

2. In keeping with our search for descriptively richer accounts of behavior, we will delve into the heuristics and biases program of Kahneman and Tversky. In this context, we will also discuss dual-process theories of cognition.

3. We will discuss Kahneman and Tversky’s Prospect theory and the paradigm of reference-dependent preferences, more generally. We will ask, just like they did all those years ago, as to what the “true carriers of value are”?

4. Neo-classical economics takes individual preferences as exogenous and given. But, in many contexts, aren’t preferences endogenous? Aren’t things like identity-based preferences, say, sexist preferences or casteist preferences, socially constituted and not exogenous? If so, how should we go about theorizing endogenous preferences? What about social influence and how it shapes our preferences and choices?

5. What about decision-making in social and political contexts? Do the same principles underlying decision-making in a more “private” context carry over seamlessly to them? Are the fundamental decision-theoretic insights with which we analyze people’s consumption decisions adequately when analyzing, say, their voting decisions?

Grading Rubric

1. Class participation (20%)

2. Midterm (25%)

3. Final (25%)

4. Group assignments and research-related tasks (30%)

Attendance Policy

Regular attendance is a necessary (although not sufficient) condition for scoring well in the 20% of the grade assigned to class participation. I do not do asynchronous teaching, although I do post lecture videos. Regular attendance is vital for you to do well in this course. I expect that you will attend all lectures and take responsibility for coming to them prepared. Regular attendance will be taken in all classes. Unexcused absences (apart from those necessitated by health reasons or other emergencies) are strongly discouraged. If you feel that you won't be able to attend the synchronous lectures because of a scheduling conflict, you should not take the course.

Overview

VA 4001-1 Methods in Art History

Course Level 4000

Course Specifics: Compulsory/ Gateway course for students pursuing Undergraduate (ASP) Capstone thesis or Maters (MLS) Thesis in Visual Arts, especially Art History.

Prerequisites: The course is restricted to students pursuing ASP Capstone thesis or MLS Thesis in Visual Arts. It is open for credit or audit to graduate studies or masters students from other disciplines who have completed a 3000 level course in Art History and interested in research methods in Art History for their thesis.

Course Description

This course introduces theories and methods of art history that have played a major role in its intellectual and professional formation of the discipline. From the pre-disciplinary cusp of Vasari and artistic biographies in the Renaissance, the course will explore the origins of art historical scholarship in the eighteenth century, and then touch on a wide range of subsequent approaches, including Marxist, feminist, and post-colonial interpretations of art. The course approaches the discipline of art history as an archival mediated site of cultural critique and construction. Special attention will be given to the adequacy of established art-historical paradigms of formal, stylistic, and iconographic analysis in dealing with the “expanded field” of visual studies. Keeping the mind the research interests of students, the course will introduce them to various ways of reading archival traces and sources beyond the North Atlantic context and problematize the professional structure of art history and visual studies as an increasingly “globalized” mode of inquiry.

Learning Outcomes

The course is designed to help MLS and ASP Capstone students in Visual Arts develop their research skills for writing their ASP Capstone or MLS thesis in Art History.
