Overview

Course Description:

This course focuses on the Himalayan regions of Ladakh, Himachal Pradesh and Tibet to understand how art, material and ritual cultures are intrinsically connected with the idea of ‘place’. How did the field of ‘Himalayan Art’ emerge? Where do we ‘locate’ this field; which geographical areas and religions are made emblematic of this discipline; which cultures are excluded and why? The course will examine how places, cultures and people are constructed through representations—visual and written—both by ‘outsiders’ as well as local communities. Students will engage with critical questions about the ethics of representation in imaging ‘other’ places and people, the political and social processes that inform the making of ‘tradition’, and the entanglements of politics and culture in the formation of regional and national identities.

Methodologically, the course will explore a wide archive of material from the 10th century to contemporary times. It will include colonial and contemporary photography, travel accounts, art historical writing, temple and monastery sites, performative rituals, museum displays, films and representations in popular culture. A key area of study will be major museum collections of Himalayan art. How were these collections built and in what historical circumstances? What curatorial strategies are used to reconstruct the sacred auras of objects? How are objects of worship segregated into categories of art and ethnographic things? How is culture constructed through acts of museumisation? The course will examine the recent museum-making impulse in the Himalayas through case studies of a range of museums situated in these borderlands — war memorial museums, community museums of conflict and trade route artifacts, and museums in Buddhist monasteries to understand the relationship between heritage and religion, the impact of the movement of things from sacred sites to ‘secular’ museums, and to ask how a politics of remembrance may manifest in cultural production. The course will conclude with an introduction to contemporary Tibetan art and Tibetan Buddhist culture-in-exile.

Modules:

Constructing ‘Place’: hierarchy, difference and chronopolitics

Colonial Encounters in the Western Himalayas

Writing a Region: Travel Accounts from the 18th to the 20th centuries

Colonial photography in the Himalayas: Representation and its Uses

Tibetan Cultural spheres and Contemporary Photography

Material Culture in situ: Ritual uses, ‘display’ and decay, photographs as sacred objects

‘Collecting Tibet’: Younghusband and the British Expedition of 1903-04

Museum collections of Himalayan Art: Making ritual objects into art, knowledge production through framing, display and texts.

‘Other’ museums: monastery museums, trade route artifact museums, war memorial museums by the State and the community.

Tibetan Culture-in-Exile

Contemporary Tibetan Art in Tibet and the Diaspora

Course Deliverables:

The course will consist of illustrated lectures and seminars in which active participation will be expected of students. Readings for each seminar class will be assigned beforehand. We will also view a small selection of films, and read short travel essays and discuss these critically to understand the construction of place, people and culture through image making and text.

Students will:

  • Write a critical report on a film/exhibition/text (1000 words)
  • Curate an exhibition (digitally) and make a presentation
  • Write an essay (2000-2500 words)
Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students:

  • will be familiar with the broad field of the visual and material cultures in the Himalayas as well as major art-historical sites in Ladakh and Himachal Pradesh.
  • will learn about major museums and collections of Himalayan Art and be able to critically analyze the framing of objects as art/ ethnography.
  • will be conversant with critical questions around ‘heritage’, the politics of museums and the role of ‘tradition’ in the construction of contemporary cultural identities.
  • will acquire the critical tools interrogate the nature and impact of ‘representation’ of regions, cultures and communities in images, writing and art history.
  • will be able to critically ‘read’ images and texts, with a focus on meaning making through vocabularies and terminologies, and ‘apply’ this critical thinking through a practical curatorial project.

data.name: Caves: Surfaces, Shrines, Art, Architecture
data.html_details:
Office timing

Class Schedule: Thursday and Friday: 2.50-4.20 p.m.

Office Hours: Friday: 1.30-2.30 p.m.

Overview

Course Overview:

As natural geological formations, caves provided humans with the earliest surfaces for leaving behind enduring visual accounts. Their status between ‘nature’ and ‘culture,’ meant that they have long been associated with sacred spaces in Buddhism, Jainism and Hinduism. They also serve as a large corpus of art and architectural histories. While hugely labour-, time- and capital-intensive, what made caves popular across religious and political formations, and for a large period of human history? Delving into this, and allied questions, the proposed course will promote engagement with the histories of rock-cut art and architecture from the South Asian Subcontinent. Reflecting on the foundational relationship, between caves and the discipline of art history, students will deepen their understanding of issues of iconography, the relationship between religion, art and architecture, religious and philosophical formations such as monastic orders and their impact upon stylistic changes, artistic patronage and royal power, etc.

The course envisions advancing two tracks of study, viz. chronology and thematic concerns. The chronological component will introduce students to key sites and the attendant questions of architectural and iconographic developments. The sites considered will include: Bhimbetka, Lomas Rishi cave, Khandagiri/Udayagiri, Karle, Bhedsa, Kanheri, Ajanta, Badami, Elephanta, Mamallapuram, Ellora, among others.

Thematic concerns will include: historical methods and the ‘discovery’ of sites, the role of caves in fashioning neo-revivalist projects (e.g. Ajanta murals’ constitutive role in forging an ‘Indian’ visual language) and as spaces of artistic transmission, through long-term 19th century projects such as the copying of its murals. Underscoring the many lives of these sites, one theme explored will be the conversion of cave shrines into ‘monuments’ under colonial governance and the consequent impact upon questions of public access; Elephanta in western India will be considered as a case-study. Taken together, these case studies and themes will equip students to carry out iconographic, historiographic and critical analyses of Indian art history.

Learning Outcomes

At the end of the course, students will learn:

  • Key art historical skills, such as the reading of architectural plans, holistic analysis of sites, analyzing primary sources such as field reports and a close-study of images and iconography.
  • The process of building a ‘context’ for reading images by developing questions around iconography, historiography and socio-political developments.
  • A historically informed understanding of human interactions with the landscape and natural formations, and learning to problematize the nature/culture binary.
  • The ability to develop new, independent research pathways in disciplines such as art history, anthropology, sociology, religious studies, etc.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Preliminary Reading List:

  • Brown, P. (1956). Indian Architecture, Bombay: D.B. Taraporevala and Sons.
  • Spink, W. (1958). On the Development of Early Buddhist Art in India. The Art Bulletin, 40(2), 95-104. doi:10.2307/3047760
  • Tarr, G. (1970). Chronology and Development of the Cha?ukya Cave Temples. Ars Orientalis, 8, 155-184. http://www.jstor.org/stable/4629258
  • Mitter, P. (1977). Much Maligned Monsters: History of European Reactions to Indian Art. Oxford: Clarendon Press.
  • (1994). Art and Nationalism in Colonial India: Occidental Orientations. New York: Cambridge University Press.
  • Dhaky, M.A. & Meister, M. W. (1983 – 1999). Encyclopedia of Temple Architecture, Vols. 1-10. New Delhi: American Institute of Indian Studies. [selected sections]
  • Huntington, S. & Huntington, J. (1985). The Art of Ancient India: Buddhist, Hindu, Jain. Boston: Weather Hill.
  • Michell, G. (1990). The Penguin Guide to the Monuments of India. vol. 1, Buddhist, Jain, Hindu. New Delhi: Penguin.
  • Willis, M. (2009). The Archaeology of Hindu Ritual: Temples and the Establishment of the Gods. New York: Cambridge University Press.
  • Brancaccio, P. (2013). Living Rock. Buddhist, Hindu and Jain Cave Temples in the Western Deccan. Mumbai: Marg Publications.
  • Singh, U. (2004). The Discovery of Ancient India: Early Archaeologists and the Beginnings of Archaeology. Ranikhet: Permanent Black.
  • Guha-Thakurta, T.(2004). Monuments, Objects, Histories: Institutions of Art in Colonial and Postcolonial India. New York: Columbia University Press.
  • Lahiri, N. (2015). Marshalling the Past: Ancient India and Its Modern Histories. Ranikhet: Permanent Black.
  • Guha, S. (2015). Artefacts of History: Archaeology, Historiography and Indian Pasts. New Delhi: Sage Publications.
Grading Rubric

Course Deliverables:

  • Mid-semester presentation, accompanied by a report (Word Limit: 1000 words)
  • End semester research paper, between 2000-2500 words, including footnotes, bibliography.

The course follows a continuous assessment mode with class participation carrying 10% of the credit as we read plans, identify images, iconographic departures, architectural innovation, and critically read texts.
In the first assignment, which will serve as mid-term evaluation, students will be expected to choose a site, theme, motif, to make a class presentation on the same. This needs to be accompanied by a report of a maximum 1000 words. Presentations are key for demonstrating your grasp over the subject as well as your critical reading of multiple sources. Each student will have approximately ten to fifteen minutes to make their presentation, and respond to questions/comments— this is a chance for the class to engage with your research. Together with the report, this presentation carries 40% of the credits.
In the second assignment students will choose to respond to one question out of two; these will be questions relating to methodology and/or historiography. Alternatively, they may develop a curatorial concept for a curated walk-through a specific site; issues of conservation will need to be taken into account, and site-specific solutions will have to be advanced.

Attendance Policy

Two absences are permitted. However, being absent on the day/s of presentation will result in a grade-cut.

data.name: Non-Fiction Comics
data.html_details:
Office timing

12 noon to 5 pm

Overview

Course Description:

In an era which some commentators have described as the ‘golden age of the documentary’, comics – particularly non-fiction comics - have emerged as a persuasive new form of narrative art situated at the intersection of the visual, the textual, the spatial and the temporal. This course is designed to lead students through an overview of the history, semiotics and structures of comics to the techniques and methods of researching and creating non-fiction comics.

The course will have theory and practice components. We will engage in reading and writing as well as drawing from life, taking photographs, collaging, tracing and digital image-making and manipulation. It is a project based course, and while each student will be required to complete an individual project, they will also be encouraged to interact/collaborate and share skillsets and resources with each other as far as possible.

Course Modules:

The course is divided broadly into two parts. In the first part (4 weeks), students will be introduced to some seminal works from the global and Indian comics universe – spanning various kinds of non-fiction genres, including documentary, history/oral history, witness accounts, biography/autobiography, reportage and commentary. The selection of works for study and discussion will be curated rather than extensive. For example, Art Speigelman’s Maus will be explored in conjunction with Keiji Nakagawa’s Barefoot Gen – the remarkable parallels of subject matter of both works contrasted with their sharp divergence of perspective providing a perfect opportunity for comparative readings of the different forms, styles, techniques, narrative devices and approaches of the artists. Similarly, the experimental Bhimayana – the graphic biography of B.R.Ambedkar, could be paired with the more conventionally structured Gandhi by Campfire comics. The presentations will be discussion-based and participatory. The examination of master works will provide the opportunity to delve below the surface and understand the governing principles and fundamental architecture of comics in general, while also noting the medium’s constantly evolving nature.

The second part of the course (9 weeks) will be practice oriented, focusing particularly on research as practice, and will be conducted in three stages.

1. Students will be asked to select an area of interest related to their concerns or engagements – for instance, the ongoing farmer’s protests at the Delhi borders. After developing an initial understanding of the background, the student will be encouraged to research and document the visual landscape of the protest sites – from tractors to tents, charpais to kitchens, the fields, trees and seasons, the implements of protest. Mundane objects and precious objects, the faces, expressions and body languages of resistance will all become worthy subjects of the artist’s gaze. Art research breaches boundaries of sociology, anthropology, history and geography, and its methods and tools are also cross disciplinary. Students will be required to use live drawing, photography and note taking, supplemented with audio and video recording. This kind of work sharpens the skills of close, empathetic observation and engagement. It also builds and strengthens visual memory and vocabulary – the bedrock of all visual art practice. At the same time, the student will be asked to seek out and record the stories, opinions and voices of the protestors. This will simultaneously need to be backed up with secondary research from blogs, social media sites and other sources such as the farmer run publication Trolley Times. While the research process is often proactive and investigative, students will be encouraged to integrate periods of absorbtion/reflection – of becoming still and listening, seeing – acts of deep witnessing. These are also the pauses that allow for the internalization and distillation of experience, which is so crucial to an artist’s process of creative transformation.

2. The next stage will involve the process of cataloguing and consolidating the collected material/evidence and the sorting, classifying and discerning of patterns. The student will identify key visual and narrative elements, extract details and begin shaping a graphic script based on images and texts. At this stage, the imagination will come into play - through brainstorming, lateral thinking and ideating. This may also involve group presentations and feedback sessions. Discussions on the continuities and disruptions of text and image relationships, the rythms of time and space in sequential images, page composition, layouts, pagination and other formal and structural elements of the comics medium will return – but now within the specific frame of the narrative at hand . The first draft of the student’s visual story will result at the end of this.

3. The final stage will be devoted to the execution of the stories in the form of a 10 to 12 page work. Aspects of media, technique, style, skill and finish will be discussed alongside. Each student will be required to produce an individual project and encouraged to adopt techniques best suited to their individual approaches and intentions. Collaborative sharing of skill sets and resources will be encouraged.

Learning Outcomes

Learning Objectives:

At the end of the course, students will have developed the capacity to research, interpret, narrate and create comics stories on any subject that is of interest to them. They will have grasped the essentials of graphic strategies and techniques, and have the ability to conceptually handle text, image, time and space in ways that are relevant to conceptualising visual narratives of all kinds.

Course Deliverables:

One completed non-fiction comic of at least 12 pages length - publishable as a stand-alone work in the format of a Zine or as part of an anthology of comics.

data.name: The Body in Indian Modernity
data.html_details:
Overview

Taught by Navtej Singh Johar

This course will view the body through the lens of Indian embodied practices. Beginning with a brief study of pre-modern texts, both body-dismissive and body-reliant, the course will look into the introduction and assimilation of Western puritanism into the advocacy, pedagogy and practice of yoga and dance. It will closely trace the reconstructive processes of these practices that were adapted by leading Reformers from the mid-19th to early-20th centuries that led to the redefinition of the body and its focus within modern India. But apart from these shifts in definition, the course, in addition, will closely observe the covert switching of the "lens" through which both the body and history have come to be viewed in our times. A somatic training influenced by both yoga and dance will also be part of this course. No prerequisites required.

data.name: History and Memory - from Alexander to Gandhi

Overview

Course Description: The course aims to analyze the many meanings that make history and memory intelligible. What is history? How does memory work? Is memorialization selective or inclusive? These are some of the questions that will be examined through an exploration of some iconic persona and phenomena. On the one hand, three famous personalities will be explored – Alexander the Great, Emperor Ashoka and Mahatma Gandhi – in order to understand the elements that form the title of this course. On the other hand, the phenomena of war will be examined ranging from Massada in the Middle East to the American-Vietnam War in Southeast Asia in order to explore the contested terrain of history and memory. Apart from reading the works of historians, the course will involve analysing excerpts from literature and films.

Note: All reading material will be emailed to students.

data.name: China’s First Historian: Sima Qian and the Records of the Grand Historian
Wealth and Inequality in China  (1500 to the present)
data.html_details:
Overview

Among the most vivid images of China’s modern history have been the extremes of decadent imperial courts and starving peasants. China’s sixteenth-century commercial revolution, in the context of the growing international trade in silver, transformed social and cultural life in every corner of society. Since then, arguments about the distribution of resources and the proper remedy for inequality have been central to political and social movements, especially during the twentieth century. In this course we will examine the economic bases of income inequality in Chinese history, investigate strategies Chinese governments and individuals have used to mitigate rural and urban poverty, and come to appreciate how these economic realities affected people at all levels of Chinese society. Wealth and poverty were experienced differently according to factors including (but not limited to) gender, age, level of education, disability, sexuality, ethnicity, and location. We will read primary sources which illuminate a wide range of perspectives and consider, in conversation with the secondary literature, how to synthesise these materials.

data.name: Prose Fiction Workshop
data.html_details:
Overview

" Prose Fiction Workshop" to be taught by Professor Amit Chaudhuri in a slightly unusual format. It will be an 8 day workshop that meets for 3 1/2 hours each day - 4 days on a stretch, a day's break, and then again for 4 days starting from 16th August till 25th August.

The eight-day course is designed to hone the skills of writers who already have a fair amount of competence in writing. It is also designed to encourage a discussion and conversation about the craft of writing and about critical and imaginative concerns. It is modelled on the Prose Fiction MA in Creative Writing at the University of East Anglia, and workshops will comprise a mix of detailed feedback on the participants’ samples of writing general critical discussion. The eight-day UEA India international workshop , which serves as a precursor to this one and took place annually from 2013-17 in Calcutta, helped identify and nurture the skills of some of India’s most interesting new writers who then went on to get published by major publishers in India.

The course should enable the student to do at least two things: first, to develop a piece of writing that they are currently working on in response to workshop discussion and tutorial feedback, and initiate a new piece of work; second, to reflect upon their own work and those of other participants in a wider literary and cultural context.

During the first four days, three participants will each submit, in alphabetical order, a 2,000-word sample of a piece of non-fiction – either new work or extracts from or examples of ongoing work. Samples they may have handed in earlier with their application shouldn’t be submitted for the workshop.

These will be read and discussed in detail by other students in the class for three to three and a half hours. The workshop tutor will offer their thoughts on each of the pieces too, as well as bring into the discussion relevant critical ideas if they think this appropriate. All students will have had their 2,000-word samples discussed by the end of the fourth day.

Each day, after the workshop, the tutor will have a one-to-one meeting with the three

students who have been workshopped earlier that day. This will be a focused tutorial on their submission lasting thirty minutes each – so a total of one and a half hours.

There will be no workshop on the fifth day.

During the second cluster of four days, participants will bring to the table a short 1500-word piece that they have written during the course of the workshop. This piece may be a response to a text handed out earlier in the workshop. The pattern of workshopping and tutorials established in the first four days will be repeated exactly.

Participants are encouraged to make detailed notes about other participants’ works, which they should respond to thoughtfully, constructively, and in detail. Criticism of samples is welcome as long as it is constructive. The introduction of critical and intellectual concepts to the discussion is welcome too, as long as it is pertinent to the discussion, and to issues and questions raised by the work being discussed.

The evening sessions and other activities will give participants the opportunity to engage with the tutor. Amit Chaudhuri will discuss his new books, Finding the Raga and Ramanujan, during a two-hour interaction with students. A separate one-hour interaction will involve a talk by a writer invited to speak at the workshop by Professor Chaudhuri.

data.name: Critical Thinking Seminar: The Spoken and the Sung: Exploring Orality
data.html_details:
Overview

In this course, we will be looking at the world of storytelling beyond the textual and written, and specifically at those that are "spoken" and "sung". It is crafted around the belief that to be a good writer one must be a good listener. Oral storytelling traditions, old as language itself, still live on, despite colonial encounters, and their dismissal of these "fickle" traditions for script. We will touch on the oral and landscape, memory, history, identity, and complex knowledge system, all of which feed into the focus of this course: forms of storytelling. From the Indian epics to the songlines in Australia, dastangoi to Bob Dylan, oral creation myths to modern-day stand-up comedy, spoken poetry to podcasts—the course seeks to ask what can we learn from the oral, the unwritten, as practitioners of creative writing? How can our creative practice be enlarged and enriched by attuning ourselves to the "sound" of stories?

Overview

Credits: 4

Open to: All students across UG, PG, and graduate studies.

Introduction

The objective of ‘Elementary Sanskrit-I’ is to introduce interested learners to basic Sanskrit grammar.

The word 'Sanskrit' is synonymous with a continuous trail of intellectual traditions in language and literature which includes vedas, vedangas, epics, puranic traditions, etc. These intellectual traditions serve as storehouse of knowledge that waits to be decoded and explored which is precisely why they intrigue researchers even today. For example, there is a revived interest in scientific interpretation of the Vedas to exploit encoded methodologies of agriculture harvesting, linguistic analysis, and other similar areas. Institutions working in applied research in Indian psychology study and interpret the Sanskrit texts based on yoga. Similarly, Paninian grammar and formalisms have gained the particular interest of computational linguists and artificial intelligence researchers. In other words, Sanskrit language and literature serve to provide a glimpse to the future while joining dots from the past.

Reading, writing and comprehension abilities in Sanskrit are essential for undertaking any of the aforementioned or related work in the language and this course teaches grammar from elementary/beginner level to pave way for developing the aforementioned abilities.

Learning Outcomes

The course will guide students to learn Sanskrit from the basic building blocks of grammar to some standard concepts in sentence formation and comprehension. After successful completion of the course, students will be able to read, write and understand basic sentences in Sanskrit.

data.name: Varieties of Regional (State) Politics
data.html_details:
Overview

This course aims to introduce students to select issues in Indian politics. Conventionally the centre or the so-called national has been the vantage point for the study of Indian politics. This course, however, takes a different path. First, it turns the spotlight away from the centre to the states. Second, it uses a comparative lens as the framework for analysis.

The view from the centre not only masks key differences among states but sometimes gives us an inappropriate picture when the features and characteristics of certain regions become characteristic of India. At the same time, this course does not intend to emphasise the distinct nature of individual states and focus on state-specific stories. Subnational comparisons give us the right balance between the “all-India” and the particular and thus enrich our understanding of political phenomena.

The course will underscore the usefulness of subnational comparative analysis to study issues like economic policymaking, party strategy, ethnic conflict management, leadership styles and dynastic politics among others.

Overview

This course looks at the Indian ‘state’ – its history, components, problems and opportunities. The ‘state’ is a key concept in political science, and we begin with theories of state formation – world over and in colonial and newly independent India. We then look at the design and capacity of the Indian state – both at the top (in Delhi) as well as the bottom (how does the state in an Indian village look like?). We will then study problems of state and bureaucratic capacity, the role of the state in providing public goods such as education and health, as well as in transforming Indian society.

Learning Outcomes

At the heart of this course are the compulsory readings – around 50 pages a class. You will read theories of state formation, as well as practical case studies of state failure (‘Why have some many children died in a Gorakhpur hospital?’) and attempts to reform the state (‘Are AAP’s primary education reforms in Delhi working’?). You will also study the Indian state at the top (‘How does Parliament function?’) as well as at the bottom (‘What does a Block Development Officer do?’). I guarantee you fun readings, and the total freedom to choose any viewpoint or ideological position -- including (and especially) those that are opposed to mine.

Overview

Inquiries into science studies, animal rights, and climate change are building up the foundations of a ‘new political’ in our times. This theorizing and the charge
of the ‘new political’ is co-evolving with capitalism as it intensifies its extractive relationship to nature. The planet can well do without us humans, but it is rather our survival that is contingent both on living and non-living nature. We now seek to remake the political: we postulate rights of non-human nature; we deliberate the agency of matter (such as machines, for instance); and reckon with precarity as the earth’s present condition. The ongoing attempts at reforming politics are not without ifs and buts... and so we shall look into the continuing force of inclusions by legacy and troubling exclusions.

data.name: Economy, Politics and Society
data.html_details:
Overview

Faculty - Saptrishi Mukherjee

The design of social institutions (e.g., marriage, property rights, electoral systems, markets) and the way they function matter to every facet of our lives. Often, the outcomes depend on what game theorists call `strategic' behaviour. This is just saying that our actions and choices are made keeping in mind the actions and choices of others. For instance, my decision to be a good citizen (in class, in life) may well depend on similar decisions by others. The outcome (e.g., pollution, global warming, traffic congestion, the spread of Covid) is the aggregate of each of these micro-decisions. Clearly these can be good or bad. Indeed, very often they are bad despite well intentioned policies. Why is that?

In this course we aim to introduce multi-agent interactions using game theory. We will follow an example-based approach where intuitive reasoning would be provided to explain various phenomena as mentioned earlier. This would illuminate why co-operation can be hard and when it can be sustained. We will discuss, using examples, how one can circumvent the problem of inefficiency led by strategic interactions. Several applications from market and institution design such as voting, auctions and matching will be discussed. Further, it is interesting to model some of the observable characteristics in the biological kingdoms as strategic interactions. For instance, consider oak trees in a wood shading each other. If the surrounding trees are tall, then a tree must also grow tall to get more light. We will discuss how modeling such observations as games helps us understand evolutionary outcomes in phenotypic terms

Grading will be based on the three exams. Each exam will account for the one third of the final grade.

data.html_details:
Overview


Welcome to “Auditory & Temporal Cognition”! This course will: take you on a journey deep into the human central auditory system, its structure and functions, ranging from simple pitch discrimination to rhythm perception, and all the way up to language and music processing, the two most sophisticated “end uses” of auditory cognition. We will also cover about the related dysfunctions, including developmental and neurological ones, with one specific focus on rhythm and timing in the human brain as the basis for music, language - and even movement.
We will start with the inner ear and move on into the brain, along the ascending auditory pathway, discover specialisation of the relevant brain structures, learn about the role of expertise (e.g. musicianship) and go full circle by touching on predictions and top-down projections.
Each of the lectures will in the following session be complemented by presentations and critical discussion of related articles of your choice, which will range from relevant classical studies to hot-of-the-press ones.

data.name: Thinking with Things
data.html_details:
Overview

Things are us. Things are the material stuff that we can touch, smell and feel. Things can show and recall a point of view. They can figure as non-tactile hyper-objects, such as the internet, or move us as embodied signs and symbols. Things turn amazingly into thinking tools shaped and reshaped by social context and perspective. Things are storied, thought-laden, and plentiful. And so we have to cherry-pick things that have been unravelled for us by a venerable, anthropological canon ( the sacred totem; money). And delve into contemporary thing theories about new things (mobile phones; visual images), the thingness of discarded objects (waste; hair), and touch on the production and seduction of things in our times. People do and think such extraordinary thinks with things!

Overview

The Calculus is a major achievement of humanity without which none of the developments in modern science, technology would have been possible. The course is a second look at the subject. It is an introduction to mathematics. It is about building the intuition, knowledge and skills required for studying mathematics and other mathematical subjects. It is an `enabling' course.

We will follow and read from Spivak's book, which has been described as the `best book on Calculus ever written'. If you read this book, and do many of the problems, you will learn what mathematics is all about, and be prepared to embark upon a scientific or mathematical career.

Mathematics is learnt by doing mathematics. Be prepared for a lot of doing. In addition to lectures and discussion sessions, expect to spend 8-10 hours outside of class every week working on the material.

The Syllabus is as follows:

Number systems. Sequences and series. Functions of a real variable. Graphs of functions. Limits and continuity. Differentiation. Mean value theorem. L’Hospital rule. Maclaurin and Taylor series. Curve tracing. Riemann integral. Definite and indefinite integrals. Fundamental theorem of calculus. Applications of differential and integral calculus in areas such as optimisation and mechanics.

Other than the above, there are many things in Spivak's book that we will discuss.

Overview

Documentary Film Script and Synopsis | Life at Ashoka through the Pandemic

The main theme of this film is to explore the stories of students at Ashoka University who choose to continue to live on campus due to exceptional domestic circumstances. Primarily, the film delves into their backgrounds and encompasses the variety of reasons which prompt these students to reside at Ashoka instead of going back home to their families.

However, I would not like to limit it to merely their stories and also explore some of the challenges they face living in a closed environment (like that of campus currently) for exceptionally long periods. Potentially, we could explore the ways they have engaged themselves, how they have developed relationships with people around them, etc. Ideally, I would like to boil it down to whether they prefer living at Ashoka or if it’s their only choice.

Here are some questions to further clarify the ideas behind this film…

(1) Why is this film being made?

The purpose of this film is twofold…

(a) The primary motive here is to give these students a voice. It essentially aims to help them by giving them a platform to speak up. Especially, in the case of students who belong to a background where they have been emotionally/physically abused. Hopefully, by providing them with a platform, we’ll be able to help them be more proud of the challenges they are rising through.

(b) There is a notion within the Ashokan Community that the administration is not empathetic enough towards its students. Thus, by voicing these issues, it can potentially be a way to appeal to the admin to further help such students, not only current ones but in the future as well.

(2) Who is the targeted audience and what should their reaction to the film be? The primary Target Audience definitely would definitely be the Ashokan Community. However, if this film turns out well, it could have a great impact. There is no expected reaction that I am considering. However, by the end of this film, we aim for more people to recognise the challenges of Remote Learning especially for those who do not have the privilege of a conducive household. At the same time, for more privileged viewers, maybe they will actually be cognizant of what they have.

(3) What will be the film’s technical conditions of use and style of this film?

I plan to make this film a combination of direct interviews, paired with montage sequences of the characters as well as stock shots pertinent to the relevant storyline. Ideally, I would like to use ‘actuality’ (having characters enact things that are intrinsic to them) and ‘wallpaper technique’ (usage of pictures to profile the characters of the movie) to use as the visuals for the film. Additionally, stock shots of the movie would be based on the interviews we record. For example, if someone tells us that one of the challenges they faced living here was the food, we could have a shot of the mess, so on and so forth.

The Characters

To make this documentary authentic, we would like to screen people and get to know them off-camera before interviewing them. This will help us get to know how comfortable they are sharing their stories and to what extent they would like to share. It would also help us to explain our purpose behind making this film in the first place. I would like to put out a casting call and screen the interviewees/characters of this film during the first week (see week by week breakup).

The Storyline

This is a brief storyline for the film,

(a) Initially, the storyline would seek to profile our characters and have the audience get to know them and where they come from. I would like to keep this as brief as possible. (b) Then we delve deeper into the challenges they have faced in life and explore the reason(s) which prompt them to stay here.

(c) After that, I would like to explore the challenges of living at Ashoka - this can encompass a variety of reasons but we would like to essentially centre it in the context of the Ashoka Administration.

(d) I would like to conclude this film with positive reinforcement of these characters and to portray them as potential changemakers of affirmative action.

Learning Outcomes

DEVELOPMENT: turn your idea into a workable script, storyboard and schedule.

PRODUCTION: develop skills to shoot original short documentary films and turn a zero-to-low budget to your advantage.

POST-PRODUCTION: learn basic editing techniques to enhance your original idea using iMovie, Premiere and other popular tools.

Grading Rubric

A weekly report of assignments through the semester will be an ascending base of developing skills in seeing, making a media product and maintaining a proper record of the process.

Attendance Policy

Weekly Update

Week by Week Tentative Schedule

Week 1: Casting Calls, Screening and finalising people for interviews, Finalising color palettes for the film.

Week 2 and Week 3: Finalising initial script for the movie, start conducting interviews. Week 4 and Week 5: Analysing content acquired through interviews and filming stock shots for the same.

Week 6 and Week 7: First round editing, will go over the script and conduct another round of interviews based on feedback and analysis of original interviews.

Week 8 onwards: Post Production

Bombay cinema, affectionately called “Bollywood” has become the background music to our lives, whether as innocent entertainment or ‘time pass’. However we often overlook Bollywood’s serious intent and its strong ideological underpinnings. Right from its inception, with Dadasaheb Phalke’s Raja Harishchandra (1913), it has shaped the public narrative in India.

While the themes of Hindi films have changed over the years --from the patriotic ‘Mother India’ to the sports-feminist ‘Dangal’, the presentation of nationalism, sports and sexualities may just be old wine in new bottles. We will examine these ideologies primarily through the lens of gender.

We will also explore how the language, fashion, music, dance, and social values embedded in Bollywood films are disseminated. International theoretical readings from ideas of nationalism, film, gender, class, and cultural studies, and literature from various parts of the world will underpin our discussions of Bombay’s film industry and our exploration of the values and ideologies embedded in apparently innocent entertainment.

[Please note –Supplementary readings and films may be assigned during the course of the semester. Film viewing is mandatory. Overview

Class timings Tue-Fri 11.50 am to 1.20 pm

The grammar tradition of Sanskrit is witness to many creations by acharyas at different points of time. Pāṇini is one of the most renowned acharyas of the tradition who in his creation/text, the Aṣṭādhāyī, compiled and organized different grammar and linguistic principles including those of syntax, distributional structure, phonetics, word formation, etc. Moreover, two widely studied characteristics of the text include scientific organization, and brevity of content. The brevity is made possible by various techniques, one of which is formalism.

The course, Introduction to Paninian formalism and linguistics, will present to students the formalism of the Aṣṭādhāyī' and some basic concepts of its linguistics. Besides Aṣṭādhāyī, some other supplementary texts will also be studied in parts to help the students get initiated into the system of Pāṇini.

Late papers will lose 10% of the grade for each day they it’s turned in late, up to a maximum of 50% off. The late penalty is calculated per hour (0.42% lost per hour). Your grade also depends in part on discussion participation.

Reading Quizzes (10% of your grade) are to help you focus on the important parts of the reading and to get instant feedback on whether you have understood the reading. There is one quiz per reading. The lowest 6 reading quiz scores will be dropped. You will earn maximum credit (10% of your grade) if your average reading quiz score (after the lowest 6 have been dropped) is 80% or higher. Otherwise you will earn whatever your average quiz score is.

Perusall Annotation Assignments (20% of your grade) allow you to collaboratively read the readings by using the Perusall website. Canvas has a document detailing examples of annotations you can make on Perusall and explaining the grading system. The lowest 6 Perusall annotation assignment scores will be dropped. You will earn maximum credit (10% of your grade) if your average reading Perusall score (after the lowest 6 have been dropped) is 80% or higher. Otherwise you will earn whatever your average Perusall score is.

500 Word Papers (20% of your grade) are short writing assignments designed to give you practice writing concisely about philosophy and to give you more detailed feedback about how well you are understanding the material. There are 10 due and the lowest 6 will be dropped.

Revisions (30% of your grade) are revised resubmissions of 500 word papers. Using my feedback and your own thoughts about how the assignment could be improved, you rewrite one of your papers with the aim of making it better. There are 6 revisions due and the lowest 2 scores will be ignored.

Discussion Participation (20% of your grade) can be earned discussion participation by participating in class discussions, by watching recordings of class discussions and posting a discussion response post on Canvas, or by posting discussion questions and replies.

Attendance Policy

Attendance at online meetings is not required but it is very very very recommended.
